text: Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers: Funding of Children's Services To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectFully showeth: That Federal Funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored Forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia. That Budget allocations For children's services be spent in Full For the purposes designated. That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped Forthwith. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Birney, Mr Bungey, Mr Carlton, Mrs Child, Mr Coleman, Mr Dawkins, Mr Fry, Mrs Kelly, Mr Morris, Mr West and Mr Young. Petitions received. Sales Tax Legislation To the Honourable the Speaker and Members oFthe House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectFully showeth: That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, Footwear, newspapers, buildings and Food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a Further burden on home builders; Families and children; inhibit the Free How of inFormation through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities. Your pPetitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should exempt these items From the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Adermann, Mr Braithwaite, Mr Free and MrJull. Petitions received. Sales Tax on Publications To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes. The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them From general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers. This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Child. Petition received. Sales Tax on Publications To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned, wish to protest against the Federal Government's proposed 2t per cent Sales Tax on books, newspapers and magazines. Sales Tax Legislation To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that: I. The 17.5 per cent sales tax on pet foods places unreasonable financial strain on pensioners and other pet owners. 2. A pet is not a luxury item for many owners, it fills a vital part of their lives and, in many cases, is therapeutically beneficial, particularly for families and pensioners. 3. The added financial strain may cause many people to abandon or otherwise dispose of their pets, thus adding to the distress of already disadvantaged people and further overloading the resources of animal welfare societies. 4. In view of the abandonment of sales tax on veterinary drugs, it seems inconsistent to tax pet foods when food is as much a basic need as medicines. We therefore request that this tax on pet food be immediately withdrawn. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Lionel Bowen, Mr Humphreys, Dr Klugman, Mr Leo MCLeay and Mr Morrison. Family Allowances To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: I. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount. 2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60%. Your petitioners most humbly pray that: The Parliament should actI. To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises. 2. To increase the spouse rebate from $830 to $1,342 per year. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling and Mr Falconer. Petitions received. Moreton Island: Sand Mining To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: I. That sand mining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment. 2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island. 3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed mining leases against the advice of conservationists and a State Government sponsored Public Inquiry. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray .that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling and Mr Humphreys. Petitions received. Plant Breeders' Rights To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government: I. Note that legislation establishing other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely: a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation. b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers. c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats. 2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from faIling into private hands. 3. Defend the vital interests deners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Duffy and Mr Humphreys. Petitions received. Unemployment Benefits To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That, as it is clear that lem in Australia, the Government should extend to the unemployed the same assistance as is given to any other disadvantaged member of the community. There is an urgent need to alleviate the financial hardship unemployed are suffering. Your petitioners therefore pray: I. That the Government adopt unemployment, 2. That the basic Unemployment Benefit be raised to at least the level of the poverty line as calculated by Professor Henderson, 3. In line with other Social Service additional income awards, and in order to encourage work creation schemes and the fostering of initiative and self respect, that the $6 per week additional income limit be raised to at least $20 per week, 4. That the financial penalties above the earning of $20 per week, assessed on a monthly basis, be calculated at the same rate as other Social Security benefits. 5. That the Commonwealth grant subsidies to state governments so that the unemployed can be granted transport concessions in order that they are not penalised injob seeking. 6. That pharmaceutical and medical concessions be granted to the unemployed equivalent to those received by other Socia I Service beneficiaries. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Armitage. Proposed Sinai Peacekeeping Force To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 pm and 6 am would(a) Substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep; (b) Contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Hon. (ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post-graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling-such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling. Petition received. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I am grateful that the honourable member for Adelaide, in his courteous fashion, has referred me to the consultancy report. I might refer the honourable member for Adelaide to the conclusions of the Committee on that subject. The Committee's conclusions were that the average cost of funds in that area would not vary appreciably. It concluded that there Notice of Motion would be rises in some areas and there could be falls in others. I remind the honourable gentleman that the Committee's recommendations are now before the Government. I have already indicated in the tabling statement a number of principles which will guide the Government's deliberations. So far as the assessing of that report is concerned, those principles include a concern to concentrate on the method of providing assistance to various areas of the community and the economy and not necessarily upon the levels of that assistance. In that I am in fact mirroring the approach of the Committee. I refer the honourable gentleman to page 624 of the report. I think it is very-salient that what was said be borne in mind by people who are objectively assessing the Government's response to this report. In a chapter dealing with sectoral assistance, the Committee stated: The Committee has not sought to assess the appropriate level of assistance to particular groups . . . The judgments involved extend well beyond questions of economic efficiency and are outside the Committee's terms of reference. The Committee has instead focused solely on the methods of assistance and their implications for the financial system. In adopting the approach that I outlined in my statement yesterday, the Government is being entirely consistent with the approach adopted by the Committee and is in no way in conflict with. the basic approach adopted by the Committee. . Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Is the Minister for Housing and Construction aware of a recent comment by his counterpart in the Victorian Government that this year Victoria will have to pay the Commonwealth $2.6m more in interest and loan repayments than it has received in its welfare housing allocation from the Commonwealth? Can the Minister confirm that repaynients of previous loans now exceed Victoria's allocation from the Commonwealth?

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I.am aware of the recent article in the Press by the Honourable Jeff Kennett, the Minister for Housing in the Victorian Parliament. I advise the House that there is a basic-I suspect mischievous-inaccuracy in the statement referred to. If the Minister cares to look at Table 101 in Budget Paper No.7-it is to be hoped that he can add and subtract-he will find that the allocation the Victorian Government will receive from the Commonwealth Government is $58.5m and that his Government has to repay $56.5m. That gives the lie to his statement. However, there is a more basic and fundamental fact to which his statement must be related. It is simply that since 1945 a long list of free enterprise governments have contributed a sum of $5,000m to the States for welfare housing on the basis of very low interest loans and straight-out grants. These loans have to be repaid over a period of 53 years. Quite obviously, the greater the number of years over which loans have to be repaid the more closely will the repayments approximate the amount given by the Commonwealth to an individual State in a year. We note that these payments are made not by the Victorian Government, but by the people who have loans and who are in receipt of rental assistance. To summarise, I repeat for the benefit of my counterpart in Victoria that this year no State in Australia will repay-not from its own money but from the money of renters and home ownersmore than it receives. I conclude by giving a couple of other examples. This year the State of New South Wales will receive $82.6m and will repay $71.4m. Queensland will receive $30.8m and will repay $19.1m. South Australia will receive $34.7m and will repay $31m. Those figures indicate that the Federal Government is quite .charitable in its contributions to the States for welfare housing. Inaccurate and mischievous sta tern en ts do nothing to improve Commonwealth-State relations. AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: NA

Speaker: Dr CASS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I direct my question to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommends immediate abolition of the 30-20 rule which requires certain institutions to hold a minimum of 30 per cent of their investment portfolios in government securities? Does the Committee indicate that it would be preferable to make government securities more responsive to market preferences? Would this mean that the Commonwealth, in order to market its debt, would have to raise the interest rates on its bonds, thus setting off a round of further interest rate rises and competition for funds in all sectors, as well as necessitating increased government taxes and charges to meet higher debt costs? In addition, would State and local authorities, which are also covered by the 30-20 rule, be forced to pay higher interest rates on their borrowings and also be forced either to curtail services or to increase taxes and charges?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is yes. The answer to the second part is that the real determinant of the price that governments have to pay for the amount of paper they shift is the total volume of paper they have to shift. When it comes to total volumes of paper that must be shifted, the Opposition can leave the Government for dead. The real determinant of the level of interest rates is ultimately the competitive demand for funds in the community. The best contribution that any government can make towards reducing the demand for funds in the community, and therefore reducing the price that one has to pay to raise funds in the community, is to reduce its own borrowing demands. Anybody who examines this subject knows that under our side of politics the borrowing demands of government are significantly less. NA NA

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney General. Does the Minister recall that earlier this year I was threatened with legal action by Medibank Private following my drawing public attention to the disastrous financial position of the fund in some States and the financial danger contributors to that fund were in if Medibank collapsed? Though I have since received an apology I am, therefore, law suit conscious. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent case in the High Court of Australia known as Shaddock v. City of Parramatta in which the Court has ruled that many individuals and companies providing information to others as part of a service will be liable for any negligence in providing the information if another has suffered loss by relying on it? Has the Minister considered the application of this decision to members of parliament and their staffs who are continually called upon by constituents for advice of a sometimes delicate nature which, if relied upon and incorrect, could cause a loss?

Speaker: Mr VINER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I am well aware of the involvement of the honourable member with Medibank Private. I am well aware of how law suit conscious he is. I should be careful about giving a dispatch box opinion for the benefit of the honourable member. The question that he raises is a very important one for honourable members and honourable senators. As we all know, in the course of doing our duty for members of the public we are asked for and we give advice to them on a variety of matters. It is questionable whether this decision in Shaddock v. City of Parramatta would, in fact, apply to advice given by honourable members. Nevertheless, there is a word of caution to be given to honourable members. For the information of honourable members. I just give a precis of the essence of the decision in Shaddock's case without giving any history of decisions by the Privy Council or Australian courts beforehand. The essence of the decision in Shaddock's case is that the duty of care is not so narrowly confined as was decided in an earlier case of MLC v. Evatt. A duty of care will arise whenever a person gives information or advice to another upon a serious matter in circumstances where the speaker realises or ought to realise that he is being relied upon to give the best of his information or advice as a basis for action on the part of the other party and it is reasonable in the circumstances for the other party to act on that information or advice. As to the applicability of that decision to the situation of honourable members and honourable senators, I will refer the question to the Attorney-General and provide further information to the honourable member. Mr Armitage- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I request that, in accordance with Standing Order 321, you require the Minister to table the document from which he has been reading. I know that he got into trouble once before.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The honourable member for Chifley will resume his seat. Was the honourable gentleman quoting from a document?

Speaker: Mr VINER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I would be glad to incorporate the paper in Hansard because it contains a reference to earlier decisions of the High Court and the Privy Council and may be of benefit to honourable members.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The Minister has asked for leave to incorporate the document in Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as followsSHADDOCK v CITY OF PARRAMATTA (A decision of the Full Court Prior to the decision in this duty of care exists a person can be liable for financial loss resulting from a negligent mis-statement of fact or opinion, although the mis-statement was honestly made and there was no fiduciary or contract ural relationship between the parties. The Privy Council had held in MLC v EVATT (1970) 122 CLR 628 that the duty of care is casf only on a person who carries on a business or proFession which involves the giving of advice of a kind which calls For special skill and competence or on persons who, while not carrying on such a business or profession, nevertheless profess to have a comparable competence. The essence of the decision in Shaddock's case is that the duty of care is not no narrowly confined and will arise whenever a person gives inFormation or advice to another upon a serious matter in circumstances where the speaker realises or ought to realise that he is being relied on to give the best of his information or advice as a basis for action on the part of the other party and it is reasonable in the circumstances For the other party to act on that information or advice. Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: My question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, concerns the suggestion in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System that the cost of the considerable increase in interest rates for home buyers, farmers and small businessmen that would flow from deregulation could be offset by budgetary measures such as subsidies or tax concessions. Does the Treasurer acknowledge that the cost of any such measure would have to be considerable if these groups were to be fully protected from the consequences of deregulation? Does the Treasurer also acknowledge that implementation of the taxation recommendations of the Campbell Committee would result in further considerable reductions in tax revenue? If so, does the Treasurer agree that the consequence of implementation of the Campbell Committee report and ensuring that protected groups remain protected by budgetary measures would be to greatly reduce the prospect or extent of a general tax cut which the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have previously indicated was likely to be forthcoming?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I am not in a position to give any quantification of particular measures that a government might decide to introduce in the future, given a certain set of assumptions in a certain set of decisions in this or, indeed, any other area. I remind the honourable gentleman that this report is of very great complexity. It has only just been received by the Parliament and I hope it receives a more detailed study from the Opposition than his remarks yesterday would indicate that it has been receiving. I do not know how any party of the High Court on 28 October 1981) in this Parliament could have seriously studied the case it was settled that when a report in the less than 36 hours that it was available to the Opposition to enable it to responsibly reach the conclusion that it reached yesterday. Yet, apparently, it is within the capacity of the Opposition to reach that conclusion. I merely repeat what I said to the honourable gentleman and the House yesterday in tabling the report-that there are certain areas where this Government has, and indeed, other governments have, over the years maintained priorities. The Committee essentially dealt with methods of assistance. It indicated in certain areas that in its view, on efficiency grounds, if governments wish to help a sector the best method of helping that sector is through direct budgetary assistance. Questions as to what volume of assistance, what direction that assistance might take and whether that method of assistance might be adopted are naturally questions for the future. I am certainly not, therefore, going to get into the business of ing hypothetical responses as to quantum and cost.

Title: ZZZZZ
text: I ask the Treasurer a question which does not concern the Campbell report. It concerns something more relevant. Has the recent sale of tap bonds been successful? Is the successful sale of tap bonds a necessary ing-edient for the future reduction of interest rates?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: -.:It is true to say that recent sales of government paper have been more succ-ssful. In fact, it would appear that, as a combmed result of the decisions taken at the Loan Council meeting just before the Budget and also the near balance achieved in the Budget, the tone of the bond market has changed appreciably. Although I am traditionally very cautious about responding to questions in this area, I believe the outlo-k in the interest rate area is more promising than It has been for some time. It is certainly a prerequisite to any downward movement that we commence selling government paper in a very significant volume. That certainly has occurred. I naturally enter a number of cautions, including the fact that to counterbalance the sale from the tap there have been significant net redemptions of Australian savings bonds which have offset the ?on-bank take-up effect of sales out of the tap. It IS still early days but the outlook is certainly better than it has been for some months. It would appear that the market sees the rates as being totally realistic. Of course, ultimately that is what influences whether we sell paper, be it public or private. AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: NA

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I made all the statements to TAP BONDS which the honourable gentleman referred. I do not resile from any of those statements in any way. I believe that the Committee was established against the background of this Government's commitment to a freer, less regulated and more competitive financial system. We would not have established the inquiry in the first place if we had not believed in those objectives. I remind the honourable gentleman that I repeated those objectives in my tabling statement yesterday. I said that many of the recommendations of the Committee were fully consistent with those objectives. I do not retreat one inch from what I have said about the objectives of the Government in this area, but that in no way alters the fact as the Committee itself acknowledges, that in r-aching decisions on reports of this kind the Government has to achieve an appropriate balance between considerations of economic efficiency and social - and political realities. Title: ZZZZZ
text: Is the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs aware that there is a continued disparity in the price of petrol, firstly between the capital cities of Australia and, secondly, the country areas of Australia? Will the Minister ensure that the inquiry pays special attention to the practices of oil companies in relation to the marketing of petrol? Will the Minister ensure that the inquiry or working party, as it has been described, be composed of, as well as academics, persons who have been actively involved in the industry?

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: ZZZZZ
text: At the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers conference in Adelaide just on a fortnight ago the questions of pricing, marketing and divorcement within the petroleum industry were discussed by all the State Ministers and the Commonwealth Minister. The honourable member will be aware that there is a divergence between the States in terms of thei,r pricing policies. New South Wales and South Australia have fixed prices. Yictoria is looking at this possibility. Needless to say, Queensland has no desire to move in that area. On top of that is the question of divorcement proceedings. In that area the Commonwealth has a particular law. The Victorian Government is looking at the same question. Because of this wide range of approaches the meeting decided to establish a working party consisting of officers of the various departments involved in that meeting. They have been asked to look at the consequences of the various regulations with the hope that we will be able to develop a common approach. That will take some time. It is probably worth pointing out that at present the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority justifies petroleum product prices in Australia, that this particular form of pricing is not accepted by New South Wales and is added to by other States by various State taxes. The price levels between the States thus vary enormously. It is also fair to say that it is a tribute to the forces of supply and demand that the prices vary enormously throughout Australia. In very few States at present are retailers getting the price for petrol justified by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. NA

Title: ZZZZZ
text: Does the Minister for Industry and Commerce recall the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission for the fork lift truck and associated industries, which, if implemented, would cause large scale displacement of workers in those industries? Will the Minister assure the House that the Government has no intention of implementing the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission and thus save this worthwhile local industry from closure?

Speaker: Sir PHILLIP LYNCH
Title: ZZZZZ

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Title: ZZZZZ
text: My question is to the Treasurer. It follows several that have been asked already. Does the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System indicate that interest rate controls are regressive, failing to assist those for whom the controls were intended? Will the Government take into account the need to adopt policies which favour poorer rather than more well to do people in determining policy for the housing capital market?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: As the honourable member for Moore pointed out in his question, it is a fact that, according to the view of the Committee, interest rate controls have a regressive effect.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: But not the view of the consultants.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Perhaps the honourable gentleman will contain himself. That is the conclusion that is reached in the Committee's report. One of the obligations of the Government. is to assess that conclusion and to form a view as to whether it agrees with it. I find it absolutely ing that a party that professes to be interested in the interests of low income earners in this country can, in 36 hours, dismiss a conclusion that argues against a regressive system in a report that has taken three years to compile. I think it is a very markable exercise in indifference towards an objective examination of whether the conclusions of the report are correct. Without seeking to pass a view as to whether the Government agrees with the conclusions of the Committee on this particular subject, I can say to the honourable member for Moore that in assessing the Committee's recommendations the Government, unlike the Australian Labor Party, will be concerned to ensure that the existing financial system does not have regressive effects on low income earners. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Order! The House will come to order. I ask all honourable gentlemen to remain silent. The honourable ladies have not interjected. The House will come to order. I ask every member to remain silent. I ask the Prime Minister to draw his answer to a conclusion.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: There are one or two points that need to be made seriously. Quite obviously, members from both sides of this Parliament have taken advimtage of loans that were available in the Australian Capital Territory at varying times. I want to make a point about the conduct of the Parliament and the way in which we do our business. Many former and present members of this Parliament have young families. Very few members of this Parliament can afford to have a home in the Australian Capital Territory and a real home in their own electorates or wherever they come from. For a long time. I have doubted the wisdom of moving members to Canberra on Monday or Tuesday mornings and moving them out on Thursday nights or Friday mornings. I believe that over time. I think it will take time because it is a habit that will die hard-we would probably do much better if we ultimately established the circumstances whereby members of parliament could come to this place for the session and then leave and have the electorates educated to understand that this is the way that they are going to get better service from members, electorally and through this Parliament. The amount of time that we all collectively spend travelling every week is enormous. It is all very well for me because I use a government aircraft which is a travelling office, but it is obviously very hard to work in a commercial aircraft. So there is an enormous waste of time for all members of parliament, which is dead time to them, while they are travelling. I believe that over time it would make more sense if there were arrangements that made it possible for members to establish a home in the capital as well as in their electorates. I am not suggesting that there can or should be any early change of policy in relation to these matters, but there is no doubt that the loans that were available to enable members of parliament to purchase homes in Canberra were in part a recognition of the very plain fact that I think most honourable gentlemen recognise. We do not conduct our business in the best way, with the best use of our time and to the best advantage of our eleCtors and of the constituency at large. I think that it is petty in the extreme for members of the Opposition to raise these points when they know that these loans are matters of long standing and were available to members of all parties. NA NA

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the New Zealand Government's supplementary minimum price scheme is now estimated to cost $200m this year to support, at this stage at least, wool, beef and skim milk powder export prices? What effect could this open-ended and massively expensive subsidy scheme have on international prices for these commodities, on closer economic relations between our two countries and on the level of the New Zealand dollar?

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The supplementary minimum price scheme was introduced by the New Zealand Government in 1978. It was said to be a temporary measure to assist farmers in achieving incomes which might more adequately provide for meeting farm costs than the stabilisation schemes which presently exist in New Zealand. I do not know how temporary the scheme is, but certainly this year it is estimated to cost an extra $200m. However, I note that most of that cost will not be on this year's Budget. I understand that most of that cost will be on the ensuing year's Budget. The scheme applies to lamb, mutton, cow beef, bull beef, prime beef, milk fat and wool. The honourable member asked about the impact on the international prices of commodities. I think that is difficult to assess. It is also difficult to assess the real cost of the scheme on the value of the New Zealand dollar. I quote what the Leader of the Opposition in New Zealand, Mr Rowling, had to say about the matter. It seems to be a complete quote from a newspaper article. It states: What we have got with the supplementary minimum price proposals is a government trying to head off the anger of the farmers by pitching SMP levels not at the market realisations or any relationship to the market realisations but at the escalating costs that are actually occurring on the farm. I draw attention to the point he made about market realisations because I think that is the aspect of it that in terms of closer economic relations with New Zealand we, as a Government, will have to study, along with other important factors such as the difference in the value of the New Zealand dollar and the Australian dollar. The value of the New Zealand dollar is running at about 140c to the Australian dollar. I think that the impact on CER is an important impact and is something that will have to be studied more closely. One cannot assume that there will be any quick conclusion to the CER study because of all the factors that are involved. Indeed, I think one can assume that it will be a very difficult process to get agreement between the industries on a number of the factors that are outstanding at the moment.
