Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Kennedy)-On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the Committee's report 'Threats to Australia's Security: Their Nature and Probability', together with the transcript of evidence. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: by leave-I thank the House and I also thank the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, the honourable member for Higgins ( Mr Shipton), for the privilege of being able to table this report. The purpose of this report is to canvass' the concept of threat within the Australian context. Throughout the report there is understandable reference' to Australia's relationship with the ,United States of America and the ANZUS alliance. In this regard I state at the outset that the more I observe and analyse the Australian defence situation the more I am totally convinced that our alliance, our understanding with the United States, is of critical importance to our security and to our defence. What responsible Australian would fail to appreciate the advantage of having such a powerful friend? What thoughtful Australian would not work and pray to bring about an even closer friendship with a people with whom we have so much in common and whose destiny in so many ways is so irretrievably associated with ours? This is the background against which I now present this report. The report is intended as a forerunner to further reports covering particular aspects of the terms of reference given to the Sub-committee on has Defence Matters on 26 February 1980 which are 'to monitor the implementation of the Australian Government's announced defence programs'. I must emphasise that this is not a report in the usual sense. It does not at all finalise the inquiry under our current terms of reference. The Committee decided that the terms of reference were so comprehensive, so all-embracing, that it would be better to report in significant segments that would highlight basic considerations such as the levels of threats to this nation. The report seeks also to provide a framework for public discussion of the subsequent issues. It is the Committee's view that no analysis of the defence program can proceed without a thorough understanding of the type of threats and contingencies which may be faced by the Australian defence forces. It is the Committee's hope that a frank discussion of such matters will dispel unnecessary fears, lead to, an informed appreciation of Australia's regional relationships and improve the climate of understanding between Australia and its neighbours. The report has considered threats to Australia under four headings: Firstly, the potential for global conflict and its implications for Australia; secondly, the invasion of Australia; thirdly, intermediate level threats to Australian interests; and fourthly, low level contingencies. With regard to each category of threat the report discusses the level of capability needed to pose the type of threat, which nation might have the capability, which nation might have the motive, the likely warning time involved and possible deterrents. The report devotes substantial space to the issue of global conflict because of the importance of this subject. However, I draw attention to the importance for defence planning of the issues, canvassed in chapters three and four. These deal with intermediate level threats and low level contingencies which might require an Australian response independent of the actions of our allies, and have serious implications for the structure and capacity of our defence forces. The Committee concluded that Australia would be a difficult invasion target. Australia is separated by oceanic distances from other countries. It has a considerable capacity to deter tial aggressors and its alliance with the United States of America involves the threat of retaliation against a major aggressor. Large scale attack on Australia is regarded as remote and improbable in the foreseeable future. It could be expected that such an eventuality would be preceded by a period of warning which is likely to include a severe crisis or confrontation between the Soviet Union and the United States. An assault on Australia would involve a very difficult military operation, as chapter two of the report explains in detail. Even for an economical\y advanced regional power it could be expected to take at least five years to develop a capability. Australia's relations with neighbouring countries and most regional states are good, despite some relatively minor irritations which develop from time to time. In fact there are currently no serious disputes with any member of the international community which in the foreseeable future could develop into motives for warlike actions against Australia. Nevertheless, the Australian Defence Force needs to continue to sustain a technological level relevant to those of regional powers to include those long lead time capabilities which act as a deterrent to hostile action. Australia needs also to maintain the skills relevant to operations in the region and to have the capability for the timely expansion of its forces. Although there is no discernible threat of invasion of Australia on which force structure can be based, there is a danger that the emergence of such a threat may take less time than is likely to be required to obtain long lead items of important equipment and increased trained manpower. There is therefore a heavy responsibility on our intelligence agencies and on those responsible for planning for a smooth expansion of Australia's Defence Force. This matter was taken very much into account in the recent operations at Shoalwater Bay. There was particular accent on that aspect and I believe that the results were very gratifying. A nation that spends relatively little of its gross national product on defence requires a relatively large and competent intel\igence effort. The Sub-committee on Defence Matters received significant evidence on the need to have appropriately trained intel\igence analysts. The report discusses elements current in the world situation that contribute to an uncertain global strategic outlook. The main risk or threat to Australia's security at present lies in a global context rather than in our regional situation-in the possibility of world-wide conflict or disruption poten- of the strategic balance between the superpowers. The deterioration in the global relationship between the super-powers, or possible conflicts in our region which might attract the support of one or both of the super-powers, could affect adversely Australia's strategic prospects. It is difficult to envision a serious strategic threat to Australia which would be unrelated to a major breakdown of the existing world order. There is likely to be continuing, and perhaps increased, tension and competition between the super-powers, particularly in regions where there is instability or confrontation. Nevertheless, on all rational calculations, nuclear war between the super-powers should be regarded as an unlikely eventuality because of the immense devastation which would result from such a conflict, which would wipe out any conceivable benefits to the warring states. In a nuclear war between the northern hemisphere powers, even if Australia were not directly targeted, we would be disastrously affected. One of the consequences of such a war would be a complete breakdown in international trade which, of course, would have catastrophic consequences for Australia's economy. Even if Australia were not seriously affected directly by radioactive fall-out from the northern hemisphere, there would be ecological consequences for the whole world which would also affect, of course, Australia. The report discusses the joint AustralianUnited States facilities at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape. I believe that the risks associated with nuclear attack on Australia, which might result from the alliance with the United States, are outweighed by the advantages Australia derives from the alliance. The ANZUS alliance is likely to act as a deterrent to hostile actions against Australia that would be beyond Australia's own capabilities. Australia is more likely to suffer from low level contingency type threats than from the threat of outright invasion, or from what the Committee has called intermediate level threats. Low level threats could arise at short notice and pose challenging problems. Australia would almost certainly be required to meet such threats from its own resources with little or no allied port. This calls for continuing emphasis on self reliance and on the possession of well balanced defence forces. Irrespective of whether significant threats to Australia develop, the Defence Force must be capable of undertaking current tasks. Current tasks include contributing to coastal and maritime surveillance. In the course of its inquiries the Sub-committee on Defence Matters devoted considerable time and attention to this question. Evidence was taken in many parts of northern and western Australia. Support for the law enforcement agencies against terrorism is also an important current task for the Defence Force. We know that considerable advances have been made in that area. The Australian Defence Force should also have the capability to contribute to United Nations and other international peacekeeping forces. The report stresses that the relative absence of short and medium term threats arises not only from Australia's fortunate geographical location, but also from the success, so far, of the war prevention strategy of the Western alliance and from the comparative strength of Australia's own defence forces within our own region. Indeed, the primary aim of a defence strategy is to prevent war and not to fight it. Reassurance as to Australia's security is available only so long as the perilous balance between super-powers is maintained or their armaments are dismantled and also so long as we continue to play our part in contributing to the Western alliance and in improving our own self-reliance within our region. Though we do not make firm judgments, we did set out conclusions, many of which could well be regarded as arguable. This is what they are intended to be. During the years I have had the privilege of chairing the Sub-committee on Defence Matters, its members generally speaking have accepted their responsibility as being one of profound and serious importance to our country. We see our role in three categories: Firstly, to provide a forum for those sufficiently qualified and experienced to express to the Sub-committee their valuations of the matters under scrutiny. Then we feel that the exposure of these opinions and the conclusions made on them should provide the Parliament, our masters, with sufficient opportunity to develop further the defence subjects under examination by a meaningful debate. In this regard it has always been my hope that such a debate would be bipartisan and constructive. Finally, we see our role as doing all possible to bring the whole matter of defence closer to the sup- Australian people, to have them feel an involvement in this supremely important element of our national life; that is, our security, our defence. I conclude on a personal note. I thank Mr Claus Ducker and Mr Robert King for the way they have worked with their staff with enthusiasm and obvious dedication finally to produce this report. Members of our Committee, whom I cannot thank enough, have time and again gathered from all parts of this vast country to spend long hours examining witnesses, analysing evidence and finally producing this report. I thank the Minister for Defence, Jim Killen, and senior officers of the Defence Force for their ever ready assistance to us. I thank the American Defence Attache, Colonel Jim Rider, for arranging the splendid briefing I experienced in Hawaii with the Commander-in-Chief, PacificCINPAC-Admiral Long and his senior officers. I am sure that this is not so much a recognition of my position as a tribute to our Sub-committee. I am convinced by my discussions with the American defence chiefs that they see how valuable a sub-committee such as ours is not only in offering a forum to responsible and qualified Australians, but also in being able to cement further our splendid relationship with the United States. I commend the Committee's report to the House. Mr MORRISON CSt George)-by leaveThe basic purpose of the report, as the Chairman of the Sub-Committee has outlined, is to provide a basis for a sane and sensible debate on the defence issues in Australia. As the title indicates, the report examines threats to Australia's security, their nature and probability. We undertook that analysis in measured terms and certainly not in the frantic and emotional terms that frequently mark the discussion of threats or defence in some sections of the defence community in Australia. The report concludes that a large scale attack on Australia is regarded as remote and improbable in the foreseeable future. It points out that it is difficult to envisage a serious strategic threat to Australia or to Australia's area of primary strategic concern which is unrelated to a major breakdown in the existing world order or to Australia's alliance with the United States. The report further notes that it is the presence of the joint facilities and the role that they could be called on to play in the event of war between the super-powers that provide the risk of attack. I believe that the report faces up squarely to the balance ofrisk and advantage in hosting the facilities. In fact, there is a large section in the report dealing with this balance of risk and advantage associated not only with the alliance with the United States but also with the hosting of United States facilities on Australian soil. All countries have an interest in the maintenance of a stable central balance between the super-powers, if by that it is meant a condition which prevails against the outbreak of war between the two super-powers, which would be horrendously destructive of all mankind. Australia, through the three main United States facilities on our territory, contributes to that United States deterrent capability. To the extent that that contribution plays a significant role in the maintenance of a stable central balance between the superpowers it can be justified. All countries also have a professed interest in disarmament and have encouraged the two superpowers to negotiate the limitation of nuclear arms. The Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty discussions, limited as they are, are a feature of that process. Intrinsic to reaching an agreement on arms limitation between the United States and the Soviet Union was the capacity of each superpower to conduct its own verification procedures. There is no doubt that SALT was predicated on adequate and detailedÂ· verification capabilities available to each of the super-powers and that Pine Gap, with its surveillance and monitoring capacity, was crucial to the United States acceptance of the SALT agreement. Therefore, viewed in the broad perspective of a stable central balance and of steps towards arms limitation, there are strong arguments in favour of Australia hosting the United States facilities. Nevertheless, very real risks are associated with the presence on Australian territory of the facilities. The United States nuclear powered and armed submarines, which receive communications through the North West Cape station, are part of the United States deterrent but equally they are highly potent offensive units which have a prescribed role should the international situation degrade and deterrents fail. Similarly, the very characteristics that enable the other facilities to be effective in verification have a relevance to situations that might arise in periods of increased tension possibly leading to open conflict between the two super-powers. For these reasons, the facilities are likely to be targets in the event of clear exchange between the super-powers. However, another likelihood has emerged in recent statements by the Reagan Administration over the last few weeks. The timing prevented the Sub-committee from a detailed examination of these statements. I think we can sum them upby saying that there is now a greater emphasis by the Reagan Administration on the possibility of limited nuclear war and the use of tactical or theatre nuclear weapons. But of particular significance to us in these recent very confused signals emerging from the Reagan Administration is the statement by the Secretary of State, Mr Haig, about what he describes as a demonstration strike. I suppose that we can only try to describe a demonstration strike in the sense of the old gunboat diplomacy-a shot across the bows. The notion is not really all that new because I can recall, as undoubtedly the Minister for Defence ( Mr Killen) can recall, a statement in 1975 by the then United States Defense Secretary Schlesinger to a Congressional committee that in a limited war situation the Soviets 'could, for example, just go after one of the communications systems to our submarines'. Of course, as we all know, North West Cape is one such submarine communications system. The danger is that, if the Soviet Union followed Secretary Haig's logic, North West Cape would be an ideal demonstration strike target. It would show to the United States that the Soviet Union was serious. Its loss would be serious but not crippling to the United States communications system and, as it was not on United States territory, it would be less of a provocation to the United States than a strike on similar facilities in the United States. That is what is bound up in this concept of a demonstration strike. It is in this context, the very real risks associated with the advantages, that Australia has a role to play. The arrangements for North West Cape, which were renegotiated by the Labor Government in 1974, prescribed Australia's consultation rights and made clear to the United States that the denial of the rights pursuant to the exchange of letters between the United States Ambassador and the Australian Minister for Internal Affairs in 1963 was not acceptable. That renegotiation was not a cosmetic change but was intended to give Australia a greater role in the operations of North West Cape. Following that renegotiation, a framework was put in place to allow for greater Australian participation. The opportunity thereby presented for a more active role for Australia, of course, depends upon the attitude of the Australian government of the time. The a nu- Fraser Government has not chosen to avail itself to the ftill extent of the opportunities thereby presented. A Labor government would certainly carryon from the position that we had developed prior to dismissal from office. The Australian Labor Party, in the statement made recently by the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden), has announced its intention of establishing a national security committee. One of the functions of that committee would be to analyse and to provide assessments from the Australian viewpoint of the United States and Soviet strategic concepts, capabilities and planning. We must have our own source of information on what developments are likely to exacerbate the risks associated with Australia's hosting of facilities and our own assessment of circumstances under which the United States is likely to act in ways which are inimical to our interests. We must also ensure that we are fully capable of utilising the formation that should be available to us from the surveillance systems which Australia hosts and that consultation procedures negotiated by the Labor Government are fully implemented. As the hosts of facilities that are acknowledged to playa significant role in the super-power balance, we have the opportunity of encouraging restraint and promoting meaningful disarmament between the super-powers. It would be, I must confess, an unaccustomed role for Australia, but the preparatory groundwork was laid by the last Labor Government. I trust that the debate of this report will lead to a revita1isation of Australia's interest in the nuclear power balance and an interest in the role that Australia can play in assuring that the world is not subject to the nuclear holocaust, the possibilities of which seem to be prevalent now in statements emanating from both Washington and Moscow.

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Casey)-by leave-As a member of the Sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which prepared the report which has been tabled by the honourable member for Kennedy ( Mr Katter), I outline briefly the hopes that I have for the way in which this report will be treated in the context of a forthcoming public debate. As previous speakers have said, there is a need in Australia for a sensible debate on the nature of threats facing Australia. To the extent that there is any debate on this subject, too much of it seems to go to one of two extremes. One extreme is that Australia is in dire danger of invasion and we must keep ourselves virtually on a war footing, on the point of national mobilisation, so that we can deal with any eventuality, however substantial, when it might arise. At the other extreme, some people say that it is alarmist to talk about threats, that Australia is surrounded by a vast amount of water anyway and that no one is likely to molest us: So, let us not spend any money on defence; let us spend it elsewhere. I believe that there is a need to involve in fence debate the reasonably well-informed citizen who has made no special study of defence but who may have some balanced perspectives to offer if he or she takes some time to study the issue. This is a major objective of our report-to involve ordinary citizens in a discussion about defence. There appears to be in Australia-indeed, in any democracy-a fundamental difficulty in maintaining a viable peacetime defence force. In a democratic community there are always other and more appealing claims forced upon governments by pressure groups and by the broader electorate. A government seeking electoral popularity in- will always be tempted to accede to these electorate pressures. When a democratic government decides that a bigger defence effort is called for and that more public funds must be devoted to military manpower and equipment, that government often feels that it has to justify higher defence expenditure and drum up public support by, in a sense, drumming up a threat. To obtain public support for a reasonable defence effort, politicians often in the past have had to go around talking up a threat, so to speak. We sometimes get into trouble eventually with our own rhetoric in this matter. r believe that the motto 'Walk softly and carry a big stick' is appropriate for Australia's defence effort. Australia should have a credible defence force, but without the Government having to raise unnecessary fears by exaggerated public statements about the threats we face. That is a difficult position to maintain in a democracy, as I have said. Accordingly, I welcome the publication of this report as, I hope, a major contribution to an informed public debate. There has already been some comment about aspects of the report which deal with the overall global nuclear balance. I do not want to add to the comments that have already been made except to say that I believe that there is some danger that those parts of the report could become a preoccupation in any public debate, compared with some other parts of the report which are not so spectacular but which deserve a great deal of analysis. Chapter I of the report refers particularly to the global nuclear situation. This is a source of fascination for many people who become involved in discussions and analyses about Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, about the throw weight of various categories of missiles and about whether certain installations at various points in the world are likely to be nuclear targets in various types of nuclear exchanges. This can have the unfortunate effect of diverting attention away from matters dia de- rectly within Australia's own control. We can have, for example, the situation in which people interested in selling nuclear air-raid shelters have an interest in drumming up fears about some imminent nuclear attack. We have seen that happen in Australia very recently. We have seen public statements made by public officials who unfortunately have given credence to some of those fears. The point I make is that we would be better advised to put all of that nervous energy and, indeed, that expenditure into working out how we, as a nation, can contribute to the lessening of world tensions and to the reduction of risks in our area of the world in particular. If we look at those parts of the report which deal with low level contingencies and with medium level threats, we read of several situations that Australia has actually seen occur or has come close to seeing occur in recent years. For example, under the heading 'Low Level Contingencies' we have listed matters such as 'sporadic intrusions into Australia's air space by military aircraft or smugglers'. That has actually occurred in Australia in recent years. We have mentioned 'the planned introduction of exotic diseases or the support of illegal migrants or drug-runners'. The support of illegal migrants into Australia has apparently occurred very recently. We have mentioned also 'external support for dissident elements in, or military pressures against, a regional country the security of which is important to Australia'. I suggest that the newly independent country of Vanuatu comes into precisely that category. Only last year we saw activities taking place in Vanuatu which were supported by outside elements and in which, through our defence co-operation program involving the Papua New Guinea forces, Australia eventually become involved, even if only to a marginal extent. However, those are the sorts of situations that have occurred. I believe that we ought to consider very seriously how our defence forces ought to be structured in order to meet these levels of threats so that we can respond quickly and effectively when the occasion arises. Let me give one example of what I mean by a rational defence debate which, in fact, leads us to proper conclusions about the structure of our Defence Force, having in mind the types of threats we might face. Many people in Australia suggest that we ought to have a significant effort in national service training on some broadly based level for the purpose of greater mobilisation of manpower, if that should be called for. Without debating in full the arguments for or against those propositions, let me say that if we faced an intermediate level threat or lower level contingency in one of the island groups off Australia's shore and our main defence effort had gone into providing the capability to raise an army of 200,000 or 300,000 people, but we did not have the capacity to get even a small number of people with our own facilities, our own ships and planes, to some point only slightly off-shore from Australia, then we would not be able to cope with the actual threat that had developed. We would have developed something which may look good on paper in terms of the figures that we could produce-the numbers of people we could put under arms if a major threat arose-but we might not be able to deal with the lower level threat which we were facing and which could become a real situation within a very short period. I draw attention to that part of paragraph II of the introduction to the report which states: Substantial space has been devoted to the issues concerning globalconfiict because of the immensity of the subject. However the Committee wishes to draw attention to the importance for Australian defence planning of the issues canvassed in Chapters 3 and 4. These deal with intermediate level threats and low level contingencies which may require an Australian response independent of the actions of our allies. Therefore they have implications for the structure and capacity of our Defence Force. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend this report to the Parliament and, indeed, to the public. Speaking for myself, let me say that there are aspects of the report which I would give a greater emphasis to in some areas, or less emphasis to in others, but I support the general thrust of the rep orr. I would say also, however, that if, as a result of the public debate other considerations are brought to light which cause me to change my attitude to any of our recommendations and conclusions, then I believe that that would be a very good result for the report. I am sure that no members of the Committee who are responsible for preparing this report would take a dogmatic attitude that they are irrevocably committed to every sentence in it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Swan)-by leave-As a member of the Sub-committee on Defence Matters of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I have much pleasure in supporting the remarks of the Chairman of the Subcommittee, the honourable member for Kennedy ( Mr Katter), in commending the report to honourable members for their consideration and to the public for debate. The Committee has addressed itself to one of the most difficult questions which confront Australian defence planners; that is, to define threats to Australia's security. Our geographic location is one of our principal strategic advantages. It gives us time to see a threat developing, but it makes the type of long term projections of a likely threat suitable for the appropriate planning of a force structure and weapons procurement program extraordinarily difficult. The absence of immediate threats to our security has not prevented Australians from becoming threat obsessed. The British military historian, Professor Michael Howard, said, after a visit to Australia in 1971, that there were more 'threat, experts' per square mile in this country than in any other of the many he had visited. The Committee confidently expects and wishes to encourage the minute examination of this report by those experts and others with an interest in the general public. The Sub-committee has a general reference to monitor the implementation of the Government's defence program. We did not feel that we could do this /',ffectively until had addressed the basis on which any defence policy for Australia must be made. We recognised the inexact nature of that task, but were no more deterred by it than anyone with an interest ought to be. We did not draw conclusions. The Committee report's real value is the systematic organisation and presentation of the problem. The report really is in two parts, One part deals with a level of threat which is largely a problem for Australian diplomacy rather than defence planning. This involves the question of threats arising out of involvement in a global war. The Committee does not see such a war as likely, but if it occurs we argue that aspects of Australia's alliance relationship make our involvement in that conflict highly likely. This includes the possibility of a nuclear attack on Australian territory, at least one directed to the joint defence facilities. We do not see this as a threat to major population centres, at least while those centres are not involved in basing allied military activity. This of threat-an attack involving nuclear tipped missiles-is not a problem for Australia's defence beyond the area of civil defence. As I said, we would never have the capacity to interdict such an attack; therefore, it is not a defence problem. But it is a problem for Australian diplomacy and I will say a little on that a bit later. The second level of threat which concerned the Committee was of various forms of conventional invasion and harassment. In the remainder of the report the Committee addressed itself to the question of motive and capability on the part of various nations or movements capable of posing such threats. 'I would say that most members of the Committee are optimistic that most contingencies at this level of threat can be dealt with from within Australian resources, provided we keep our priorities clear. As we point out, even the super-powers would require a massive diversion of resources and forward bases which they do not currently possess, to be able to mount an effective assault, assuming the development of the necessary motive on their part. We were supported in those views and came to those conclusions as a result of evidence given by various members of the Department of Defence. Defence policy based on deterring such an assault by appropriate maritime strike capabilities and the mobility of Australian land forces would make a difficult task almost impossible. It is my view that defence procurement and planning should be oriented to deal with the maximum possible conventional threat even though, because of the difficulties such a task may pose to a potentional enemy, this is less likely than lesser we conventional threats. Here I do part company with some of the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Casey ( Mr Falconer). The problems of minor harassment, such as those to which he referred, and limited lodgement, can be picked up on the way to achieving the primary objective of deterrence agairist major attack. Planning for the maximum possible threat that we can deal with from our own resources will, I believe, prevent us from being diverted by debilitating side issues along the way, as we have been diverted so often in the past in the planning of our defence policy and in our international commitments. The Committee's report and the very extensive evidence presented to it by government and private sources, which is also incidentally publicly available, will provide a useful data base for a serious and systematic discussion of these Issues. In conclusion, I refer back to an aspect of the Committee's report that I mentioned earlier, and level that was of a nuclear threat to Australia, The Committee discerned, as have Australian governments, a very clear Australian interest in superpower arms control agreements and multilateral nuclear arms control agreements, such as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We have documented why we should be interested. Instead of just saying that a potential nuclear threat exists, we have gone into detail as to the circumstances, the strategies adopted by the principal nuclear powers and the manner in which such a threat may come about and emerge in our region. In fact, in chapter 1 we go into detail as to the nuclear delivery systems which should be of interest to us as well as the particular strategies which are being pursued by the super-powers that could mean that they would come into use. For the sake of completeness, I want to incorporate in Hansard a research note produced in the journal of the International Institute of Strategic Studies written by one of the committee's witnesses, Dr Desmond Ball, which gives in greater detail than we felt justified information about Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles deployment. I would like to do that to assist further public debate on the matter. In particular, I believe that this would provide useful information on the use of an SS-18 missile to which we refer in the report. I seek leave of the House to have that document incorporated in Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as followsRESEARCH NOTE: SOVIET ICBM DEPLOYMENT (Dr Ball, Fellow in the Strategic & Defence Studies Centre, Canberra, is currently a Research Associate at the I1SS.) Since the United States put together the first Single Integrated Operational Plan (SlOP) in 1960, US target plans for strategic nuclear war have become extremely comprehensive. The current plan, designated SIOP-5, was approved in December 1975 and came into effect in 1976, but has been regularly up-dated and revised since then.' It includes some 40,000 potential target installations,' divided into four pal target groups, each of which in turn contains a wide range of target types. The four principal groups are Soviet nuclear forces, general purpose forces, military and political leadership centres and the Soviet economic and industrial base.' However, nowhere in the public clear targeting doctrines and basic national security policies is there any comprehensive description of this Soviet strategic target structure-the locations of the installations relevant to US targeting policy, the characteristics of the particular installations, and their geographical proximity to one another and to population areas within the Soviet Union. This is particularly remarkable since such considerations are not only the essential data of the military war planners but are also critical to any informed discussion of some fundamental questions of strategic policy. For example, the locations and characteristics of Soviet targets are obviously important factors in US strategic nuclear force structure development since they should, at least in part, inform decisions on the numbers and types of forces needed to attack them. They figure centrally in certain aspects of arms control measures and negotiations and the geographical relationship between the targets and the Soviet population centres is a key factor in assessing the viability of any strategic policies involving limitations and constraints, or of any targeting doctrines designed to destroy certain target categories (such as Soviet strategic nuclear forces) while limiting civilian casualties and damage to nonmilitary installations. These points are the subject of particular elucidation in the following discussion of Soviet ICBM deployment as these missiles are a primary element of the nuclear forces group of Soviet targets. As shown on the map on page 168, the Soviet ICBM force is deployed in 26 complexes.' Contrary to frequent observations that these complexes lie in a broad band astride the TransSiberian Railway, they are in fact distributed quite widely throughout the Soviet Union, with about half of them situated west of the Ural Mountains. According to the supplement to the F.Y. 1981 Military Posture of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Soviet Strategic Rocket Force deployed in these complexes consists of 1,398 ICBMs.' Some limited information is available which indicates the relative numbers and locations of some of the missile types that comprise this force. For example, there are reportedly 60 SS-13 ICBMs, all based at a single location.' The SS-18 deployment, which is limited under the SALT constraints to 308 ICBMs, is now essentially completed. These SS-18s are located in six fields in southcentral USSR previously occupied by SS-9s; each field contains eight or nine flights of about six SS-18s each.' The SS-II force was in the past far more widely deployed-in western USSR, around the Urals, and in three locations near the Mongolian border (at Drovyanaya, Olovyannaya and Svobodnyy).' Under the SALT constraints, the Soviet Union is allowed to replace 512 of these SS-II s with SS-17 and SS-19 missiles equipped with multiple independently-targetable reentry vehicles (MIRVs). According to the Organisation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the deployment of the SS-17 has been completed at about 150 silos,' suggesting that SS-19 deployment will level off in the near future at about 360 missiles. In general, the Soviet Union has continued the practice of Desmond Ball deploying different kinds of missiles in separate complexes, although there are two exceptions-Derazhnya and Pervomaysk, where 180 launchers consist of both SS-ils and SS-19s." Soviet ICBM Deployment In addition to these 26 ICBM fields, the Soviet Union reportedly has about 150 test and training launchers deployed at the two ICBM test centres at Plesetsk and Tyuratam; these are used for both research and development purposes as well princi- as for crew training and testing of operational ICBMS." Plesetsk is used principally for testing solid-fuel ICBMS (the SS-13 and SS-16) while Tyuratam is the test site for all the liquid-fuel ICBMS (the SS-II, SS-17, SS-18, and SS-19). Many of these launchers including eighteen SS-18s at Tyuratarn, are reckoned to have an operational capability. Soviet target structure Implications for US Strategy strategic discourse on nuThese locations are significant, first, from the perspective of US strategic nuclear force development and employment. About two-thirds of the complexes are located-deep within the Soviet Union, which enhances the US concern with respect to Qoth the range and defence penetration capabilities of her strategic forces. The depth and intensity of Soviet air defences poses special problems for bombers and air-delivered weapons, including short range attack missiles (SRAMS) and air-launched cruise missiles (ALCMS) that might be considered for use in some circumstances against ICBM sites or their associated command posts and support systems. These problems might be met partially by the development of longer-range missiles capable of being launched at stand-off distances outside the Soviet borders, but they may also require the employment of penetration aids. In the case of ICBMS and submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMS) there is rather marginal problem of penetration deriving from the deployment of the Galosh antiballistic missile (ABM) system around Moscow. As John Newhouse has noted, this system 'affords some protection to about 300 ICBMS deployed within its operating area '." Given that the Galosh has a range of something in excess of 200 miles, it is likely that the potentially defended ICBM fields are those at Kozelsk, Teykovo, Kostroma and perhaps Yedrovo, although there is some uncertainty due to the lack of data on the specific locations of both the ABM launchers and the actual ICBM silos. Of course, the 64 Galosh missiles currently deployed could not defend all of these 300 ICBMS as well as Moscow, but the capability must be given some consideration, particularly in scenarios involving very limited counterforce strikes. The question of range is especially relevant to the possibility that SLBMS might be targeted against the Soviet ICBM sites. These sites can certainly all be reached by the Minuteman and Titan 11 ICBMS, and by the bomber force, granted in-flight refuelling capabilities and appropriate penetration aids, but the situation with respect to SLBMS is problematical, depending essentially on the nominal operating areas of the fleet ballistic missile (FBM) submarines. The Trident I SLBM which is currently entering service has a reported range of about 4,000 nautical miles, whereas that of the Poseidon SLBMS is only about 2,500 nautical miles; however, the US Navy has repeatedly emphasized that this in, crease is to provide the submarines with a much greater operating area, hence maintaining t-eir survivability. against any advances in Soviet anti-submarine warfare. ThiS could well mean that some of the Soviet ICBM sites, and most particularly the SS-9-cum-SS-18 fields in south-central USSR, are beyond the range of US SLBMS, so that US counter-silo capability rests with two rather than three legs of the American Triad. This will become an increasingly important consideration if the counterforce potential of US SLBMS improves through the I980s. With respect to arms control, the question of the locations of Soviet ICBM deployments has figured in the SALT debate in two ways, quite apart from the issue of the numbers of i1es involved. The first derived from the deployment of the mixture of MIRVed SS-19ICBMS and single-warhead SS-II ICBMS in nearly identical launchers small towns of Derazhnya and Pervomaysk. This problem was eventually resolved in a Common Understandng to the effect that all launchers in any fields judged by the United States to contain MIRVed ICBMS would be counted as MIRVed launchers even though some might in fact contain singlewarhead missiles." The second concern, which was raised in US Senate Hearings in 1972, relates to the possibility of more general verification problems. According to Se-ator B.uckley, the monitoring of Soviet ICBM deployments IS particularly difficult because 'the general area in which Soviet ICBMS are deployed is in North-Central Asia, where the normal cloud cover is among the heaviest of any region in the Northern Hemisphere'." This concern might well have been alleviated had the location of the Soviet ICBM fields been generally known, since they clearly extend far beyond Central Asia and are mostly located south of in this wide deployment area might be covered by clouds at some times, the coverage is unlikely to be concurrently severe in all areas. In fact, many of the ICBM fields, including the SS-9/SS-18 fields, are in areas which are generally free of cloud cover. Targeting and Collateral Damage Finally, the particular locations of the Soviet ICBM fields implications for the development of viable strategic policies and targeting doctrines. For example, the geographic spread of Soviet ICBM sites suggests possible difficulties with strategic policies which attempt to control escalation and rely, at least in part, on Soviet attack assessment capability. Unlike the US, which has deployed her ICBMS generally in the centre of the country, the Soviet ICBMS extend across virtually the entire USSR. A Soviet attack limited to US ICBM sites would fall completely east of 115Â°W longitude and west of the Mississippi River, and early-warning and attack assessment systems to differentiate from an attack involving the major US population and industrial centres and the national capital. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: This means, I believe, that we should see our arms control stance as a central part of and fully integral with our defence strategy, not as a side issue in which we occasionally interest ourselves or something to be undertaken by the diplomats assigned to the arms control committee of the United Nations. It should be in the centre of our defence strategy and of our foreign policy stance, as it is in the centre of the types of situation which could, at some time in the future, create difficulties for Australia and pose a threat to Australian security. We have the right to comment on this matter. These comments are openly sought by virtue of the agreement to which the honourable member for St George ( Mr Morrison) referred and which was signed by the then Defence Secretary of the United Nations Administration, James Schlesinger, and Lance Barnard. The United States, by that agreement, invites our comments on a wide variety of strategic nuclear matters. The second reason why we have a right to comment is that we host facilities. This has been referred to already and I do not want to refer to it at any great length. From the evidence presented to our Committee on this matter-evidence at some considerable length-we discovered that those installations have a very serious contributing role in regard to arms control agreements. In assessing, as the honourable member for St George said, the balance of risk and advantage in the presence of those installations, that is one of the matters to be weighed in the balance. However, that arms control function will be meaningless if we are not to pursue a diplomatic strategy aimed at achieving arms control arrangements. We believe, as this Government believes and all other Australian governments have believed, that those arms control agreements are absolutely vital to Australian security. Our report makes clear, in detail, precisely why. I join in the comments of thanks of the honourable member for Kennedy to members of the staff of the Committee. They did an excellent support job for the investigations that we undertook. In conclusion, I hope that the general public will treat this as a seminar document, a document for a widespread public discussion. If it does, I believe that it will be of considerable value to the defence debate in Australia for many years to come.

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Higgins)-by leave-I welcome this report, as it has been welcomed by other members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, as a contribution to the defence debate in Australia. As the Chairman of the Sub-committee, the honourable member for Kennedy ( Mr Katter) said, it is an interim report and Committee, Briefing on COUlllerit must be seen as a report that raises issues for discussion in the Parliament and the community rather than a report that makes particular recommendations at this time. As the Chairman of the Sub-committee pointed out, the report makes no firm judgments but does set out some conclusions on the evidence before it. It is important that the report be seen for what it is; that is, a contribution to the debate. This must be clearly understood. The honourable member for Casey ( Mr Falconer) made a good point when he said that, in his view, no member of the' Committee was firmly committed to every sentence of the report and that the public debate may, in fact, throw up other aspects of the defence debate that will cause honourable members and senators to change their minds. In any discussion of a report of this nature it is important to reflect on the United States alliance and Australia's relations with that country. I think that Australia's relations with the United States, particularly the ANZUS alliance, are the basic uinbrella of defence for Australia. The United States alliance is as important now as it was at the time of the Battle of the Coral Sea. I was distressed recently, in talking to some higher school certificate students in Melbourne, to find that they had not heard of the Battle of the Coral Sea. Our alliance with the United States is our most important alliance and is vital to the security of Australia. But the relationship between the two countries must be based and is based on mutual respect. I reiterate that it must also be one in which Australia is in no way subservient, nor does it have a subservient role, to the United States even though it is not a super-power, as is the United States. In speaking today, I see my comments as additional to the comments in the report. I would have liked to include in the report as printed some comments under the heading 'additional comments', but under the Standing Orders one can only table and note a dissent or a protest. I certainly do not want to note a dissent or protest in those formal terms because the very nature of the report is one that raises matters for discussion. The course open to me is to comment in the House today on some additional points on the report itself. The report mentions a number' of countries in the region and makes comments about some particular countries. In that regard, I can do no more than refer to paragraph 2.23 of the report, which states: Australia's relations with neighbouring countries and most regional states are good despite some relatively minor irritations that develop from time rently no serious disputes with any member of the international community which, in the foreseeable future, could develop into motives for warlike actions against Australia. I believe that that paragraph is paramount. I believe that that paragraph needs to be taken into account in any examination of the report and consideration of the countries mentioned. Two countries that spring to mind are Japan and Indonesia. The report comments also on the question of the joint Australia-United States facilities in Australia. I think it is important, at the outset, to refer to the comments of the Chairman of the Sub-committee in tabling the report when he said: I believe that the risks associated with nuclear attack on Australia, which might result from the alliance with the United States, ar!' outweighed by the advantages Australia rives from the alliance. I believe that the report supports the proposition that the presence in Australia of the joint facilities poses a much lesser risk to Australia than not having them. I refer to paragraph 1.76 and to conclusion 10 because these are two paragraphs that are relevant to the debate on the joint facilities. Paragraph 1.76, in part, states: The SALT agreements were predicated on adequate and detailed verification capabilities. played in this regard by the joint United States-Australian facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar is vital. I differ with the comments made by some of my colleagues in this regard, particularly the comment made a few moments ago by the honourable member for Swan ( Mr Beazley) when he said something along these lines: 'The Committee discovered that these facilities had a contribution to make to arms control arrangements'. I do not believe that the evidence taken by the' SubGommittee supports that conclusion. Some of the evidence quoted in the report-evidence which was taken from a Dr Desmond Ball-is of opinions of Dr Ball and that is all that it is. Some conclusions were drawn also from some of Dr Ball's evidence and paragraph 1.50 states: It would seem from what has been said These are Dr Ball's opinions and the report uses the word 'opinions'that the Soviet Union is likely to think that the North West Cape installation . , . Pine Gap and Nurrungar are connected in one of the following ways . . . Inasmuch as that might be seen as a committee observation and determination I do not think that anybody could draw that conclusion. It gives some credibility to an opinion that I personally do not think it deserves. I have examined the public evidence given by Mr Mathams, former director of Defence Scientific and Technical Intelligence, where he said: to time. In fact, there are curI have no comment to make on the joint facilities in AustraliaI point out that evidence also to the House.

Title: ZZZZZ
text: Read the report.

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I am reading the report. I am reading from the evidence of Mr Mathams at page 1349. He said: I have no comment to make on the joint facilities in AustraliaI am sorry that the honourable member for St George saw fit to interject but I read that part of the record into Hansard because of his intervention. Similarly, I believe that the comment made in paragraph 1.76, concerning a part of the de- evidence of Dr Ball does not support the comment in conclusion 10 which states: , The presence of the installations can be justified in terms of their contribution to the central balance between the superpowers . . . It is a matter of opinion. In my opinion the comment in conclusion 10 is based on the comment in paragraph 1.76. As I said, it is only a comment. In my opinion, on my analysis and on my reading of the evidence, it is not evidence upon which one It would seem that the part can make those comments or draw the conclusion which has been reached in conclusion 10, or that part of it to which I have just referred. At this stage, I refer also to the visit by some honourable members of the Joint Committee to some of the joint facilities. I am sure that honourable members will agree that the Committee received no evidence during its visits to those facilities which would support any of the conclusions in the document tabled today. Even though there may be some agreement or disagreement as to what are the conclusions in the document today, they are based on the evidence given to the Sub-committee referred to in the document and are not the result of any evidence obtained by visits by the Committee to any of the facilities. I believe that the report recognises that fact. I be. . . lieve that the House will clearly understand that fact. The report analyses threats of various sorts which are set out. 1 welcome the discussion and analysis of threats in the debate today. I point out that honourable members must always remember-this is always a case of eternal vigilance as honourable members obviously know that the strategic environment can often change rapidly and unpredictable threats can arise at any time.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Melbourne Ports)-by leave-The report that has been tabled by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is an important document. I believe it is important in this way: It is basically a consensus document which is concerned to consider the range of threat which must be considered by defence planners and the Government in the maintenance of an effective Australian defence capacity. It has reached some fairly broad conclusions. I believe the importance of the report lies not so much in the conclusions that it has reached but in the number of questions that are pqsed and the way in which those questions are posed. I believe this is probably the first occasion when any parliamentary committee has considered the threat of nuclear war, its impact and effect upon Australia, and the way in which Australia could unfortunately be involved in such a conflict. I say to the Chairman of the Joint Committee that, on the evidence given to the Committee, it reached the conclusion that while the joint American facilities within Australia played an important rolehonourable members might have 'their own views as to the significance of the role that they played-the conclusions that the Committee reached were not just based on the evidence of Dr Ball. There was substantial evidence which indicated that those who examined this matter had reached the conclusion that the presence of those bases made them a likely target in the event of nuclear conflict between the Soviet Union and the United States of America. I think that is a view that has also been supported in the House by the Minister for Defence ( Mr Killen) and the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden). Mr Killen-I have offered no view on that whatsoever. My friend does me a great disservice.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: ZZZZZ
text: If the Minister takes that view I apologise to him. I was not concerned to do him any disservice. I rather recall that the Minister tended to be quoted in respect of a statement about potential nuclyar threat. But if he says that he has not made that statement. I certainly adopt what he says as I do not want to misrepresent him. I think the importance of this document lies in the fact that whatever view one might take members of this Committee or parliamentarians have a wide range of deeply held views about the role that Australia must play in its defence preparedness. They are differing and strongly held views. I think it possibly says something for the effectiveness of the committee system that despite the depth and divergence of those views members of parliament are capable of sitting together, weighing the evidence and producing a consensus document which, as I have said, is concerned not so much with inviting conclusions but to posing questions which we hope will be very seriously considered not merely by the Parliament but by the people of Australia. I think that is the real significance of this report. I think that some of the generalities which have coloured the whole approach to Australia's defence preparedness were long overdue to be dealt with in the way that they were approached in the Sub-committee's report. We realised that we had to deal with some sensitive issues when looking at the question of regional threat and the way in which any Minister or any government has to deal with that subject. Those issues, I think, were faced squarely and objectively. The major conclusion that was reached, I believe-and fairly reached-is that the major threat which could affect us lies in the possibility of a major nuclear conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union. I think the Subcommittee performed a useful service by pointing out the awesome display of weaponry that exists in the arsenals of both the United States and the Soviet Union and the faci that those nations have an overkill capacity of about five or six. There is an analogy used, not directed against the United States but in terms of technological development, that one United States Polaris submarine has enough nuclear strike capacity to destroy every major: Soviet city with a population over 150,000. That is the kind of evidence that I think has to be thought about seriously by the community because it is equally true that, just as the United States has that capacity, so too does the Soviet Union. Therefore I think that makes it even more important that the Australian Government, in considering our defence role, gives a great deal of importance and a great deal of emphasis to the need for continuing discussion between the United States and the Soviet Union on the whole question of disarmament. If one takes the view of this Government that Australia has to operate within the framework of the American alliance, that does not prevent us, within that alliance, within the United Nations and in the world assemblies, from raising our voice to point out that the greatest single threat to the people of this nation, and indeed to the people of the world, is the threat of nuclear conflict. Already there are very considerable movements in Europe. People are concerned that Europe could in fact be turned into a nuclear graveyard as a result of what is glibly described as limited nuclear conflict. I believe the impact of those movements will ultimately be felt in Australia. Whichever view one might take of these issues, I think what is important is that we now have a document which, for better or for worse, puts the range of arguments that have to be considered by every parliamentarian and by every citizen upon which an informed debate can take place within the Australian community and the Australian defence establishment. I thank my fellow members of the Subcommittee because I believe all members made a genuine attempt to put aside their own political attitudes to produce a document which was based on fact. I particularly thank the officers of the Parliament without whose work and dedication this report would not have been available. I think it comes to the Parliament as a document on which a useful and informed debate upon the whole question of the range of threats that face Australia may be predicated.
