Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Werriwa) (4.0)-I move: That this House censures the Minister for Communications for having misled the Parliament with respect to his edge of activities by the Australian Dairy Corporation under his ministerial control. At the weekend, the Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) described critics of his dear old mates the Minister for Communications ( Mr Sinclair) and the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Nixon) as 'toad-like creatures skilled in the personal smear'. At the outset, I wish to say that my croaky voice has nothing to do with the Deputy Prime Minister's statement. I think the Deputy Prime Minister was rather upset because there have been new developments in this case. Previously we had been discussing the findings of an all-party committee, a committee that came down with a unanimous finding. We had been discussing matters that are subject to widespread public debate and we had been discussing the whole concept of ministerial responsibility. No doubt the Deputy Prime Minister was stung also at the weekend by the disclosure that his house in Canberra is subsidised by the taxpayers to the extent that he pays only 4.75 per cent interest; but, basically, he was upset because people dare question those of his mates who are born to rule. This is the National Country Party's problem. There is cine rule for it and another rule for the rest. According to the Country Party's double standards, it is okay for the leader of the National Country Party in the New South Wales Parliament to smear an innocent man under parliamentary privilege. It was okay for the right honourable member for Flinders ( Sir Phillip Lynch) and the right honourable member for New England to use smear, innuendo and lies to hound Connor and Cairns out of this Parliament. But, no; the Opposition is supposedly not allowed to raise questions relating to this report of an all-party Senate committee which cast serious doubt on the capacity of the Minister for Communications to tell the truth. The question of ministerial responsibility demanded and still demands debate. If this Parliament has standards or is not to be run by the cowshed Cabinet, which the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the top three Country Party Ministers so cynically form, these matters must be debated. There, are double standards galore. The Prime Minister is the master of the double standard. I would like to refer to the standards of previous parliaments.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Mr Millar) - Order! I invite the honourable member to be relevant to the motion that he has before the House. There must be some limit to the latitude that the Chair can extend to him.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I was trying to prove that, given that we have a Case of ministerial responsibility, knowlwe need to have consistent standards applied. I when was going to point out that Connor resigned from this House because he left out one sentence in a statement and that Senator Withers was dismissed from the Cabinet-he was a Liberal-because he might have said something in a telephone conversation. What I am referring to are the double standards in this House. What we are talking about is ministerial responsibility. On that question, as I have quoted to the House before, the Prime Minister said: It is certainly true that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments . . . But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should take responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign. I was pointing out that these are the sorts of standards that are now hot air. Although the present Prime Minister may have believed in them when he made that statement, it is certain that those standards are not being applied in this House because the Prime Minister will do nothing. That is why his language is not believed and that is why people cannot trust anything he says. This is the third time in as many months when the Minister has been the subject of a censure motion raised by the Opposition. On both occasions, the censure was directed towards the Government or the Minister for failure to ensure adequate and proper standards and for lack of ministerial responsibility. On both occasions, the main questions were whether the Minister for Communications knew of the continuing breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade with respect to the sale of skim milk powder, whether the Minister had acted promptly in ensuring that the breach did not continue and whether the conclusions of the all-party Senate committee which investigated Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd could be upheld. Honourable members will recall that, in the personal explanation of the Minister for Communications of 16 March 1981, his speeches of 17 September 1981, 22 September 1981 and of 29 October 1981 and in correspondence with the Senate Committee on several dates commencing on 16 March 1981, the Minister categorically denied that he knew of the continuing breach of the GA TT agreement and that, once he learnt of it, he took steps to stop the breach by issuing instructions to the Australian Dairy Corporation which in his view, from that point on, had the responsibility of ensuring that no further breaches occurred. The Minister refused to give sworn evidence to the Committee, stating that his ministerial oath meant that his correspondence was sufficient. The Minister confirmed his recollection of the events in 1976 in clear and unequivocal terms in statements to the House of Representatives. At the weekend the Minister did not deny the latest sets of allegations; that is, the latest sets of allegations appearing in the PM interview on the Australian Broadcasting Commission network last Thursday. I do not think he denied them because they are facts. He simply said that his memory is worse than those of other people. So, all of this business of posturing about toad-like creatures and character smearing is nothing more than a manifestation of the fact that the Country Party thinks it is born to rule, as does the Liberal Party. They can have double standards-one standard for the Australian Labor Party and one for the coalition-one for the Liberal Party and one for the Country Party. At all times the Minister said that the breach of GATT would be totally unacceptable. I will read what the Minister said on other occasions. In his letter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, he said: Such an arrangement, if known about, would have been totally unacceptable to the Government. In his speech on 17 September, as recorded on page 1484 of Hansard the Minister said: I strongly support the contention that action should be taken by a government with a chairman of a statutory corporation or a subsidiary of a statutory corporation if it finds there is a breach of an international arrangement. Such action was undertaken by me immediately evidence came forward to that effect. He is saying that the arrangement was totally unacceptable. He keeps on saying that he took immediate steps to end the breach. Again, I quote from Hansard wherein he stated: I recall discussing the situation with the then Chairman of the ADC, Mr A. A. S. Webster in November 1976 and requesting him to take action to rectify the situation so that the GATT minimum price would be observed. At page 1601 of Hansard he stated: . . . there was a reference by me directly to the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, immediately a breach of this arrangement under GA TT had been identified, requesting that he terminate those arrangements and ensure that the obligations under that arrangement be met. He drew the attention of the House to other statements that he had made. We have other evidence of the Minister's categorical position on whether he believes that immediate steps should be taken to end the breach and on the concept of ministerial responsibility. I refer honourable members to page 2694 of Hansard. The Minister stated: I urge those honourable members who wish to pursue the matter further to analyse the great volume of reports that my colleague has tabled. I might point out the fact that everything has been tabled other than some reports which the Australian Federal Police Commissioner has suggested should not be tabled, and they relate only to some evidence obtained by the Federal Police. If one looks at these reports one sees that at no stage did any member of the Ministry or the Government have any knowledge of these mailers. As soon as there was knowledge, of course, action was taken. I am trying to make a case that the Minister at all stages has said that any breach of the GATT arrangement would be totally unacceptable and that once he learnt of it immediate steps to end the breach would be put in train. Now we have a new situation. All previous debate on this question related to the Minister's having a knowledge of the continuing breach of GATT, not the initial breach, and whether he knew in September ot November 1976. It was subsequently shown that he knew of it on 9 November 1976. So, there is a bit of a question about whether the Minister knew of it in early September 1976. Nearly all discussion in this House in the two censure motions and the debate concerned the sale of skim milk powder to the Philippines subsidiary, Holland Milk Products Inc. Now, we have evidence of Mr Jack MCGuire of the Murray-Goulburn Dairy Co-operative Ltd and the Minister for Communications who is at the table knowing of the GATT situation on about 4 April 1976. In other words, he knew of a GATT breach that was in the offing. He knew of the GATT situation at that time.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Shame!

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Indeed, but before I get on to that matter, let me take honourable members back over the evidence thus far and examine the Minister's reply in the light of evidence that has now come out-evidence, incidentally, that the National Country Party never thought would come out. There have been three possible breaches of GATT. There was a breach when the price fell under the GATT limit on about 5 April 1976. The Australian Dairy Corporation and the New Zealand Dairy Produce Board negotiated jointly to sell $5tm of skim milk powder to Mexico at a price close to and possibly below the GATT minimum. The sale was approved on 2 April 1976 at an ADC board meeting. The price returned to the ADC was nearly $10 a tonne under the agreed world minimum price. It is the records relating to this sale which have been deliberately falsified to demonstrate that the GATT minimum pricing arrangement had not been breached, according to the General Manager of the Australian Dairy Corporation. The second breach was the HOMPI rebate. This was negotiated in early 1975 when the price for skim milk powder was $670 a tonne. The fall in the world price to the GATT minimum coupled with a $25 a tonne rebate appeared to the ADC board at its meeting on 2 April 1976 to constitute a prima facie breach of Australia's obligations under GATT. The board agreed that the rebate would have to stop on 2 April 1976. However, no apparent action was taken to end the rebate until 1 September 1976 when a telex was sen.t by the Department of Primary Industry to the ADC drawing the attention of the ADC to the apparent GATT breach. A further two months elapsed before moves to end the rebate are recorded elsewhere. On 13 October 1976 Mr Webstertold a meeting attended by the chairmen of other statutory authorities and officers of the Deunacceptable partment of Primary Industry that the $25 a tonne rebate on sales to HOMPI had been discontinued. The third breach occurred when Mr MCGuire, Chairman of the Murray-Goulburn Dairy Cooperative, reported that Murray-Goulburn in April 1976 received a firm offer to purchase about $5m worth of skim milk powder. MurrayGoulburn applied to the ADC for approval on the same day as the Corpora ton approved the Mexico deal. The price offered to Murray-Goulburn was $US340 a tonne, in breach of GATT, but returned to Australia almost exactly the same as the ADC contract with Mexico. The ADC refused to give export approval because of the GATT breach. Mr MCGl ;re raised the matter with the Minister who is presently at the table and the Minister raised the matter with Mr Webster of the Australian Dairy Corporation who said that the ADC could not approve because the sale would be in breach of GATT. I can go through all the evidence and counterevidence, what transpired in each of these breaches. What we are mainly talking about now is the evidence of Mr MCGuire and whether we can now say very clearly that the Minister had knowledge of a potential breach of GATT as early as April 1976. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the relevant parts of the PM interview which come from the Press office of the Prime Minister and which have been incorporated in Hansard in the Senate. Leave granted. The document read asfollowsNew revelations in the hands of 'P.M.' in the Asia Dairy InÂ· dustries affair could involve the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Ian Sinclair, in further controversy. Simon Nasht: The major criticism surrounding Mr Sinclair in the Asia Dairy affair is that while Minister for Primary Industry, he failed to ensure that many doubtful practices within the Dairy Corporation at the time were firstly not identified and secondly, once discovered, weren't corrected. Mr Sinclair denied these claims, saying that in many cases, the Dairy Corporation and particularly its former chairman, Tony Webster, were keeping the problems from him. Mr Sinclair say that when he did become aware of the problem areas, he acted quickly to put a stop to them. One of the main areas of controversy surrounds contracts made by the Dairy Corporation which breached Australia's international trading obligations under the GATT-the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In one particular instance in which the corporation was selling skimmed milk powder to the Philippines, the Senate enquiry which investigated these sales came to the damaging conclusion that it preferred the evidence of Mr Webster in these events rather t'an that of the Minister, Mr Sinclair. Mr Sinclair has attacked that finding strongly, and repeatedly defended himself by saying at no time would he consider contracts that meant GATT would have been breached. In evidence to the Senate enquiry, and I quote, 'Such an agreement, if known about, would have been totally to the Government.' And again, two weeks ago, he told Parliament in a carefully worded statement which centred on his responsibilities as the Minister, he said, 'it was not for me to do other than to direct that sales should not be made under the GATT arranged price. At no stage did I in any way accept that there should be international sales by the Dairy Corporation, its subsidiaries or any other private organisation that might have breached that direction.' At the time in question, in the mid seventies, the world price for milk pOWder, was tumbling, leaving Australian producers with a huge excess of products which seriously threatened the industry. The price fell so quickly that contracts that we had overseas with buyers were taking our Government and private industry suppliers perilously close to the agreed GATT minimum price of $350 US a ton. In fact, the world price slumped below GATT in April 1976. Despite the fact that the price slumped below GATT in April and the Dairy Corporation was aware of this, Mr Sinclair has said the first time he was made aware of the possible treaty breaches was at the earliest, September that year, vital months later. However, 'P.M.' has now information that Mr Sinclair was approached well before that date by a private company to approve a contract worth well over $sm which was clearly in breach of the GATT minimum price, and despite his often repeated policy that the Government totally opposed such arrangements, he was prepared to take the approach to the Corporation chairman, Mr Webster. The context surrounding these events is important. In April 1976, Australia jointly negotiated with New Zealand to sell $s.2sm worth of milk powder at a price perilously close and possibly under the GATT minimum because of deductions being made for freight charges. In any event, the money returned to the Dairy Corporation was nearly $10 under the agreed world minimum price, but in the desperate circumstances, it was approved. A report handed to the present Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, last month, reveals that recent attempts this sale had been frustrated because crucial files are now missing and those left behind, have, in the words of the Corporation's General Manager, Brian Norwood, been deliberately falsified to demonstrate that the GATT minimum pricing arrangement had not been breached. At that time, one of the Corporation's board members was the managing director of one of Australia'S largest dairy companies, Murray Goulburn Co-operative, Mr Jack Macquire. As Mr Macquire recalls it, on the very same day the Corporation approved the Mexico deal, his company applied for approval to export another huge pile of skim milk powder at least as big as the Government contract. The price offered to Murray Goulburn was $340US, in breach of GATT, but returning to Australia almost exactly the same as the corporation contract at a time when the industry was facing the corporation refused to give export approval because of the GATT breach, leaving Mr Macquire furious. He told the board of management he was left with no option but to raise the sale with the Minister. Soon after, a meeting with Mr Sinclair was arranged for Macquire by Canberra lobbyist, Mr Peter Cullen. It took place late at night at approximately 11.30 after the Minister had finished in Parliament. Reports of what took place at that meeting that Mr Macquire pushed strongly to have Murray Goulburn's offer approved, using the Corporation's Mexico contract to support his case. Despite the fact that Murray Goulburn's offer breached GATT, Mr Sinclair was sympathetic. So much so, that despite the late hour, he agreed to reach Mr Webster and discuss it with him while the meeting continued. Mr Webster was woken up at a Canberra motel, and on a conference phone so everyone present could hear, Mr Sinclair enquired from his chairman as to why approval had not been granted. At least twice during a substantial conversation, Mr Macquire recalls Webster telling the Minister that the contract could not be approved because it would infringe the Government's GATT policy. Mr Macquire does not believe that Mr Sinclair was directing the Corporation's chairman to breach GATT, but it raises serious questions as to why, in the light of the Government policy, Mr Sinclair pursued the matter. Also, in the light of the Minister's evidence to the Senate enquiry that he was not aware of GATT breaches by the Corporation until late in 1976 the matter of the Corporation's Mexico deal being raised also becomes significant at this meeting took place months earlier. Mr Macquire has agreed to talk to 'P.M.' about what happened that night in Mr Sinclair's office. Mr Macquire: We had an enquiry and a firm offer for powder that was less than the GATT price, and as is normal, the general manager of our company, I think it was, that submitted this to the Corporation, , it came up. I am not sure, exactly sure, if it was the same day or around about that time, for discussion and it got agreed to. The Corporation did not agree to make that sale on the basis that it was under GATT. Question: But on the face of it, it was on terms that would have been very similar to the Mexican deal. Mr Macquire: Well, that's true. It would have returned SOc a ton more to the pool than the Mexican deal, and I was a bit concerned about it because I had watched a lot of powder from Australia because of prices that I felt were set higher than world prices come down from, say, $600, right down, and I was concerned that this was a sale that as it returned to the pool this amount, and I could see in the next few months it was going to go low, and it finally did go lower inaudible powder was finally sold, disposed as stock food. I think for around about $180. Yes. I was concerned about it. Question: You must have been pretty worried. The industry itself was going through a whole lot of turmoil at the time. Here was a deal-even if it was 15,000 tons at the GATT by the Corporation to investigate minimum, it was worth $s.2sm, to you. It was a big deal. You were going to get a price, in fact, that returned more, than the Mexican contract. Mr Macquire: That's true. Question: It must have worried you Mr Macquire: It did worry me. It worried me to no end. It didn't really affect our company as a company because whatever these prices came, and that view included some sales made at 6.5, some 6.75, not much, but some, but it was an equalised thing, and we I think were aware the Government had agreed to underwrite at 300, but it seemed to me it was a shame to miss this sale. Question: Do you think it was a bit unfair? a crisis situation. Despite this, Mr Macquire: Well, I was concerned, and I felt it was. I made reference to that at the Corporation meeting, and I did say, well, I have got no alternative now but to go and discuss it with the Minister, which I came back either that night or the next morning to arrange an interview with the Minister to discuss it with him. Question: So, you went to Canberra after that. varied, but what is clear is Mr Macquire: Yes, I did. Question: And you hoped to see the Minister. Mr Macquire: Yes. Question: Now, I believe that meeting took place quite late that night because you had to wait for Mr Sinclair to finish his duties in the Parliament. Do you think he was sympathetic towards your problem? I mean, there was a mountain of skim milk powder in Australia at that time, and this was a deal worth perhaps more than $sm, it was a way of at least starting to clear some of the backlog. Do you think he was sympathetic? Mr Macquire: I think he was concerned of the whole skim milk powder position of which I would imagine he would be aware about and I think he was concerned, but I had seen fit from my position in our company to go up and discuss it with him. Sure, I think he was concerned, as we all were. We would have liked to have seen the skim milk powder flowing out and being disposed of at sensible prices and I expressed to him my concern that it had been sliding continually down. The stock on hand in the EEC-government stocks, trader stocks-all pointed up to that the price would ultimately go down lower. Question: Yet the Corporation was able to make a deal, but your company wasn't. Mr Macquire: Yes, but when we look at this in its true perspective-the Corporation-I was part of that decision, inaudible don't forget. We made what we believe to be a price that was not under GATT but it only came under GATT by a commission to the trader who organised a sale at this end. Now, that is the difference, really. Simon Nasht: Before we lost the line, you will recall that the managing director of the Murray-GouIburn Co-operative, Mr Jack Macquire wasÂ· discussing the events of a meeting he had in Mr Sinclair's office in 1976. He was seeking approval at that meeting for a bid contract of skim milk powder which had been refused by the Australian Dairy Corporation despite the fact that the Dairy Corporation had approved its own contract for a sale of a similar amount of powder to Mexico. Question: You didn't think it was strange at all that the Minister should discuss a contract that was possibly in breach ofGA TT with the chairman of his corporation? Mr Macquire: No, I don't think so. Question: But you went there to try and get the contract pushed through, didn't you? Mr Macquire: I went there to take up our case. What the hell was going to happen to this damn powder. Here was a chance of selling-yeah, sure, I was aware that the 340 was under GATT, but I knew every other bugger, countries were doing the same thing and what the hell . . . Question: You thought it was sound business? Mr Macquire: I thought it was just common sense that we should otherwise we would be left on the damn, left behind by other countries doing these deals interest rate and 180 day interest rate at I per cent and some countries-they were doing it by putting it on palettes and shrink wrapping it and all those damn things which to me added up to what's cost, lands in the warehouse of a buyer overseas. And I felt that this was-the hell with convention. Those were desperate days. Question: Do you think Mr Sinclair understood your problems? Mr Macquire: [ think he understood my problems. He wouldn't have bothered I don't think to have rung the chairman if he wasn't sympathetic towards what I was saying, but-and I think that is why he went to the trouble to ring Webster-I can only summise that. Question: He did discuss . . . Mr Macquire: I wouldn't say the matter on my behalf, and a general discussion took place on powder and the likely possibility of sales of powder inaudible of Australia and what likely prices they could be sold at. Derivations were mentioned as a possible outlet for Japan, for school lunch programmes, stock feed possibilities in Japan were discussed, I think, with Webster and the Minister. And it sort of-the conversation finally sorted of drifted out. , said the phone down, he said, 'Look Jack, you heard what I said. You heard what Webster said. Nothing much' can do about it. You appreciate that for me to override the chairman of the corporation would be something-it would have to be very grave before one could do that sort of thing' audible , said well thanks for trying to do something, Mr Minister . . . Question: So, for then, the Minister left the matter, even though he understood that it was proposing a possible GA TT breach, but he left the matter there? Mr Macquire: He left the matter there and' say again the sale never went through.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: We will just have a look at what was said there. We already have the situation in which the Australian Dairy Corporation agreed to the sale of milk to Mexico and on the same day refused to allow a sale by Murray Goulburn to go ahead t6 Cuba. The PM interview on the meeting that Mr MCGuire had with the Minister for Communications reads: Question: Now, , believe that meeting took place quite late' that night because you had to wait for Mr Sinclair to finish his duties in the Parliament. Do you think he was sympathetic towards your problem? , mean, there was a mountain of skim milk powder in Australia at that time, and this was a deal worth perhaps more than $5m, it was a way of at least starting to clear some of the backlog. Do you think he was sympathetic? Mr Macquire: , think he was concerned of the whole skim milk powder position of which' would imagine he would be aware about and' think he was concerned, but' had seen fit from my position in our company to go up and discuss it with him. Sure,' think he was concerned, as we all were. We would have liked to have seen the skim milk powder Howing out and being disposed of at sensible prices and' expressed to him my concern that it had been sliding continually down. The stock on hand in the EEC-government stocks, trader stocks-all pointed up to that price would ultimately go down lower. Question: You didn't think it was strange at all that the Minister should discuss a contract that was possibly in breach of GA TT with the chairman of his corporation? and they were doing it by no Mr Macquire: No, , don't think so. Question: But you went there to try and get the contract pushed through, didn't you? Mr Macquire: , went there to take up our case. What the hell was going to happen to this damn powder. Here was a chance of selling-yeah, sure. , was aware that the 340 was under GATT, but' knew every other bugger, countries were doing the same thing and what the hell . . . So the interview goes on. The very drift of the matters that Mr MCGuire raised in that interview is quite clearly this: The Minister has always said any breach of GATT would be totally unacceptable. When he learnt of a breach of GATT he he overly pursued it. He raised took immediate actions to stop it. We have discussed many of these questions before. Now it is absolutely clear that the Minister who sits at the table knew of a potential breach of GATT as early as 1976. A man who said that it was totally unacceptbefore when the Minister closed able for any breach of the GATT arrangement to be contemplated was prepared to ring Mr Webster of the Australian Dairy Corporation late at night, urging a breaching of GATT. The Minister inmay be able to say that he did not know that the earlier sale had been negotiated that day by the Australian Dairy Corporation, but there is no way in which his previous statements to this Parliament that he knew nothing of the matter until 9 November 1976 can possibly be substantiated. Quite definitely, as people were talking to him about the fact that a sale of skim milk powder was not to go ahead because a breach of GATT would be incurred, there is no way in which this Minister can say that he had no knowledge of any of the problems involving GATT and skim milk powder until 9 November 1976. How can it be believed? How the heck can we believe the Minister when he now says that he knew nothing of the breach of GATT until 9 November 1976? Why did the Minister not tell the Senate Committee of this matter? Why did the Department of Primary Industry not tell the Minister of this matter? Of course, as is always a big problem with this Minister, files have gone missing. In previous debate the Minister for Communications has put the blame on Mr Webster of the Australian Dairy Corporation because all the files are missing. But why have they not been found? We will never find out the answer to that question, but copies of all those files went also to the Department of Primary Industry. Again, the files seem to have gone missing. Whenever it is essential to prove this Minister's innocence, files go missing. I think the Australian public is now asking: How many more times can this Minister be proved innocent? The last time the Opposition moved a censure motion in this House the Deputy Prime Minister said that his mate Ian, and not his Department, had been deceived by all those wicked people in the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries. The Deputy Prime Minister was very careful about that because if it had been the fault of the Department of Primary Industry it would clearly have been a question of lack of ministerial responsibility. There was no need for these wicked people not to advise the Minister of the situation because the Minister was told of it on 6 April 1976. He knew then of the skim milk powder situation. In terms of what Mr MCGuire said on PM, the fact that officers of the Australian Dairy Corporation went to Canberra to ask the Minister to allow a sale of skim milk powder in breach of GATT is clear and incontrovertible evidence that the Minister cannot say that he knew nothing of this matter until 9 November 1976. He cannot possibly say to this Parliament with any veracity that any breach of GA TT would be totally unacceptable. He cannot now say to this Parliament that the moment he knew of the breach of GATT he took immediate steps to rectify the situation. We concede that he did not stand over the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation and say that the sale must go through, because the sale did not go through; but it is quite clear that the Minister knew of this affair in April 1976. He has never told the Parliament that. All he has ever told the Parliament is that he did not know of the matter until 9 November 1976. In doing that he has Clearly breached his responsibility and he has misled this Parliament.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Is the motion seconded?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Blaxland) (4.19)-1 second the motion. We have before us a Government which has no honour. That is the principal objection of the Opposition. The present Prime Minister ( Mr Malcom Fraser), when he was Leader of the Opposition and in his election policy speeches in 1975 and 1977, talked about ministerial propriety and ministerial accountability. Perhaps one of the most salient statements is that of the Prime Minister which is recorded in Hansard of 29 October 1981. He said: It is certainly true that ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments . . . But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should take responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign. We have seen a lot of mistakes on the part of Ministers in the present coalition Government. We remember the days when the Minister for Communications ( Mr Sinclair), who is at the table, and the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Nixon), who is now lying back on the front bench, were like the Katzenjammer kids at Question Time, attacking and humiliating the Speaker of the day at every turn. They attacked and tried to discredit Labor Ministers, attacked their private lives and attacked their propriety. They sent Minister Connor, the former honourable member for Cunningham, to his death. By any standards, the measure of the decline in his health under the brutality of those attacks is clear. Mr Kerin-And his wife.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The hardship which they caused to his family is also clear. The same applies to the former honourable member for Lalor, Dr Cairns. There were attacks upon his private life. The reprehensible circumstances which brought on the 1975 election involved the resignation of Mr Connor on the basis that in some way he had deceived the Parliament by continuing to seek a loan after saying that he had ceased to do so beyond a certain date. That was his crime over which he had to resign. They were the reprehensible circumstances which brought about the defeat of the Labor Government and the whole constitutional crisis of 1975. But we on this side are beckoned not to dare to challenge the accountability of this Government's Ministers. A Senate committee-a committee of members of both sides of the Parliament-has called into question the motives of the present Minister for Communications when he was Minister for Primary Industry, yet we are supposed to remain silent. Is it not a terrible thing that Country Party Ministers are being attacked? What a shocking thing! The Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) talked at the National Country Party conference on the weekend about Australian Labor Party toads attacking National Country Party Ministers. In looking at this question of ministerial accountability we should look at the actions of the present Minister for Primary Industry. He nearly wrecked the major meat trade between Australia and the United States of America.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Order! The terms of the motion are directed against the Minister for Communications. I ask the honourable gentleman to remain relevant.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that it also concerns this question of accountability. I just make the simple point that there could be no greater blunder in terms of the administration of a department than that which nearly wrecked Australia's meat trade and which, of course, affected it adversely for some period. That Department was presided over by the honourable member for Gippsland, the present Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon. Again, shamefaced, the Minister sat it out on the front bench and refused to resign. He sits back smirking. This is an example of the gangsterism of the National Country Party. The attitude of its ter is to sit it out and not to be responsible. same applies to the Minister for Communications. He sat by while an international agreement, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, was being breached. Members of his department, the Department of Primary Industry, sat on the board of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and understood all the behaviour and commercial activities of that corporation. Despite the fact that he would have been told often about the matter, he also failed to resign. When he was called into question by a Senate committee we had the Government stonewalling and sitting out the situation. How can we have any respect for the Government? It has no integrity and no decency and it will not stand up to the standards of behaviour which it supposedly set for itself as a government in the Prime Minister's various utterances from 1975 onwards. Does it not seem to be a joke to honourable members on this side of the House that the Labor Government had Ministers resigning over such trivial matters when the present Government has the meat trade with the United States up for grabs, when the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is being ripped apart and, need we say, when we learn of the Minister for Communications latest forays? He is a sort of corporate Santa ClauÂ· of the Government, giving away things in the telecommunications area. Wherever we look we find that this Minister's statements do not stand up to scrutiny. We find that he said that he did not know of the GATT breach until September 1976. But Mr Webster, the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, told the Senate committee inquiry that he had told the Minister of the breach prior to September 1976. Now we find in the latest evidence being given by Mr MCGuire from the Murray Goulburn Co-op. Co. Ltd, that he had a discussion with the Minister in April 1976 about attempts by his co-operative to sell skim milk powder on the world market at prices below the GATT minimum. What do we find? The Minister was on the telephone that evening to Mr Webster, pulling him out of his bed in some hotel in Canberra to find out why the co-operative could not sell skim milk powder below the GATT minimum. Mr MCGuire says that the Minister stopped short of actually directing the Corporation to allow this contract to go ahead, but what is so clear and so painfully obvious to everybody is that the Minister understood quite clearlyÂ· that Australia was selling a product at a price below the GATT minimum. The dogs were barking at the time that sales were being made under the Minis- GATT minimum by Australia and many other The countries. That was the case. Despite that we had ministerial assurances that there was no selling under GATT where we now clearly understand there was. The statement by Mr MCGuire brings into sharp focus the fact that this matter was canvassed with the Minister in April 1976, months before the Minister told the House that this did not occur. We have here the same sort of problem that President Nixon of the United States got himself into with Watergate. If he had come clean right at the start and said that he was involved in the bugging of the Democratic .headquarters, maybe the nation would have forgiven him. This Minister could have said: 'Look, I was trying to move the skim milk powder surplus. I did what I could for Australia. I know we skirted around the thing in breach on occasions, but I did this and I did it in Australia's best interests.' At least then he would have been judged on the basis of his motivation by the Parliament. But that is not what he said. He said that he did not know. We know he did know. He did just what Richard Nixon did, he stuck it out for months, for years saying that he did not know and finally had to resign his presidency. The crime this Minister has committed is to have lied to all of us here, to have lied to the Parliament and to have misled the Parliament. His secondary crime is selling below the GATT minimum. From what MCGuire said we understand that every other country was at it. At least the Minister could have put up a reasonable defence of his motivation by saying that he was trying to move the massive store of skim milk powder out of Australia. Hundreds of dairy farmers' walked off their farms when the European Economic Community dropped the massive skim milk powder surpluses on the Western world. We know what that did to the manufactured milk industry of Australia. I think that honourable members on this side of the House would be prepared to listen to a Government Minister who said: 'I am trying to do the best for Australia. We are not going to openly, flagrantly breach GATT, but will do whatever we can to see that our surpluses are sold.' Instead of that the old National Country Party con men tried to stick it out, to brave it out by saying that they did not know when in fact they did. I do not think anyone who reasonably looks at the evidence or reads the transcript of the PM interview, or anything which Mr MCGuire has said could be left with any doubt about the fact that this Minister entertained breaches of GATT as early as April 1976. He thought it was important enough to ring Webster in his hotel late of an evening. Apart from falling short of directing the Australian Dairy Corporation to agree to the sale of this contract below the GATT minimum, he was certainly well informed and appraised of all the market circumstances which prevailed in the world at that time about the shifting of skim milk powder. I cannot see how the Minister can continue to deny the fact that he knew these things, that he has misled the Parliament and that he has lied to the Parliament. For that reason he should simply resign. That is what would happen in any other parliament in the Western world. That is what would happen in Great Britain or any other place where ministerial accountability occurs. Let us have a look at this Government. The Treasurer ( Mr Howard) two years ago had the Commonwealth Budget made public. The Commonwealth Budget was published in the newspapers a week before the Government delivered it. Yet he is allowed to stick it out. There is no accountability. Would you not think the Prime Minister would say: 'You are in charge of the' confidentiality of the Budget. I am not interested in how it is leaked, where it is leaked or what the circumstances of its leaking were. If it is leaked, you go. You are responsible'. The whole concept of ministerial accountability and. responsibility has just simply broken down. The Ministers now recognise that they have no responsibilities. Anything that happens can be sheeted home to some poor devil in a department, some Australian corporation or someone in commercial life. The Ministers take no responsibility whatsoever. We have seen the whole of the Australian meat trade come to a standstill, meat being stacked up in store rooms around the United States and trade stopped in Australia while the Minister sat it out and said that he did not know about all these things. Yet a Labor senator made a speech in the Senate about it 10 months earlier. If it surfaces in this Paliament there is no doubt that everybody knows about it in the trade. Everybody in the trade knew that was going on in the meat business. The Minister for Primary Industry says that he did not know and he sits it out instead of resigning. As he did not have the decency to resign, the Prime Minister should have made him resign. Of course, he is scared stiff of the National Country Party. In fact, he is a surrogate member of the Country Party himself as a sort of rich cocky grazier, and he will not bring them into line. The Minister for Communications, Jumping Jack Flash, just never will stand up to the accountability of the Parliament and insist upon the standards of behaviour which he himself insisted on from Labor Ministers some years ago. Here it is in these breaches. We have seen this over and over again. No doubt when he moves on from this portfolio to something else, as he wanders like a gypsy through the Cabinet, we will find a whole string of misdemeanours left behind him in the telecommunications area as we have found in others. It is a disgrace that hardly any members of the Government are here in the chamber and that the Prime Minister is not here to listen to a challenge against one of his senior Ministers. To think that this brazen corrupt group we call the Country Party in this Parliament sits here, brazens it out and brave-faces it out against all the standards of behaviour which have come to be recognised in parliaments under the Westminster tradition. The motion is a reasonable motion. It is a motion of censure against the Minister for Communications which should be carried by the House and should be carried by decent members of the Government who are concerned about the standard of behaviour within the coalition parties. We on this side of the House jeer at the members of the Government over their past behaviour in attacking the Labor Party. The present Prime Minister when in the Opposition insisted upon resignations when he thought that standards had been breached. Yet now his Ministers sit it out, trying to deny the undeniable. This Minister knew all about it months before and he is as culpable as Richard Nixon was in the United States in sitting it out and trying to deny to the public of that country, as this Minister is denying to the public of this country and to the Parliament, that he knew of things which he now says he did not do. The Government is a disgraceful Government. It is a corrupt Government. It is corrupt because it has no standards of integrity. To try to store some of the integrity, this Minister should accept the censure and get out, resign.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I apologise. I have misstated the electorate. Honourable members will cease interjecting. This is a motion of censure against the Minister. He is entitled to be heard in his defence in silence.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Without doubt the genesis of this motion is the level of morality pursued by members of the Labor Party themselves. The sorts of statements made and the distortions by a senator in the other place which were picked up and extended by journalists bear no relation to fact and are obviously what lie behind this charge. This afternoon I was interested to hear the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa ( Mr Kerin), who was followed by the honourable member for Blaxland ( Mr Keating). They gave us the reality of what this is all about. They are cerned that they were found out. We are going back to shades of that Iraqi breakfast and the Khemlani loans. I have no doubt that if we looked behind this charge we would find that it is only cause Labor supporters feel that they have to get their own back in some way. Let them look at the accuracy of the assertions made and see where it gets them. The honourable member for Werriwa tells us that there are three breaches. The whole substance of the claim is that because I had a discussion in April 1976 I therefore knew of facts rethat subsequently became revealed in late August or September 1976. Even blind Freddie, to use a phrase that has been used in this place before, would realise that there is a difference between those separate periods-one transaction in April and another transaction in August-September. They were different transactions. Certainly they related to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The GATT minimum prices for skim milk powder were set down from time to time. It is true that on 5 April 1976 the export price was reduced to a GATT minimum of $US350 free on board. It continued at that rate to the end of the year. In fact, it was 24 December 1976 when the GATT minimum rose to $US400 f.o.b. The fact that knowledge of one contract was held and that there were discussions about whether a sale would be a breach of GATT obviously does not mean that there was knowledge of another sale or a situation in another market that might also have taken place in breach of GATT. All the circumstances and the evidence that has been produced to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-I will try to expose in a moment the evidence presented on the PM program-does not prove that there was any knowledge by me of any sales in breach of GATT. Let me say again in this place that the Government did not then, nor does it now, condone sales :n breach of an international arrangement entered into in accordance with GATT. Nor does it condone any operations within any statutory corporation that needs to be investigated. It was for that reason that I instigated the inquiry by the Auditor-General which, progressively, has led to the revelations that were the subject of a report to this House by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Nixon) only a few weeks ago. Certainly the three charges and areas that have been identified by the honourable member for Werriwa need to be distinguished as to the allegations he made. He has tried in some way to draw a connection between a knowledge related con- to a $5.25m sale of skim milk powder to Mexico by the Australian Dairy Corporation, which demonstrably the records show had been so doctored that nobody knew it was in breach of be- GATT, and another sale to the Philippines in respect of Holland Milk Products Inc., HOMPI, when a $25 a tonne rebate was given. As soon as there was evidence of that having been in breach of GATT there was advice, first of all by telex from Mr Wallace of the Department of Primary Industry and then through a discussion by myself with Mr Webster, to terminate the arrangement. From those two sales there is some connection with another offer made to the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Ltd to sell skim milk powder to Cuba. The fact that I had a discussion with the person responsible for those sales is somehow supposed to link together the fact that each one of them was to my knowledge a breach of GATT. That sequence of events just does not follow. I want to go through them because I think it is very important that we do so. I also think it is very important that we realise that the genesis o-much of these lies in inquiries between the Chairman of the Senate Committee, the Rae Committee, and the Australian Dairy Corporation. A letter was written on 9 April 1981 by Mr B. A. Norwood, General Manager of the Australian Dairy Corporation. I understand that it has been tabled in another place and I will not read it all today. It relates to some of the GATT skim milk powder minimum pricing arrangements, in particular, the one related to the HOMPI sale. On page 2 of the letter Mr Norwood concludes: There is no record of these sales having been reported to either the Corporation Board or to any Federal Government Department. When we are looking at these facts we need to know that, according to the inquiries made by the Dairy Corporation, there was no evidence of any of these matters that I am supposed to have been aware of having been reported to the Federal Government or to me personally. We are now looking at the degree to which there was evidence of things being reported. Another letter - rom Mr Brian Norwood dated 5 October 1981 gIVes considerable details with respect to the sale to Mexico. If we look through the record we will find something about the doctoring of the inform-tion. The Mexico sale to which the letter refers involved a number of documents relating to the exporting of the product. The letter states: However documentation available shows that a deliberate effort was - ade to prepare documents containing incorrect facts. There was no knowledge that the Mexico sale was in fact in breach of GATT. Without going into the full evidence-there is no time available for me to do so-it is quite demonstrable that the Federal Government and I certainly had no knowledge that the sale was in breach of GATT. It is interesting to look at one phrase in that letter. It states: On establishing this information, the Corporation Management have examine- availa-le Corporation documentation in order to determine the circumstances of these sales. Unfortunately, at the time involved, on a directive. - f the then Corporation Chairman, Mr Webster, no Ce-t-al FIlmgsystem was maintained and thus the Central FIlIng records are reasonably scanty for the period in question. There is no doubt as to who directed that there would be no central filing system. There is no doubt who ensured that there would be no records. Because allegations have been made in the other place and here that in some way I aassociated with this matter let me repeat that thiS letter is the result of inquiries within the Australian Dairy Corporation regarding what happened to these missing records. I repeat that the letter states: Unfortunately, at the time involved, on a directive o- - he then Corporation Chairman, Mr Webster, no Central FIlIng system was maintained . . . If we look at the PM transcript-it is from this transcript that much of this allegation appears-we find that Simo- Nasht has seen - t to extend, again beyond any evidence that was .glven to him, the circumstances of the whole affair. He has come to conclusions about the price that are not backed up by evidence given by Mr MCGuire. He has made assertions about the quantity that are not backed up by Mr MCGuire. He has made comments about the degree to which the central filing records were in some way apparently laid aside, according to him, largely as a result of r,ny instigation. In other words, in t-e PM transcn-t which has fortunately been Incorporated III Hansard by the honourable member for Werriwa, we see that the whole of the substance of this allegation has been developed and extended by inferences not based on fact but on presumptions that Simo- Nasht seems to have developed for himself. What concerns me is that they were then further distorted on 12 November in the Senate by Senator Walsh who sought again to try to extend the long bow. The whole of the substance of each one of these allegations is not backed up by the evidence given. There are two things I should say about Mr MCGuire's evidence. First, I think it is quite apparent that any telephone conversation held so long ago would hardly be in the accurate memory of anyone who had other than a complete record of that transaction. If we look at Mr MCGuire's evidence, however, we will see that the allegations made by the Opposition do not follow specificall.y from that particular evidence. Indeed, the genesIs of the interview with Mr MCGuire is itself rather interesting. It seems that it was an inquiry that began from Mr Mackey, t-e sec!etary of the R.ae Committee. At the meetmg With Mr MCGuue there were a number of circumstances that I think of themselves need to be seriously considered. Apparently, Mr Ken Baxter, who is now a full time employee of Philip Morris Ltd, happened also to be in attendance on that occasion at 2.30 p.m., Thursday 5 November. We find that prior to answering questions on that occasion Mr MCGuire asked whether any evidence had been EmptyHere sociate of the Australian Labor Party in government and who is now a lobbyist in town. Mr Cullen was said at that meeting to have reported to the Committee. Yet subsequent evidence from Senator Peter Rae and from others on the ComEmptyHere evidence. We are relying entirely on Mr MCGuire's report of the affair. Because we are relying on his report of the affair, I will refer to a telex which Mr MCGuire sent to the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to me yesterday. It stated: I refer to the recent reports on the ABC programmes AM and PM involving my discussions in 1976 with the then Minister for Primary Industry Mr Ian Sinclair on the matter of export permits for the sale of skim milk powder. The ABC reports were based on selective extracts from a taped interview with Mr Simon Nasht which was made on the II th November at his request. I was concerned to find that the ABC reports were presented in a form which casts doubts on the previous assertions made by Mr Sinclair that breaches of the skim milk powder international agreement, under the GATT would have been totally unacceptable to the Government. The allegations being made on the basis of the ABC reports are not in accord with my understanding of what transpired at the discussions with Mr Sinclair in 1976. I interpose to say that they are not in accord with my recollection either. Certainly at no stage did I suggest to Mr Webster or to Mr MCGuire that, if the sale were in breach of GATT, it should have gone ahead. In fact it was because we did not know that the ADC sale was in breach of GATT that it had been accepted as being valid. The facts being presented to me by Mr MCGuire with respect to the Cuba sale had to be investigated to determine whether they were in breach of GATT and the sale did not go ahead because, of course, they would have been in breach of GATT. So much for the allegations by the Opposition! The telex continues: During our discussions which ranged over a number of dairy industry matters r expressed strong concern to the Minister on the inability of Murray Goulburn to secure an export perrnit for milk powder at a price comparable to that being obtained under a joint contract by Australia and New Zealand for the sale of skim milk powder to Mexico after allowance was made for agency commission. My representations place strong emphasis on the depressed state of the world market . . . The Minister then offered to phone the Chairman of the ADC Mr A. A. Webster to ascertain the reason behind the Corporation's refusal to grant export permits to Murray Goulburn to allow the proposed sale to proceed. The Minister was inFormed by Mr Webster that the ADC could not accede to Murray Goulburn's request For an export permit at the price in the case of the proposed contract could constitute a breach of the skim milk powder pricing arrangements under the GATT. On the receipt of this advice Mr Sinclair then indicated to me that there was nothing further he could do. This was the end of the matter so far as Mr Sinclair was concerned. My company subsequently accepted the Corporation's decision and the proposed sale of skim milk powder did not eventuate. I seek leave to have that telex incorporated in full in Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as followsThe Right Honourable J. J. Fraser, C.H. Prime Minister Parliament House Canberra My Dear Prime Minister, I refer to the recent reports on the ABC programmes AM and PM involving my discussions in 1976 with the then Minister for Primary Industry Mr Ian Sinclair on the matter of export permits for the sale of skim milk powder. The ABC reports were based on selective extracts from a taped interview with Mr Simon Nasht which was made on the II th November at his request. r was concerned to find that the ABC reports were presented in a form which casts doubts on the previous assertions made by Mr Sinclair that breaches of the skim milk powder international agreement, under the GATT would have been totally unacceptable to the Government. The allegations being made on the basis of the ABC reports are not in accord with my understanding of what transpired at the discussions with Mr Sinclair in 1976. During our discussions which ranged over a number of dairy industry matters I expressed strong concern to the Minister on the inability of Murray Goulburn to secure an export permit for milk powder at a price comparable to that being obtained under a joint contract by Australia and New Zealand for the sale of skim milk powder to Mexico after allowance was made for agency commission. My representations place strong emphasis on the depressed state of the world market For skim milk powder and my company's concern at the ADC's apparent differential treatment in the issue of export permits. The Minister then offered to phone the Chairman of the ADC Mr A. A. Webster to ascertain the reason behind the Corporation's refusal to grant export permits to Murray Goulburn to allow the proposed sale to proceed. The Minister was informed by Mr Webster that the ADC could not accede to Murray Goulburn's request for an export permit at the price in the case of the proposed contract could constitute a breach of the skim milk powder pricing arrangements under the GATT. On the receipt of this advice Mr Sinclair then indicated to me that there was nothing Further he could do. This was the end of the matter so far as Mr Sinclair was concerned. My company subsequently accepted the Corporation's decision and the proposed sale of skim milk powder did not eventuate. On the 6th November 1981 I was questioned on the above events by two staff members of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I made it clear to the two officers that no pressure had been applied by Mr Sinclair to the Chairman of the ADC in relation to the proposed sale of skim milk powder either from the GATT aspect or from any other aspect. I am sending a copy of this telex to the Deputy Prime Minister- Mr J. D. Anthony, Minister for Communications- Mr I. S. Sinclair, Minister for Primary Industry- Mr P. J. Nixon for their info.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Oxley-Leader of the Opposition) (5.11)-The Opposition disagrees with the motion that these matters of Government Business be withdrawn from the Notice Paper. It is a matter of great concern to the Opposition that the Government is determined to close down the proceedings of this Parliament early and in circumstances which make it abundantly clear that the Government is concerned about dissidents in its own ranks. It is fearful of confrontation by the Senate and it is prepared to scuttle out from its responsibilities to the Australian community. Four years ago, a long-standing member of the Government resigned from this Parliament and from the Liberal Party of Australia in total disillusionment with the party he had served in this House for 28 years and with a Prime Minister with whom he refused to serve at all. That was the then honourable member for Mackellar, Mr Wentworth. A few months later, after the elections of that year, Mr Wentworth was asked why he thought the Government had been returned to office. The Government had won, he said, by dodging the real issues. He added: The Government's strategy in covering up was brilliant. The House will recall that Mr Wentworth was not the only Liberal Party back bencher who could not stomach any longer the arrogant style of leadership of the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser). The former honourable member for Tangney, Dr Richardson, also resigned from this place and from the Liberal Party at the same time. Dr Richardson said: We have come closer in this country to a presidential style of Government than ever before in our history. He should have added that it was a style lacking personal grace and without intellectual elegance. Four years later nothing has changed. It is business as usual and most of it is funny business. The Government is still dodging the real issues and it is still covering up, though not so efficiently. It cannot cover up the Prime Minister's growing list of broken promises. It cannot cover up the record interest rates, the higher unemployment, the increasing inflation, the falling living standards, the growing poverty or the highest taxes in this country's history. It cannot cover up the expensive debacle it has created in health insurance, the scandal it has made of education funding, the continuing sell-out of our industry and minerals to foreign interests or the cutbacks in spending on public programs and community projects. It cannot cover up the resignation of the former Minister for Industrial Relations or the wheeling and dealing that is going on in the Liberal Party to replace the Prime Minister before the next elections. Certainly it cannot cover up the rancid smell that surrounds the activities of certain Ministers of this Government. That is why the Parliament is being terminated so abruptly and closed down for the year. That is why we oppose the discharge of these business items. It is happening because none of these issues so damaging to the Government are able to be covered up. Nothing exemplifies this shonky Government more than the spineless manner in which it has decided to shut down the Parliament and run. The Prime Minister's overriding concern now is personal survival. His leadership is under threat and his Government has become accident prone. Ever since the last elections he has stumbled from one crisis to another. It has been a remarkable year made more remarkable by the way in which the Government is now scuttling into the recess after a disastrous 12 months. It started with a public brawl between the Prime Minister and one of his senior Ministers and it is ending on the same note. A year ago the then Minister for Finance, the late Eric Robinson, discovered just how ruthless the Prime Minister can be to a colleague when it suits his political interests, just as Prime Minister Gorton learned 10 years ago to his cost and as you, Mr Speaker, well know from your brief experience as party leader in trusting the Prime Minister. Mr Speaker, as you found out, a public pledge of loyalty by the right honourable member for Wan non ( Mr Malcom Fraser) has about as much value as one of his promises at election time.

text: Mr Speaker, on the contrary it does. We have the Schools Commission report for the triennium 1982-84. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: An example is the Community Youth Support Scheme. We have the disastrous behaviour of the Government associated with the gross self-indulgence of the Prime Minister, on the one hand prepared to spend more than $20m on the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-which lasted eight days at a cost of $2.5m a day-to aggrandise himself and, on the other hand, to scrub one of the few, genuine commitments of the Government towards relieving the strain of unemployment in the community, the Community Youth Support Scheme, at a cost of only a miserable $9m over 12 months. The argument is that these items are being discharged to clear the Notice Paper and are part of the process of closing down the Parliament early. The purpose of that is to get members of the Government away to the four corners of this vast continent as quickly as possible. The reason is that the Prime Minister works on the simple principle that survival depends on dispersion. The more quickly and the more widely he disperse his friends to prevent their talking to one another, mostly about him, the more secure he will feel. In those circumstances, I believe that is the record the Prime Minister in all of these matters and many others which I have raised. Mr Speaker, it was injudicious of me to draw your name into it, or I probably would have gone much further before you drew my attention to the procedures before the House. These are the reasons why the Prime Minister wants to shut down the Parliament. Mr Speaker, you know as well as I do that the Prime Minister has a long hit list when it comes to his own colleagues. He is now worried about a single person hit list. His name is on that list. A lot of honourable members who sit behind him in this House would wish to carry out the contract against him. The guerrilla warfare has been continuing ever since the last election. Mr Speaker, you know as well as I do that it reached a peak two months ago after the new Minister for Industrial Relations-the ever-accommodating honourable member for Stirling ( Mr Viner)tried a crude hatchet job on his predecessor in Parliament. Unfortunately for the Prime Minister he sent out a fumbling boy on a man's errand and the Minister botched it. We are all well versed in the performance of the Minister for Industrial Relations in this Parliament, sliding across the front bench like a slicked-down eel with one hand in his pocket and a lie on his lips to answer the latest question at Question Time. Now we will wait to see whether he gets reshuffled.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I accept your direction, Mr Speaker. The problem with this country is that the government of its affairs is in the hands of a of small clique of subsidy-grabbing farmers; a wealthy pastoralist from the western districts of Victoria-the Prime Minister-in all of his feudal splendour, administering the affairs of the country in association with a hard-boiled, or is it a halfbaked, dairy farmer from the Gippsland area; a pig farmer from the Northern Rivers district of New South Wales; and the resident handwriting specialist of the Government, the Minister for Communications ( Mr Sinclair). But not one of them understands business and all of them are pretending to be the representatives of business in this Parliament. That is why the country is in such a disastrous condition. The honourable member EmptyHere ager in the Senate, another bitter ex-Fraser loyalist with a sore score to settle, are biding their time to settle the scores aga.inst the Prime Minister and his acolytes. Those are the reasons why these matters are being discharged from the Notice Paper of the House. The Government is in a panic and the Prime Minister is in a frenzy. He wants to close down this place as quickly as he can. The further removed his 'friends' can be from him the more secure he feels. Twelve months ago at an election few people thought that the Australian Labor Party could win. They now recognise that not only was it close last time but also it will be a certainty at the next election. I wish to quote some of the experiences we have had during the course of this Parliament. The celebrated razor gang exercise early in the year by the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch) has been exposed as a public relations fraud. It was a gimmick to give the illusion of an activist government. It proved nothing except that the Minister should stick to his real estate deals and his Gold Coast investments. Ever since the report of the Lynch committee was announced six months ago the Government has been back-tracking on one decision after another, some for good reason, but most out of sheer funk after heavy pressure from vested interest groups. Its only substantial decisions so far carried through are patently against the public interest. It gave big business a free hand on price increases by abolishing the Prices Justification Tribunal and imposed absurd new staff ceilings on the Commonwealth Public Service without any real rationalisation of departmental functions. The incompetence behind the staff ceilings decision is manifest. In the area of social security, where there are now far too few hands to service the public adequately, staff union bans are increasing the log jam and the general sense of chaos. In the Taxation Office, the new staff ceilings mean a cutback of 179 departmental officers. That has saved $1. Sm in salaries but it lost the Government an estimated $46.Sm in annual revenue through reduced enforcement procedures. That is the sort of economic wizardry that has got Australia where it is after six years of Fraser Government. Repeated election pledges of tax reform have been the hoax of the year. In February, the coalition Government publicly fought over the economic nonsense of a flat rate tax system. Then the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) went through the gymnastics of floating his proposal of anew, broadly-based retail tax, later promising not to introduce it without offsetting cuts in income tax. That promise was exploded in the Budget in August which cut no taxes at all, forecast a massive 23 per cent increase in income tax revenue and introduced a new range of sales taxes which, when enforced, will add between $4 and $S a week to the household bills of the average family. The Parliament will rise for the year with the Treasurer as stubborn as ever that the outstanding tax increases in indirect taxes will be enforced in the new year. The tax confusion is indicative of the general mess the Government finds itself in with its erratic and contradictory management of the economy. Let us look at the record of this Government. We have been promised a consumer-led recovery, a resources-led recovery, an export-led recovery and an investment-led recovery. We have even had to put up with the burden of a slogan-led recovery-about the only one that persists. With every change recovery has receded. Now, when the Government is packing off Parliament for the year the major indicators of manufacturing output, building approvals, inflation and employment suggest that recovery is as far away as ever. Employment growth is only half what it was a year ago. Interest rates on bank home loans have increased a full two percentage points since the last election, or an extra $46 a month on the average $30,000 home mortgage. The average family tax burden has gone up another $3.S0 to $6.S0 a week. Health insurance charges have jumped dramatically under the Government's fifth health policy in six years. And I repeat: This is just the last 12 months in a mockery of the Government's solemn election promises in October last year. The Government is utterly contemptuous of the Parliament. For two years the Prime Minister has been promising a full debate on the Bowen report on pecuniary interests, an issue of real significance in the current climate of the Parliament's debased authority and the Government's refusal to establish a public register of all members' personal financial standing. Like all the Government's promises, it has not been honoured. The same can be said about the need for debate on the triennial report on education of the Schools Commission and the Government's pathetic apology for freedom of iriformation. The most crucial industrial relations issue in the country is wage fixation; yet we have nothing firm in relation to a proposition from the Government in respect of this. Mr Speaker, at every turn, wherever there is the slightest hint of political self interest involved, the Government thumbs its nose at its national responsibilities. That is why it is contemptuous of this Parliament. That is why we cannot ever get a straight answer from a Minister-any Minister-at Question Time. That is why the Prime Minister runs away from constitutional reform of the Senate just as fast as he runs away from public accountability and public scrutiny. That is why he thinks he can sweep any embarrassment under the carpet, just as he swept the murder of Australian Broadcasting Corporation journalist, Tony Joyce-MONICA

Title: ZZZZZ
text: Corio) (5.35)-1 want to make only a few remarks about the matter under consideration by the House. The situation relating to general living standards and the maintenance of accommodation at Defence Force bases throughout Australia is of growing concern to a large number of Service personnel. It is one of the areas about which the greatest number of complaints come from Service personnel, especially the families of Service personnel. For several years now the maintenance and the provision of what are basically decent standards of living for persons who are required to move regularly because of their defence commitments and to live in government provided accommodation have caused concern. This motion is welcome in that it seeks to improve one of those areas. I draw the attention of the Minister for Housing and Construction ( Mr MCVeigh) and the House to the fact that an enormous backlog of unmet and substandard accommodation is being utilised on a regular basis by members of the defence forces and their families. Much of this accommodation is obsolete in modern accommodation terms. A good deal of it would be deemed to be below standard by State housing authorities if, in fact, they had the option of condemning government dwellings. I point out also that there are serious problems in a number of areas with the locations of Defence Force housing accommodation which is quite unsuitable and unrelated to the persons who are expeCted to live in it. There is, as I mentioned before, a serious tardiness in this area. In Darwin, for instance, which is not directly related to this motion, there are still houses which have not been adequately repaired as a result of the damage which was caused during Cyclone Tracy. I think it is unfortunate that this sort of situation continues. It is causing problems with maintaining the skills and the levels of trained manpower that are necessary in the defence forces. Once a family becomes dissatisfied and if the accommodation that is provided is below the standard which that family is entitled to expect, problems will occur. I raise this matter briefly today because there are very few opportunities to debate this type of matter in the House. I draw to the Minister's attention the very bad state of a great deal of government accommodation in the defence area.
