Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Bonython) (9.6)-Three weeks ago this House passed the Social Services Amendment Bill (No.1). The Social Services Amendment Bill (No.2), the first of the two Bills we are dealing with tonight, clears up one of the problems with the Bill that we passed. The Social Services Amendment Bill (No.2) deals with the problem of the proper definition of refugee child. It is perhaps a comment on the somewhat bumbling nature of the way in which this Government handles its legislation that tonight we are amending a Bill we passed three weeks ago. I alluded to this particular problem of the definition of the refugee child at that time in my speech at the second reading stage. I want to make it quite clear that the Australian Labor Party supports this aill which, in fact, amends the refugee child definition which in the original Bill of three weeks ago was far too narrow. Many children are admitted to Australia as refugees but do not get refugee status. The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that all children who come into Australia in the general sense as refugees will be covered for the double orphans' pensions provisions. We therefore support the Social Services Amendment Bill (No.2). I briefly make that criticism on the way in which the legislation was handled. However, I must say at the outset that the Labor Party will oppose the Social Services Amendment Bill (No.3) and will continue to oppose it in all the fora that are open to the party. The objectives of this second Bill are to deny the single rate of unemployment benefit, first of all, to Third Reading the spouses of trade unionists involved in industrial action, secondly, to the spouses of unemployed persons denied benefits under the work test, and thirdly, to the spouses of those who are classified as voluntarily unemployed or dismissed (No.2) 1981 for alleged misconduct. One would not gather, in Second Reading fact, from the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport ( Mr Hunt) very much about the second and third of those categories; that is, the spouses of the unemployed denied benefits under the work test and the spouses of those who are classified as voluntarily unemployed or dismissed for misconduct. Those people are scarcely mentioned in the second reading speech of the Minister. In fact, despite his protests his speech is almost entirely a thinly veiled diatribe against the legitimate right to strike. This is a point to which I will return. One thing that can be said about this Bill is that the contemptible nature of its substance is almost equalled by the contemptible nature of its history. Let me just go over that. First of all, these provisions were originally included in that large omnibus Bill I have already referred to this evening; that is, the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 1) which included all the social service legislation flowing from the Budget. The somewhat cavalier attitude of the Government to that legislation was seen when it was presented to this House on Tuesday and was required for debate the next day-on Wednesday. It was extremely difficult for the Parliament to give it a proper and a considered response. It was quite clear from the amendment that we have already had to move to that Billthe first of the Bills we are debating tonight that even the Government found it a bit difficult to cope with the problem given the speed with which the Bill was dealt. These clauses were originally included in that omnibus Bill. When the Government encountered trouble with these clauses in the other place it first tried blackmail. It said that unless the Bill were passed into to certain payment provisions for the unemployed without dependants would be delayed. However, the Senate called the Government's bluff on this point and the Government then proffered a humanitarian explanation for its surrender. The Minister ( Mr Hunt) said: The Government has no intention of allowing vulnerable sections of the Australian community to suffer because of the failure of the Senate to accept one aspect of the Government's proposals. I think the best comment on the sincerity of that profession of concern is "illustrated by the fact that on Tuesday the Government introduced a Bill which provided for payments to be made from the following Sunday. It suggests an enormous amount of concern, or perhaps a very low view of the Parliament, that it could introduce a Bill on a Tuesday authorising payments from the following Sunday. I think that sort of attitude suggests the depth of this Government's concern for the vulnerable. Now the Government has introduced the rejected clauses as Social Services Amendment Bill (No.3) 1981. I simply repeat what I said in the House on 28 October. The Opposition will oppose these proposals as they are totally abhorrent and totally inappropriate to our social security system. The Australian Labor Party will oppose the Bill in this House and in the other place. We are confident that the Government does not possess the authority in this Parliament to use the social security provisions to impose destitution on families in pursuit of industrial discipline. If the Government seeks to .use this measure as the trigger for a double dissolution, so be it. The Labor Party and, I am confident, the Australian people would welcome the earliest opportunity to render judgment on this Government. Let me discuss the issues raised by the Bill and utterly ignored by the Minister in his attack on the right to strike. First of all, this Bill punishes the spouses and families of those who fail the work test and who are allegedly voluntarily unemployed or who have been dismissed from their employment. First of all, let me repeat again that an enormous hammer is being brought to bear but it is a miniscule problem in statistical and financial terms, although, of course, for the few families involved it is a massive problem. At the moment, according to the latest statistics available, there are something like 1,000 postponements a month of unemployment benefit payments. Some 70 per cent of these postponements concern people without dependants. Therefore, about 300 families a month are the object of the savage clauses in this part of the Bill. These 300 families a month have to be punished for some failure on the part of the breadwinner. He or she may be dismissed for misconduct, which is always a debatable notion; he or she may be allegedly voluntarily unemployed, which is again a very debatable notion; or the spouse of the person being attacked by this Bill may fail the work test. In many cases the failure will not even have been the breadwinner's fault but the fault of the social security system. Last year, according to the latest statistics available, which are for 1980-81, approximately 50 per cent of all appeals with reference to unemployment benefit payments were upheld; that is, something like 50 per cent of the decisions in unemployment benefit cases were in some sense made in error. But such people will be punished for their error first of all by simply having their unemployment benefit withheld from them until this error is discovered. If this Bill is passed-I hope that it will not be-not only the individual concerned will be punished but also the spouse of that individual will not be able to collect unemployment benefit even if she or he is entitled to it. Some weeks later it will be discovered that an error has been made in at least 50 per cent of the cases. As I have said, the notion of voluntary unemployment is an extremely difficult notion to prove. As we all know, or should know, people in the work place may be harassed in many conceivable ways into resignation. Probably all of us know of incidents in which authority in the work place has been used to harass people who have been forced into resignation. Again, I say that it is a difficult and frequently unfair assessment of these individuals which will lead to the punishment outlined already in the social security legislation and to be increased under this Bill. Indeed, already the penalties for being volunin tarily unemployed, failing the work test or being dismissed are peculiarly harsh. At the moment suspension period of a mandatory six weeks is imposed on these people in relation to the receipt of unemployment benefit and, at the authorities' discretion, the period can be extended to 12 weeks. A full period of suspension means a fine something like $600 for a single unemployed perdustries, son and something like $1,000 for a married unsame employed person. As one of my colleagues, cision Senator Grimes, pointed out in another place, such fines already are greater than those imposed often and frequently on drunken and dangerous drivers. These penalties for these work place fringements in the form of denial of benefits for up to 12 weeks represent financial penalties in many cases are more severe than the penalties the courts impose on drunken and dangerous drivers. It seems to be totally absurd to penalise more harshly than drunken drivers people who legedly leave a job of their own free will or who are fired for alleged misconduct. Seeking to ish the wives and families of the individual conaverage cerned seems simply to compound this absurdity. Indeed, it seems to me that the Government simply piling one absurdity on to another with measure. The other objective of the Bill-indeed the only one on which the Minister wished to speak at any length:-is to use the social security system as weapon to impose industrial discipline. The clauses in that part of the Bill embody what called earlier the latest Liberal Party principlebenefits family destitution as a system of industrial disciprovision pline. Once upon a time even Liberal members actions. who are sitting in this House today displayed certain conscience about these issued and, as this kind of tactic was developed year by year by the Government, objected to it. I refer to, amongst others, one of the honourable members present in the House at the moment-the honourable claims. member for Casey ( Mr Fa1coner)-who, to give him credit, when the initial steps were taken four years ago, protested about this way of using the social security system. I hope that he will take opportunity tonight to protest at the breaches that have occurred. The honourable member for Boothby ( Mr Steele Hall), in his more independent days when he used to express vigorous and distinct opinions on the Liberal side, equally condemned this type of development. But perhaps, living with the collection that surrounds those honourable members every day, their consciences have become stunted. We have to see this problem in perspective. Only about 60,000 workers annually are involved disputes extending over seven days. That is an average pattern. I talk of disputes extending over a seven days because the people involved in those disputes are the people who will be effected by these amendments. Of course, the amendments will not apply simply to the people who are directly on strike but also to the members of unions of stood down, often in other States or in other insimply because they are members of the union and have suffered the impact of a deelsewhere. The amendments will not affect just those who actually make a decision to strike; it will affect all members of the same union who are affected by the action, whether they are in the insame State or another State, and whether they are in the same industry or another industry. We have that 60,000 of these people. However, roughly one-third of this number would not be affected because they are single and this Bill deals with spouses. Of the remaining 40,000 a significant proalportion already have a working spouse, so they would not be entitled to unemployment benefit in punthose circumstances. We are probably down to an of 500 to 600 families a week. We have all this double dissolution strutting, all this performisance, over 500 or 600 families a week in this this category and perhaps 300 or 400 families a week in the other category. This is the great measure which is to be the basis of this Government's double dissolution activity. a Yet this Government, year by year, has expended enormous legislative resources on this small I group. First of all it denied unemployment to actual strikers, then it broadened the to include those involved in industrial Last year it reduced the benefit to spouses a of these people from the married rate down to the single rate. That was another form of punishment. This year it goes the full way,by the usual dripping process that this Government uses with the public, drip by drip, and erodes their rights and So this year we finish up with denying even the single rate to spouses. The spouses who are otherwise eligible for benefit are to be denied even the single rate; not the married rate, because an that was denied to them in the past. It is now not even greater to be even the single rate. The Minister constantly argues that the social security system largely insulates-I use his words-trade unionists involved in industrial disputes from the financial effects of their actions. That is simply untrue. I ask honourable members to examine the single rate as it stands now for unemployment benefit, even allowing provision for children, and to compare it with minimum wages and see the minimal insulation provided. There is no entitlement to that benefit in the first week of an industrial action and payment is not usually made until three weeks after the industrial action has begun. It is a pretty ineffective insulating device, particularly for a family which has had regular wages coming in. Again I think it is important to get rid of the myth that somehow a decision on industrial action is usually carelessly or thoughtlessly arrived at, which is clearly the suggestion in the Minister's second reading speech. Very few trade unionists lightheartedly enter into industrial action, particularly action likely to be prolonged. That is the sort of action we are discussing in relation to this measure. The reason for careful consideration is that industrial action is costly and unemployment benefit for the spouse at the single rate does very little to reduce the costs. It may stave off family destitution. I accept that. But it will do little to relieve the family of' the host of difficulties that follow a dramatic fall in weekly income. I simply ask honourable members on the Government side of the House to use some imagination about the effect on families whose income suddenly falls from average or slightly below average per week down to the single rate of unemployment benefit, which is a severe enough fall and causing enough family problems, and then to contemplate a situation where even that benefit will disappear because under this Bill there will not be even that minimum level of benefit. For a government which is concerned with the family, thi- is a direct incentive to get unhitched because one of the ways round this problem would, in fact, be separation in these kinds of situations. For a spouse attached to a husband who is involved in industrial action, this is the penalty. That brings me to a basic and fundamental objection in principle to this measure. The whole of the Australian social security system is based on the principle of individual entitlement qualified by spouse income. We have a basic system which entitles every individual to the social security benefits for which he or she has a claim, qualified only by the extent of spouse income. Yet this change sweeps that basic notion away because it says in particular cases that this individual entitlement will not be there. So it seems to me that we have really a fundamental attack on the basic notion of our social security system which is that individuals are entitled to benefits. It is true that that is qualified by spouse income considerations but in this case where the spouse, for whatever reason, has no income the wife-or in a few cases it may be the husband-will not be entitled to any benefit. So we have changed this fundamental principle on which our social security system has been based. In this way we are punishing the innocent, the families, the wives of men involved in industrial action or people who have got into strife with the work test or were dismissed from their work allegedly for misconduct or who allegedly voluntarily left their work. They are already penalised but under this BiII their wives and their families are to be punished for those faults. Again, this is a deliberate contradiction to the way the whole of the social security system has been organised. Again I refer to Liberals in the days when they showed some real consideration and understanding of these problems. I refer to the honourable member for Boothby ( Mr Steele Hall) who, when he was a senator, said: The Government was making the innocent do its dirty work for it. More than ever that is being done now.

text: I invite the honburable member for Higgins to stand up and express his views. This supposedly important measure has not attracted, as far as I know, a single Liberal to speak on it. It shows the concern they have for the sort of issues raised. Finally, let me make the point which I made some time ago that we are dealing with a relatively small group of families. The estimate-this is probably a fairly generous one-on average would involve one thousand families a week and, taking a generous consideration of what they would be paid, about $5m a year. What we are involved in with this legislation is something like $5m a year. I ask honourable members to contrast that $5m which is being saved by the Government with the kinds of benefits, the kinds of underwriting, the kinds of concessions, the kinds of subsidies given out by this Government to its friends. Indeed honourable members would probably be able to identify some particular friends of this Government who get an amount equal to all that is being saved by these measures. When we get through the Government's anti-strike rhetoric and see what the Bill actually does to individual Australian families, we are confident that we can win that battle.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Grayndler) (9.28)-1I have much pleasure in joining in this debate tonight to expose the utter hypocrisy of this Government in bringing in this iniquitous legislation. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), has said that the Opposition will oppose this Bill with all its might. I hope that this Bill will be defeated once again in another place. The Government's view, as expressed in the second reading speech by the Minister for Transport ( Mr Hunt), is something over which any political party in Australia would be willing to go into a double dissolution and defeat the Government. The Minister showed in that speech when he introduced this Bill that he is indeed a very heartless man representing a very heartless government. Who else but this present Government would be so obsessed with strikes and strikers that it would attempt to penalise the families of people who are indulging in legitimate industrial action? It is iniquitous to use the social security provisions to try to curb strikes and to try to force people to take a point of view that they would not like to take. We have to look at who suffers in these proposals. The Government in a dishonest and disgraceful manner has, in both the second reading speech and in the explanatory .notes, referred to the application of this renewed Bill to only the spouses of volved in industrial action. There is no indication from the Government that it includes in the Bill as strikers people wh" may have been opposed to the dispute that is being caused, as were the Geelong Ford workers who voted against joining the Broadmeadows Ford workers on strike, but were stood down just the same. Likewise, it includes as strikers people in a union whose counterpart branch in another State has closed the works, a decision that those people had absolutely nothing to do with. But they and their families will be penalised for it. These close-downs have resulted in their being stood down due to a shortage of essential parts. I feel that some unionists do not even know why they are being penalised when they are stood down through actions such as this. But the Government will use the social security legislation against those people. The Government has perverted the definition of the word 'striker'. In this legislation, and particularly in the Minister's speech, it has tried to whip up an emotional climate of hostility to the trade union movement. While we look at the Government's rather wild claims about strikes in this country I think it is important that we should look at some of the statistics that relate to strikes. If honourable members and the Minister look at the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey released last August which relates to 1980 they will find that in that year 65 per cent of all industrial disputes lasted two days or less. They involved 79 per cent of all workers in industrial disputes. Only 21 per cent of workers were involved in disputes lasting longer than two days. Honourable members will be aware that the provisions of this legislation occur only if people are on strike for more than seven days. Only 8.9 per cent of all strikers were involved in disputes that lasted 10 days or longer. Sixty-one per cent of strikes were settled without negotiation. The major cause of many disputes was directly attributable to management. In 39.7 per cent of the disputes managerial policy was given as a prime cause and 19.6 per cent occurred because of physical working conditions. Only 21.5 per cent of the disputes in Australia in 1980 occurred because of wage negotiations. What provisions will the Minister invoke to ensure that employers have safe working conditions for their employees? What provisions will he invoke to prevent employers from indulging in action which could cause stand downs? None, of course, because the Government cannot see past the end of its nose. It is interested only in penalising women and children. I would have thought that even this Government would not have sunk to that level of absurdity. Let us return to the Minister's second reading speech and see what he says he is trying to do. He strikers or of persons in- said: The Government has decided, however, that if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in the case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, his or her spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children. One might say that maybe the man really does have a heart after all and that the Government is trying to make some provision. But one has to look at what the Government means by extreme hardship. I put it to the Parliament this evening that there is no departmental definition of extreme hardship although I imagine in some cases it relates to the provisions for immediate hardship which are roughly defined in the Department of Social Security's manual of instructions on unemployment, sickness and special benefits. It will be up to some delegate of the Department to make a decision on what extreme hardship will mean. That will cause delays in the payment of benefit and will probably ensure that in most instances people do not get their benefit at all. We must look at the people who will be involved. I think the last example we had in this country of a major or a very important strike was the Victorian power dispute in October 1977. The Minister in his speech, and other spokesmen for the Gov;rnment have said that this legislation is to have an effect on strikers and that they must pay the penalty for the results of their actions. One must consider the horrendous penalty that many people will be paying. I would like to incorporate in Hansard-I have sought the Minister's concurrence on this-some extracts from a document compiled by the Victorian Council of Social Service entitled 'Too Little, too Late' which is a review of the effects of that strike and of the Government's refusing to allow unemployment benefit for the spouses of strikers during the dispute. Some of the examples in that report indicate that the people in very dire circumstances were those who, in the past, had not needed to seek any assistance from the Government. Because they were placed in a circumstance in which they would not usually be placed and because they had very little cash, they found themselves in dire economic circumstances. Some were confronted with eviction, some with virtual starvation of their families and some were confronted with family breakdowns arising out of that dispute and the Government's continual decision not to allow the payment of unemployment benefit to the spouses of those strikers. With the permission of the Minister I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard examples to show the effect of the dispute on a wide range of families in Victoria in 1977. Leave granted. The document read asfollowsFamily A Eight children, eldest II years 20.10.77 Last worked 27.9.77 Registered for Unemployment Benefit 4.10.77 - not through yet $20 in bank-have used balance Own home, no great debts Sick child needing doctor Down to last food. Action Food grant to value of $50 FamilyB Four children, eldest 15 years 12.10.77 Last worked 28.9.77 Registered for Unemployment Benefit 10.10.77 Has been out of work for several weeks and had just been re-employed for a month when stood down No money in bank but owe nothing Children at hungry stage Action Food grant to value of $20 (subsequently a further grant to value of $30) FamilyC Two children, eldest 6 years 18.10.77 Last worked 29.9.77 Registered for Unemployment Benefit 5.10.77 Rentdue No money-spent savings when husband ill recently Action Food grant to value of$30 FamilyD Two children, eldest 12 years 20.10.77 Last worked 27.9.77 Did know to register for Unemployment Benefit Rent up to date but no more money left in bank FamilyE Three children, eldest 10 years Last worked 30.9.77 Registered for Unemployment Benefit-5.10.77 Owe one weeks rent Used Child Endowment (i.e. Family Assistance) to meet payment on car Due to finance companies-$I 02 per month Action Food grant to value of $40 Mr LEO MCLEA YI thank the House. Another group that will be severely restricted by this legislation will be migrants. My electorate of Grayndler encompasses the largest number of migrants of any electorate in Australia. I am very well aware of the precarious financial circumstances of many new arrivals to this country. If they are prevented by this Government because of actions that they had nothing to do with from obtaining unemployment benefit for their families while they are partaking in indu-trial action they will be in horrendous circumstances. Many of them do not own their own homes, many of them have large families and many of them will face utter ruin and a great fear for their families if the Government implements this legislation. The migrant community in Australia is probably the lowest paid group in the economy. Migrants are in the most fragile economic circumstances. They will find that they are in an extremely unfortunate circumstance if this legislation is enacted. Many of the migrants in my electorate work in manufacturing industries that are dependent upon receiving supplies from interstate. Many of them are stood down in industrial disputes of which they have no understanding and in which in New South Wales they have no involvement and no vote in what can occur. As I pointed out earlier, the automotive industry is particularly affected by these types of shortages. The people involved have nothing to do with what has occurred. The Minister also talks about trade unions in the impersonal sense in his second reading speech. I ask the Minister and the Government: What about the trade unionists themselves? Why do we not look at the responsible attitude that most unionists and trade union officials have taken in Australia in their attempts to achieve justice for their employees? No one takes lightly the decision to strike. No one wants to ensure that he causes his members great harm and disservice. As I pointed out earlier, the statistics point to the fact that many strikes are caused by - mployer actions about which the Government will do nothing. Mr MCVeigh-What about Norm Gallagher and his seaside house?

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I will finish by stating, as the honourable member for Bonython, who spoke previously, did, that all the Government can do here tonight is to make some rather frivolous interjections, as the Minister for Housing and Construction and long speeches has done this evening, and run across the chamber putting rather pointless little notes on people's tables. What is the Government doing for the people who are forced into dire economic circumstances because of the absolute obsession with strikes of some of the cretins in the National Country Party? They are absolutely terrified of the rights of Australians and trade unionists to exercise their democratic rights. We are supposed not to worry when they decide they will jack up the price of commodities or livestock by withholding them from the market.That is legitimate business! But if an employee withholds the only thing he has for sale, his labour, this Government says: 'We will get square with you. We will penalise your wife and your children. If you want to go on strike your children and your wife can starve'. I do not see how anyone with a conscience could have the gall to propose such legislation in this Parliament. I join with the previous speaker in saying that I am pleased that this legislation will receive the discussion that it deserves in another place and will be defeated. If the Government wants to call a double dissolution on this sort of legislation, Opposition is quite happy to oblige it. It is rather interesting to see that the Government cannot put up one speaker in support of this iniquitous legislation. All the men of principle have fled the chamber tonight. The people who four years ago said that they had a number of things to say and who were going to stand up to the Government are not here to stand up to the Government tonight because they have been quickl- pulled into line. I complete my remarks by saymg that the Government will see this legislation fail. The Australian people will applaud its failing.

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Casey)- Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Mr Jarman)Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Yes, I do.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The honourable member may proceed.

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Earlier this evening, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) referred to me and to some attitudes which I allegedly took four years ago on a matter, he said, that was related to the matter now before this House. He said, I think, that I had a flexible conscience, or words to that effect, on this. I take the opportunity to point out to the House that the matter which I was concerned about four years ago and which received some coverage in the Pressalthough I am not sure that it involved very much in the way of statements from me in the House, if indeed it involved any statements in the Housewas a different matter. It was a matter which involved suggestions that unemployment benefits be withheld from those who were stood down as a result of union action and who were not involved at the work site where the union action took place. In other words, it involved strike action which then resulted in other workers at other sites being stood down and those who had been stood down as a result of that union action being denied unemployment benefits. I opposed that at the time because it meant that people who did not have some direct control or influence over the union action concerned would be penalised. The measure before us tonight is a different matter.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Fadden) (9.44)-The two previous speakers have attempted to portray a scenario of people innocently placed and far away from the scene being the ones who would be affected by this legislation. Not once did they mention the people who may have taken a deliberate vote to go out on strike. the The legislation is such that, if somebody is placed in a loss or difficult situation, a discretion still lies with the Department of Social Security to grant a benefit. Mr Leo MCLeay-Only in extreme cases.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Yes, in extreme cases. I read in a newspaper that the honourable member is in some danger in his electorate. As somebody who has survived in my own party, I give the honourable member this bit of friendly advice: If he stopped, listened and learnt, he might not be in so much trouble with his own party. My background is this: Prior to becoming a member of parliament I was an industrial officer on the Brisbane waterfront. The unions with which I dealt ranged from the Federated Clerks Union to the Waterside Workers Federation. In the mid-1960s, there was no more militant group in this country than the waterside workers. I think my friend the right honourable member for Lowe ( Sir William MCMahon) might have been the Minister responsible for industrial relations at about that time and it was he who appointed Mr Justice Woodward to inquireSir William MCMahon-I was Minister for nine years.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: For nine years. The right honourable member knows what I am talking about. This was a time when the wharfies would stop work at the drop of a hat. In those days I had a quiet admiration for the fact that when the wharfies went out on strike-I am not canvassing the wisdom or otherwise of their reasons for going out-what they were saying was: 'You can whack your job. I believe so strongly in this, whether or not I am misguided, that I am prepared to lose income to establish a point of principle'. That is what they were saying. Indirectly they were also saying: 'I am also making this decision on behalf of my family'. With great respect to the honourable member for Bonython and the honourable member for Grayndler ( Mr Leo MCLeay), who preceded me in this debate, they have painted a portrait which suggests that, when people go out on strike and things get a little tough, they have an automatic right to say to the Department of Social Security: 'Okay, I have forgone my income in this area but I want my spouse to help support me and thus allow me to continue this industrial action'. I know that, in this place, a lot is spoken about politics and that there is a lot of appealing to electorate councils at a time of dire need and a lot of appealing to the electorate from the Senate. But I wonder what this country is coming to when members of the Opposition espouse that it is a God given right for any man who is part of an industrial action and who meets with difficult times to have an automatic entry into the taxpayers' pocket. That is taking their example to the other end of the line. They have chosen to speak about one feature, the emotional side of this question, with which I have some sympathy. But they have gone to the other extreme and portrayed that God given right to which I have just referred. So often the taxpayer who is supplying the money is the person who has been tormented and who is suffering most of all. The honourable member referred to electricity stoppages. What about the women who are totally reliant on electricity at night and who have small children for whom they have to heat up milk when, suddenly, bang go the lights for two hours or even for 24 hours? There are two sides to the coin. When members opposite portray the Government as harsh and without feeling, I would like to believe that their intelligence level is such that at least they recognise that there is another side but that, because they are who they are and because of whom they represent in politics, they are in the position of having to belt the Government with a big fat stick. If the burgeoning social security bill of this country is to be contained, I ask members on both sides of this House to adopt a more responsible attitude to what is right and what is wrong. The social security bill is now $11 billion out of a total Budget of $40 billion. Ten years ago, it represented but 17 per cent of the national Budget; today it represents 28 per cent. To hold expenditure even at that level requires a mammoth effort by government MONICA

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: ZZZZZ
text: You must be getting old.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The honourable member for Kalgoorlie is going to get old too, and if he stays here much longer he will be a lot older than he is today. My great concern is that we are eroding and dissipating our nation's ability to take care of tomorrow's aged and tomorrow's disabled and to take care of those people who are really in need of looking after. In the field of education for the generation of tomorrow, our ability to give a proper education is being eroded. Anyone can stand up in this Parliament and say that money should be spent here and spent there. It is the most popular speech that one can make because there are always some people outside the Parliament who will clap and say: 'Hear, hear! I agree'. A member will build up support in that way. But if members of the Labor Party aspire to be in government, if they aspire to be statesmanlike or even responsible, it is time they abandoned the practice of jumping up and beating the drum every time they think they can pick up a few votes by stretching the rubber band and giving examples of people who are only part of the picture. Honourable members opposite completely disregard those who are part of that deliberate decision to go out on strike. As I said in the earlier part of this contribution, I admire the wharfie who packed his bag and walked off the job saying: 'I will suffer for my principles'. I just wonder how bad things have become when members of the Opposition espouse as a Godgiven right that one should qualify for a government benefit when one walks off the job.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Burke) (9.54)-We have just heard a harangue from the honourable member for Fadden ( Mr Donald Cameron). All I can say is that if this is the best the Government can do on a Bill which it has brought before the Parliament as a ploy for double dissolution, it shows the sense of responsibility which this Government has in relation to the way in which the national Parliament is operating. It has been remarked that not much interest has been taken by the Liberal and National Country parties in relation to this Bill. The reason for that is that this Bill is indefensible. It is indefensible that the Government has no arguments for its position except a simple ideological dogmatism and it is this which has serious implications for democracy itself in relation to the way in which the Liberal Party has been moving in recent times. We in the Labor Party say that our opposition to lnis Bill is based on fundamental principles. We are ready to stand by those principles and to fight hard for them. We will not be intimidated by the Government's threat to force an election in relation to this or any other matter. We are ready to face an election at any time the Government is ready to call it because we are confident that this Government has totally lost the confidence of the people. What are the fundamental principles that we believe are at stake here? There are two. The first is the democratic right to the provision of social security benefits for people who are not working and who rely on the welfare state for their survival. Let me remind honourable members opposite about the history of the development of the welfare state. The! - have been many struggles for the development of democratic rights. One of the fundamental democratic rights is that we in Western societies, in democratic societies, do not let people starve. The implication of this kind of action by the Government is that it sets in train the beginning of a philosophical development which, if carried further, would lead us back to the bad old days when workers could not find jobs and their families were forced into a situation where they had to beg in the streets. The very development of the democratic welfare state is being eroded by this Government's actions. It is consistent with the pernicious new philosophy which has penetrated what was once a great party, the Liberal Party, but which has now become nothing more than a neo-conservative extremist organisation. The Friedman philosophy has penetrated the Liberal Party. This very measure could have been taken from the writings of Professor Friedman himself. Professor Friedman argues that we must dismantle the welfare state, that workers have gained too many benefits and that what we ought to be doing is making it more difficult for them to be able to demand their rights in the work place and to demand better wages and conditions and, by that method, force a reduction in the standards of living. That Friedman philosophy is being adopted progressively by this Liberal Party and its National Country Party allies. It is the thin edge of the wedge in that it involves attacks on workers and their families, on people who, in a democratic society have come to rely on the welfare state. If this were an isolated action we might have forgiven it, but the fact is that this Government has shown a tendency to try to take away rights from disadvantaged groups of this kind. In this year alone we saw a situation in which there was a massive attempt to get rid of the Community Youth Support Scheme which assists unemployed youth. It was only after a massive outcry not only from the Labor Party but also almost overwhelmingly from the media, the church and welfare organisations and other bodies that are concerned with the welfare of this nation that CYSS was maintained. This other. measure is being introduced along the same philosophical lines. Let us suppose that the Government gets away with it. It has been mentioned by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) that it is not only the families of those on strike who will suffer but also the families of those who will be laid off in other places. This situation will mean effectively that we will have a substantial beginning of the dismantling of the rights of people in relation to the welfare system. It is an attack on the principles of the welfare system and it should be rejected utterly. The second set of principles that is involved concerns the undermining of the right of workers to seek increases in their standards of living by withdrawing their labour. We know that members of the Liberal and National Country parties are paranoid about workers' rights to strike. Some members of those parties have even openly said in this House that they want to get rid of the right to strike itself. This is a disgraceful statement in any democratic society.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It would be a good thing in Tasmania, I can tell you.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: We will hold the honourable member for Franklin to that statement in Tasmania; he need not worry about that. I will publicise that statement in Tasmania myself. Let me continue my remarks. In other words, those members are not liberals in any sense whatsoever. In fact, their philosophy is indistinguishable from the kind of fascist philosophy that existed in the 1930s when the right to strike was taken away from people. Workers do suffer during strikes. They lose their pay. It was mentioned by the honourable member for Fadden that the families of striking workers receive a small unemployment benefit. This is supposed to mean that they will be compensated for the loss of their full pay during the period when the breadwinner is on strike. The honourable member for Fadden does not even have basic logic behind his position. Recently in my electorate we had a six-week strike, the Ford Motor Co. strike, in which many people suffered. Many people lostMr Ian Robinson-Why did they not go back to work?

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: They did go back to work. They were making a very moderate demand which was not met by the company. They had every right to make that demand. We know what honourable members opposite want to do. They want to increase the power of multinational corporations to attack Australian workers so that they do not have the basic right to strike or even the basic right to survive during that strike. The Government is attempting to frustrate the very process involved inMONICA

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: ZZZZZ
text: People are starving in Tasmania because of strikes.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ZZZZZ
text: When honourable members opposite have finished making remarks about the various strikes which they have been opposed to I will continue. They have never been in favour of a single strike. If there had been no strikes in this country workers would be starving under this Government and its friends. Let that be perfectly clear. When have honourable members opposite supported wage increases or supported uions making moderate demands against corporations? They have never done so. We know who fills the coffers of the Liberal Party. Let me go back to the principle involved in this legislation. It is fundamental. It is simply that these people and their families need to survive during these difficult situations. Very often workers are placed in a strike position because they have no alternative. From listening to honourable members opposite one would think that the strike is the first weapon that is resorted to by unions. Anyone who knows industrial relations knows that many union leaders-not all, admittedly-are very reluctant to use the strike weapon unless its use is absolutely necessary and they have exhausted all the processes for getting a fair deal for their members. We have in this country at the present time a situation in which, through Government pressure, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has dropped the wage indexation system. By dropping the wage indexation system, every group of workers now has to make demands of its employers and in many cases where the employers believe that that group of workers has a weak union or is not a very powerful group, the employers simply refuse to give even a moderate increase to improve the standard of living. We have not heard anything from honourable members opposite about the employers who refuse to give even part indexation in relation to wages but who simply say that they will give no increase whatsoever in the present climate because the union concerned is not a strong union. What are workers supposed to do in those circumstances? Are they supposed to cop the situation or are they supposed to exercise their democratic right to withdraw their labour? They are supposed to do the latter. Under those circumstances, they are fully entitled in a democratic society to the same rights as everybody else, which includes unemployment benefit for their wives so that they will have something with which to feed and clothe their children.

Speaker: Mr SCOTT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Hindmarsh) (10.5)-First of all, I disagree with my colleague the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) when he said in the latter part of his speech that Liberal Party and National Country Party members have never been in favour of strikes. In fact, they have been in favour of strikes. They are very much in favour of the current strikes in Poland. They are a very convenient argument for them. I ask them to digest that. Returning to the issue, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) has laid bare what the Government is currently about. The number of families affected by this social services legislation would be in the vicinity of 300 or less and they would be involved either because of the spouse's failure to qualify for the work test or because of the spouse's involvement in disputes. I will not run away from the issues of disputes, strikes, scabs or industrial relations. They are all part of the real world outside this House and outside Canberra where people have to work for a living. We did hear something from a Liberal Party member who claimed to be an industrial officer previously. No doubt in that time he learned the realities of life. I was for 12 years Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. I know what disputes are about. I will not run away from this issue. Let us try to educate the six Government member!> who are here tonight. Very few of them are prepared to get up and defend the position. The types of dispute that occur in Australia are different from those that occur in the Americas, the United Kingdom and Europe. I will quote the Government's own source-the Australian Bureau of Statistics-in referring to a report of 4 September of this year under the heading 'Unions not main culprits in disputes'. It states: Unions are not the main culprits walk-outs. About half the industrial of this year were precipitated by management, according to the Bureau of Statistics. And its figures for the previous three years showed management policies had been responsible for between 36 per cent and 40 per cent of the country's industrial problems. I invite honourable members to check those statistics. They are from the Government's own sources. The kinds of disputes, examples of which have been laid before this House, were exemplified by the honourable member for Corio ( Mr Scholes) in his speech. Because of previous legislation which can only properly be described as union-bashing legislation, additional provisions and penalties have been imposed on unions so that they must have secret ballots to take strike action or to go into dispute with their employers. He laid bare an example of a number of unionists who took part in a secret ballot imd who voted not to go on strike but to return to work. Because of the majority decision, they were put in the position of going on strike. This Government would seek then to punish the families-the children and spouses-of those people who, in fact, voted not to go into dispute. I want to reiterate the point made earlier that in a dispute situation the first penalty is placed on the workers. How many honourable members here have got the guts to say that next week they will go into a dispute situation, that they will not work and will not receive any pay? Are they prepared to lose about $1,000? That is the kind of thing in relative terms that workers decide when they put up their hands or put their marks on a ballot paper to go into dispute. The decision is not taken lightly. Union officials do not make those decisions. The rank and file, the members of those unions, make those decisions. Honourable members opposite should not come in here with that crap unless they understand what industrial relations are all about. When they do know what industrial relation are all about, I will be prepared to debate the subject with them. Let us look at the types of dispute that we have in Australia. Because of the unique situation with the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, with its many faults, the disputes in Australia are noted for being shorter than those in Europe and in the Americas. But what kind of disputes do we have? I just want to reiterate briefly the type of dispute that it was said was holding the vehicle industry to ransom at that time. This is the kind of thing that happens. I will be generous and say that perhaps honourable members opposite do not understand these things. I will try to explain them to honourfor provoking strikes and able members. This was a situation involving a company that had the monopoly for manufacturdisputes in the first three months ing shock absorbers for cars. Ten of the workersall of them shop stewards-were in a dispute situation. A decision was taken that they would not work any more overtime. The company selected these 10 workers and sacked them. This was proved in court. The eviden<:e is there and I would be more than happy to bring it before the House to prove the point that I am making. Because those 10 workers were sacked the rest of the work force went into a strike situation. But their demand was not that the 10 workers be re-instated. Their demand was that the company agree to go before the courts and have the case tested there. For 14 days over 300 workers were in a strike situation demanding the right to go to a court to have their case tested. That is the kind of situation that is occurring continually outside in the real world .. Honourable members opposite do not want to know about it. I suggest that some honourable members know what is going on but, because of the position that their party takes, they have to toe the line and obey the Whips and their Caucus. If we have a situation where the right to strike is taken away-as it can be through this type of legislation-then workers become nothing more than slaves. Australia has a tremendous history of members of the working class establishing the standards of living that we all enjoy and everyone of them got it through struggle. This Government and previous governments of its ilk have continued to heap penalties on the workers. It is a well known fact that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is the most horrendous legislation in the statute books directed against workers. Now the Government seeks to impose penalties on the families of those workers. If it is doing it for the sake of a double dissolution I say: 'Good on you. We will have you on any time you like.' The Government might try to make a smoke screen out of this issue which involves perhaps 300 families in a month, and several million dollars. But we will be taking it to the people on other issues too. If the Government wants a fight on interest rates, sales tax legislation, unemployment, health, pensions, education and the destruction of the manufacturing industry, we will have the Government on tomorrow.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Kalgoorlie) (10.13)Tonight I want to address a few remarks mainly to the contribution made by the honourable member for Fadden ( Mr Donald Cameron). The honourable member said that he was an industrial officer. I am sure that this would have made him aware of some of the problems that confront industry. It would have made him aware also that strikes are not generated by one side. Indeed, I remind honourable members opposite of the words of Roderick Carnegie who said: 'In any protracted strike situation I look to, and blame, management'. This is one of the realities which is brought about because workers' demands are usually fairly simple and fairly just. The honourable member made this rather emotive statement about people who are on strike: 'Why should the taxpayer support the wives of people who are on strike'? Of course, this overlooks the fact that workers are also taxpayers. Many of them pay a substantial amount of the tax in this country. Anyone on pay-as-you-earn tax does not have the ability to avoid tax in the way in which a lot of other people do-people who largely would be supporters of the Government parties. However this is a valid point. There is a very substantial and rising cost in social security. It no wonder, when we see the performance of the Government in the area of unemployment that it has added substantially to the social security cost. One way in which the social security cost can be reduced is to get the economy working again and to provide more jobs. We have been through all th- various economies. We have had the miningled economy and the investment-led economy. I expect that in the new year we will be getting into the new leader-led economy. Maybe this one will be better than the last. It certainly would need to be. This business of costs shows a certain naivety on the part of the honourable member for Fadden. Obviously someone will have to pay. In the long term, one of the ways in which we could handle this high cost of social security would be to increase productivity. It would be naive in the extreme-I am sure that the honourable member for Fadden would agree with me-to believe that we could increase productivity without the support of the union movement. It cannot and will not be done. But the union movement has shown itself very eager in many areas to increase productivity. With goodwill on both sides I am sure that much can be achieved. Let us get back to this emotive issue of the person who is on strike and where somebody has to pay. The truth of the matter is that if no funds are made available to the family of the person on strike that family still has to live. Inevitably, what happens, is that it makes calls on charities and on community welfare resources of the States. Once again we see this Government transferring a national responsibility to somebody else-the States or to charities. It is a very simple observation that somebody always pays. I do not think there is any escaping that. I have been confronted a lot with this situation because I have an area in my electorate which is very prone to industrial trouble. This has been brought about in large measure by unrealistic expectations generated by companies that were all too keen to give out concessions when they wanted productivity but then they try to draw them back when things get tough. I am sure that the honourable member for Fadden would know that in reality in the field of industrial relations, it is very hard to take back what has been given. In the industrial field it is unrealistic to expect that there could be Indian giving without causing industrial turmoil. I would like the honourable member for Fadden to reflect on that simple point. If a family is without resources it has to live. It cannot go into limbo or into deep freeze. Somebody has to pick up the bill for those people. I have been often involved in getting community is welfare payments for these sorts of people in my electorate. In many cases the cost to society is farÂ· higher than the very meagre amount of unemployment benefit. If any honourable members think that living on unemployment benefit is a laugh or a good time. I suggest that they try it themselves, particularly in areas where the cost of living often is substantially higher than the cost of living that is enjoyed by the great mass of people. In conclusion I point out-I was going to make this more of a point of order but I think I can include it jn my speech-that during the speech made by the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) the honourable member for Franklin ( Mr Good luck) muttered, that in fact the honourable member for Burke was a communist. Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Title: ZZZZZ
text: MCMillan) (10.20)-1 will take just a little time to participate in this bate. I believe the area that I represent, which takes in the Latrobe Valley, possibly is the area which was first tested by the type of legislation that this Government brought into attack trade unionists and the recipients of unemployment benefits. It was back in October 1979 that the Government first had the audacity to bring in legislation providing that if a unionist was involved in a dispute, no matter where in Australia, and was out of work because of it he was ineligible for unemployment benefits even if he was not directly a party to the dispute. But what we have, of course, in the Social Services Amendment Bill (No.2) is an extension of that provision. If anybody wants to know just what the effects of this type of legislation are, I remind the House, as I did on another occasion, of just what happened in that dispute in the Latrobe Valley. It will happen again; there is not much doubt about it. Nine men, concrete hatchers, were stood down at 1.30 one afternoon, and at 5.30, because of a conspiracy between the State Electricity Commission of Victoria and the major contractors employed on that large project in Victoria, the Loy Yang site, 600 further employees were stood down. We saw that incident develop into a standoff for some seven months. Possibly the greatest obstacle to resolving that dispute turned out to be this Government's legislation. The legislation denied to those unionists the, right to unemployment benefits. Innocent parties-men who had been sacked; men who were unable to get another job-were denied work and were denied unemployment benefits. Families were coming into the trade union offices to collect food vouchers. I never thought I would ever see it. I read about it and I heard about it occurring in the depression days but I witnessed it only 12 months ago because of the Government's legislation. Families were absolutely destitute and were dependent on handouts. After seven months, the situation gets to be rather serious. This legislation now proposes to deny the few bob that were available to some of those people in that dispute. This legislation will bring about starvation. Of course, members of the Government are saying that someone has to do something about the strikes. This legislation certainly will not solve the strike situation. Bad industrial relations cannot be solved by this type of legislation, and there will be a cost to be borne. I would imagine that the Victorian Government is shuddering at present as this legislation goes through this House. Anyone who knows what happened in the Loy Yang dispute will know that it finished up costing the Vicdetorian Government millions of dollars to get the program back on course again. There was no way in which ordinary people were prepared to come back and work on that job because of the imposition caused by the legislation passed in this House. The men, in their rightful position, said: 'We no longer want to work on that job'. A lot of them went to other parts of the State or interstate and found employment. The Victorian Government found that, because of that legislation, it could not even get the program going again. That will happen again, except this time the Government is asking for more trouble. I cannot understand the logic of the Government's action and why the Government is not prepared to learn from that one lesson. If it thinks there is any political mileage in the legislation, let me say that if there was one factor that brought the total community together in that part of the world it was the action of this Government when those people were clearly put in that position. It drew together the shopkeepers. The honourable member for Franklin ( Mr Good luck) talks about small business in Tasmania. He should come to the Latrobe Valley and talk to small business people about what this type of legislation did to innocent people during that dispute. These people will very quickly tell him what they think of this type of Government legislation. This is a straight out attempt to try to starve unionists back to work. Innocent people, people who have no rights whatever and with no responsibility for disputes will be penalised because the Government wants to get at an odd one who perhaps may be on strike. Nothing in this legislation will penalise an employer who causes a problem-nothing whatsoever. It is simply a one-sided attack for political purposes. I can guarantee that there is no way in the world that I will be frightened to go to an election on this issue. Truckies in the Latrobe Valley got together and formed the largest convoy ever seen. Independent truck owners, not working men, ganged together and took the longest run of trucks-the highway was blocked with trucks-down to the Victorian Government to plead with it. When they got into the Premier's office-I was with them-the Premier said: 'The greatest obstacle we have are those idiots in Canberra'. The Government has extended those provisions today. Honourable members should not think for one minute that there is any political mileage in the legislation for them because there is none. I can guarantee that. I am prepared to fight an election at any time in the Latrobe Valley area on this very issue. Honourable members should chuck out this legislation and the 1979 legislation and get back to some decent legislation that will create proper industrial relations and stop this type of draconian measure that penalises ordinary Australians by trying to starve ordinary workers back to work when there is no possible hope of doing it. It is a disgrace that it could be happening in 1981. If it happens in 1982 that we get a chance to take this issue to the polls, we will win on it every time. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr MACPHEE
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Balac1ava-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)-by leave-I am pleased to be able to inform the House of a decision taken by the Government to establish a new program for the entry of members of minority groups fleeing substantial discrimination or avoiding significant violation of human rights in their homelands. This program has been developed within the broad philosophy of the Government's refugee policy. It will enable Australia to provide a humanitarian response, outside formal refugee programs, in instances of substantial discrimination or human rights violations against oppressed minorities anywhere in the world by governments irrespective of their political persuasion. The program was foreshadowed by the Government at the time of the last election. Oppressive regimes and governments whose policies have little regard for basic human rights inevitably cause an outflow across national borders of members of minority groups at risk. We are becoming increasingly aware of the plight of such people, whose numbers are increasing also. Often, these displaced persons are unable to satisfy the internationally accepted criteria defining refugees. Yet, their relatives or compatriots in Australia, recognising the plight of these people, have asked the Government to provide some means of assistance. The Special Humanitarian Program will focus on the individual members of oppressed minorities. Those accepted will generally be able to demonstrate a personal claim on Australia by virtue of having close relatives settled here, close former ties with us or, for a small number, a strong and well established community here which is well organised and able and willing to provide all necessary settlement support. Those eligible for consideration under the Special Humanitarian Program will generally be living in temporary asylum outside their own countries, be unable to return there for fear of substantial discrimination and have no comparable claim to another country's settlement resources. In considering who should be eligible for the SHP, the views of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees will be taken into account. Needless to say our heads of missions in the countries concerned also will play an important part in the acceptance of persons under the program. Many such people have formerly been debarred from admission to Australia as they are unable to meet either normal migrant selection criteria or the eligibility requireoppressed ments of existing refugee programs. Whilst our refugee programs and other resettlement commitments must act as something of a brake on our ability to respond to the needs of displaced oppressed minorities we will be able to provide, through the sympathetic consideration that the SHP will permit, places for people formerly unable to come here. The Governmeat would naturally expect that those entering under the SHP would contribute to the development of a socially cohesive, multicultural Australia. As the program is addressed to quasi-refugees with close relatives or ties in Australia, it will not represent a significant burden to the taxpayer. Sponsors of the successful applicants will undertake to provide all necessary settlement support. Applicants will need also to satisfy normal character and security requirements and medical standards consistent with humanitarian considerations and any legislative requirements. Officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will shortly be receiving instructions on the procedures to be followed. Nominations from Australian citizens and other permanent residents anxious to sponsor close relatives under the SHP should be lodged at a regional office of my Department. Community agencies wishing to sponsor unrelated members of the group could also lodge nominations at a regional office. Eligible nominations will be referred to the appropriate overseas post so that the nominee can be interviewed and assessed. Individual applicants claiming close non-family ties with Australia can, of course, lodge their applications at an overseas post. I should foreshadow that inevitably applicants will outnumber many times the places available under the program. I would counsel against undue expectations being raised by potential sponsors. Officers of the Department can, however, be relied upon to ensure that priority is given to those in greatest need of compassionate entry subject, naturally, to the extent of their claims on Australia. I commend the program to the House.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Port Adelaide)-by leave-The Opposition welcomes the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Macphee). I do not think it is necessary for me to say that the statement lacks much of the detail that we would like to be given by the Minister at this stage. He has assured me that a further ex'planation of the operation of this scheme will be given in the next few weeks. We have believed for some time that it is necessary to give some elasticity to our refugee program in relation to minorities. Questions have been raised by me and by my colleagues in relation to certain oppressed minorities who were not proscribed as refugees by the United Nations but who nonetheless have been putting up with circumstances similar to those of people in other parts of the world who have been designated as refugees. It is a very welcome sign that the Minister has recognised the point that we have been making over the last few months and has included in his statement the assurance that, irrespective of the political persuasion of the people in these circumstances, consideration will be given to their entry into Australia. As they will be part of the total ugee program that will operate in Australia over the next year or two, we are unaware of the number of people who will fit into this category. Nonetheless, each of us would be well aware of the minorities in various parts of the world of whom we are talking. It is of concern to some honourable members particularly those on this side of the House-that being a member of a trade union in some Latin American countries can make a person a member of an oppressed minority. There is no doubt that some people in the Spanish speaking world will be eligible under this system to seek entry into Australia whereas under the refugee system they would not have been eligible to enter this country. The only point I make to the Minister about this statement is that it appears that the people who are considered will generally be people who are domiciled outside their own country. It is not always true that people who are part of an oppressed minority are domiciled outside their own borders. Many people who make up oppressed minorities are within the borders of their own country. I hope that the Government will not rule out consideration of these people should they want to make their way to Australia. As the Minister has pointed out, obviously the number of people who would like to come here will far outweigh the number that we will be able to settle successfully. Nevertheless, it will be an enormously important step in giving the elasticity that is required to our refugee program if we can successfully view oppressed minorities, whatever their political persuasion may be, and add them to the list of people who live in Australia. In the case of the Spanish speaking people, as there are 22 Spanish speaking countries there does not seem to be any difficulty in the communities that are already well establisi:led in this country in looking after those people who want to come to Australia. Similary, many of the other communities that are already well established in Australia will be able to" look after the people who apply to come here. I ask the Minister to look very carefully at this question. He said that the people who will be considered will be generally living in temporary asylum outside their own countries. It seems to me that many oppressed minorities are certainly within the borders of their own country. The other important feature of this program is that many of the criteria that apply to others in the general migration area will apply to these people. The necessary settlement support will be required from the various organisations or, in some cases, from the family, and applicants will ref- have to satisfy the normal character and security requirements. As I have said in this House on so many occasions, we have always to keep in mind the fact that we are doing this with the approval of the Australian people. That is the sort of thing that they would insist upon from this Parliament in bringing down a program of this nature. Whilst we give our support to the Minister's statement, I reiterate what I said at the outset: It will require greater elaboration by the Minister in terms of how the system is to apply. The field work in terms of the general migration system which will be carried out between now and April 1982 could be well applied to the scheme which has been announced in the Minister's statement. I hope that some of the complaints which have been received from individual members of parliament about applicants who have been knocked back because they have not been designated as refugees but are members of oppressed minorities, in whatever part of the world they live, will now be given consideration by this Government.
