Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Sturt-Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)-by leave-This statement is given in response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on management of the Australian coastal zone. As honourable members are aware, Australia has one of the world's longest coastlines. The coastal zone has particular significance for Australians since urban development and productive activity are clearly concentrated along much of the narrow band of land bordering the sea, particularly near the major cities. The coast's wide-ranging and valuable resources are subject to the continuing effects of both natural processes and man's activity. It was appropriate, therefore, for the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to investigate the management of the Australian coastal zone, and to report to this House. In its natural state the coast is subject to cycles of erosion and accretion which is a process that must be allowed to continue essentially unimpeded. The sometimes damaging effect of these natural forces can, however, be exacerbated by pressures to use the coast for urban development, mining, tourism, agriculture, forestry, transport and communications. There are also demands to leave parts of the coast in the natural state for purposes of recreation, nature conservation, education and scientific study. Given the importance of Australia's coastal areas, wise planning" and management of the varied and often competing uses is required if future damage by man's activities is to be reduced. As many agencies have responsibilities relating to coastal zone management, the Committee has drawn particular attention to the need for collaboration among all levels of government. Local governments have responsibility for urban development, generally under State planning guidelines, and for dealing with the immediate problems of coastal management. I note particularly the questions of litter control, beach plenishment, building safety, and protection of essential vegetation cover. State governments exercise their wide responsibiliti-s for mangement and preservation of the coastal zone through agencies such as planning departments, environment protection authorities, soil conservation agencies, maritime services and ports authorities, fisheries agencies, public works authorities and national parks services. The Commonwealth also has responsibilities in the coastal zone. It owns a significant area of coastal land, generally for purposes such as (-eÂ­ fence, communications and maritime purposes. In addition, the Commonwealth has a role in such matters as informations assembly, research and weather forecasting. The Commonwealth must ensure therefore that its activities are compatible with those of the States and that Commonwealth activities do not lead to further adverse effects. A further existing Commonwealth involvement in the coastal environment arises in consideration of the National Conservation Strategy which the Commonwealth is currently developing in consultation with the States and with the involvement of the Australian community. Honourable members will recall that the report of the Standing Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government should, in consultation with the States, develop and prpmulgate those policies and objectives which will conserve and preserve the Australian coastline; an Australian Coastal Management Council be estabc lished to encourage collaboration, assess information requirements and establish research priorities; conferences and workshops be conducted to stimulate information exchange; the Council have a full time secretariat; a central information register be established and a newsletter circulated; the Council establish criteria for the funding of research; the Council determine guidelines for the allocation of Commonwealth funds for State programs concerning coastal zone management. The Government is sympathetic to the thrust of all these recommendations. After careful consideration, however, the Government does not consider that a completely new Council is needed. This is a practical administrative matter, for as honourable members are well aware, unnecessary proliferation of public agencies must be avoided. The Government intends to respond to the Committee's report through existing machinery, as already there are several consultative bodies which provide for consultation between the Commonwealth and the States on coastal environment matters. The most relevant is the Australian sand reEnvironment Council of which I am a member, together with my State and Territory counterparts. Already the Council is involved in areas of environmental concern which are compatible with the thrust of the Standing Committee recommendations. Accordingly, the Government will be seeking the agreement of States and Territories that environmental matters of common interest relating to the coastal zone be carried forward, in the first instance, through the machinery of the Australian Environment Council, and in particular, the Council be invited to consider in collaboration with the other councils the best way in which it might promote the wise management of Australia's coastal resources.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Cunningham)-by leave-I am extremely disappointed that the Government today has rejected the major recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation with regard to the management of the Australian coastal zone. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment ( Mr Wilson) agrees in principle to them. He acknowledges their importance but then disregards them. He states the importance of proper management of our coast whose wideranging and valuable resources are subject to the effects of natural and human activities. The report recommends that the Commonwealth, in consultation with the States, develop and promulgate policies to conserve and preserve the coastline. It recommends that the Australian Coastal Management Council be established to encourage collaboration, assess information and establish research priorities. The Minister rejects this proposal which is instrumental to effective coastal management. There is a clear need for such a council as found by the Committee and for a national policy to be developed to counter the damage occurring to such a strategic area of our country. The term 'coastal zone' is a necessarily vague one since no Federal legislation specifies the exact area to be covered by a coastal zone. I turn to the report itself for a definition. It says: The coastal zone must include estuaries, their associated wetlands and catchments, shallow bays and shallow i,nshore waters. All these environments are part of one interconnected system which includes not only the associated flora and fauna The Minister briefly sets out the wide area which he says falls uncleI' State Government responsibility for management and preservation of this zone including planning, environment protection, soil conservation, maritime services, fishing, public works and national parks. He really acknowledges Commonwealth responsibility only in such matters as weather forecasting, defence and communications, but he completely ignores the unanimous findings of the Committee. It stated: Management of the coastal zone must encompass all coastal resources within both the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone. Exploitation areas will have an impact on ing, pipelines, seabed mining, provision of extensive coastal support and/or processing facilities for major extractive industries. The Committee believes that it is imperative that national coastal objectives negotiations prior to the Commonwealth relinquishing any further control to the States. Further, the Committee-this was a unanimous finding of a joint committee of this House-quite rightly said that although it acknowledges State responsibilities there is still a very great role to be played by the Commonwealth. Most States have actually asked the Commonwealth for greater involvement and to develop policies to provide guidelines for State initiatives in coastal planning. They have actually asked for more Commonwealth involvement. The Opposition demands to know why the Minister has ducked these requests from the States and ducked his responsibility. He acknowledges some Commonwealth involvement and then rejects the very reasonable mechanisms set out by the Committee to handle these problems through the establishment of an Australian Coastal Management Council, particularly when the Minister's own Department gave this evidence to the Committee. The Department recommended that: National objectives be established for the conservation and preservation of the Australian coastline through Commonwealth-State consultation; A co-ordinated approach to coastal management be developed by Commonwealth authorities; Arrangements for improved Commonwealth-State collaboration on these issues be developed; and Suitable processes at a national seminating information on coastal research and management activities. All of that led us on the Committee to the inescapable conclusion that a national council for coastal management should be set up as set out in the report. Why did the Department make these recommendations to the Committee only to see the Government and its own Minister renege on them? the water and sea bed but also I now refer back to the recommendation that no more of the coastal zone should be handed back to the States lInU these objectives have been achieved. Already we have had the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act which was part of the scandalous sell-out of the Commonwealth responsibility last year and which handed back control of the territorial sea out to the five-kilometre limit to the States, with the remainder out to the edge of the continental shelf to be administered as a joint Commonwealth-State responsibility. I make the point that all the nonsense we have heard from State governments, particularly from the Queensland Premier about Commonwealth of resources within these the coastal zone (offshore drillintrusion into State rights regarding the coastal zone and the territorial sea, is fallacious and misleading. There is no reason why the Commonwealth should not control the territorial sea from be specified and accounted for in the low water mark for the issue of mining and 'exploration licences and no reason why the States should not retain their constitutional rights for those matters raised by the Minister tonight; that is, ports, public works, fishing and so on. The best example of the confusion and acrimony created by the Commonwealth's two-faced attitude is the current power struggle between the Federal and Queensland Governments over the declaration of the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. There is no reason why the Federal Government cannot declare to the low - ater mark the whole of the Cairns section, mdeed, the whole reef area as marine park as designated in the 1975 Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and then involve the Queensland Government in the preparation of zoning plans for the various sections of the whole park and continuing arrangements for public works and sea ports but taking away all rights to issue mining and drilling licences as signified in the original Act. By weakly declaring only 30 per cent of the Cairns section along the western perimeter to the low water mark the Minister and the Government-'-we warn them on this-are simply creating conditions for future clashes between the Queensland Government and any future Federal government of any political colour, given the state of mind of the present Government in level be developed for disQueensland. Make no mistake, a Federal Labor Government will terminate this situation by declaring the Barrier Reef to the low water mark in its entirety and by reasserting-this is even more important in the long run-Federal control over the territorial sea. A further example-I will conclude on this note-of this Government's contradictory attitude to the control of the :lea and the coastal water zone was the autumn session amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act which placed the whole of the Coral Sea under FederalState control for the admitted purpose of allowing oil drilling in proximity to the Barrier Reef. Coupled with this is the statement by the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) that current research may show that future oil drilling may be possible on or near the reef. These statements and attitudes cast a grim shadow over the reef's future, despite the Prime Minister's recent welcome, albeit partial, declaration of the Cairns tion. I consider it an insult to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, to the Committee and to this House that the Government has not picked up the recommendations in the report. It is a dangerous rejection of sound environmental policy and a receipe for disaster for the future management of one of Australia's most valuable assets, our national coastline. Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Sturt-Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)-by leave-This statement is a response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on the grants to voluntary conservation organisations program. This program was established in 1973 following the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate. In 1979 Senator Webster, the then Minister responsible for environmental matters, instigated a review of the program. As part of the review Senator Webster invited the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to comment on the program. The Committee did this most expeditiously, tabling its report on 15 May last year. The Government, like the Standing Committee, strongly supports the grants to voluntary conservation bodies program. It is, I believe, a healthy sign of democracy in action when groups of publicly interested citizens are assisted by government to watch over the state of the Australian environment. These groups perform an important function in representing the interests of environment and conservation and stimulate public debate on what is really a finely balanced relationship, the interdependence of environment and the use of our physical resources. The recommendations of the Standing Committee are mostly concerned with additional funding or the relaxation of funding conditions. In the framework of the 1981-82 Budget it was not appropriate to provide additional funds for the program. The case for additional funding, as presented by the Committee, will be considered in the context of the 1982-83 Budget. The Committee also recommended that the dollar for dollar matching requirement be relaxed. The Government's intention, in applying a matching condition, was to decrease the dependence of conservation groups on government. It secwas also expected that in obtaining funding support from the public, conservation groups would foster close links with the community they sought to serve, and hence be responsive to general public attitudes and needs. Whilst the Government considers that these aims are being achieved, it believes that continuation of a matching arrangement is appropriate to encourage voluntary groups to cultivate othef'Sources of funds. The Standing Committee has also recommended additional funding for conservation groups to enable them to undertake special projects, to obtain technical assistance, and to undertake research. As well as the general need to constrain additional funding, the Government has difficulty with the practicability of establishing three separate funding schemes for the purposes recommended by the Committee. The schemes would be relatively costly to administer and determining priorities would be difficult. The Government proposes, therefore, that no special fund be established, but that the purposes of the grants be widened beyond that of administration to include approved technical assistance and research. The Committee made two recommendations which did not relate to funding. One advocates the broadening of eligibility criteria for funding under the program. The present guidelines require that, to be eligible, an organisation must 'have nature conservation as its primary objective or one of its primary objectives and its actions must be consistent with those objectives'. While this definition is capable of broad interpretation, the Government recognises that environment protection and nature conservation are closely related and are both addressed by many of the voluntary organisations which are assisted. Accordingly, the Government has agreed to adopt the recommended criterion, that 'an organisation must have the protection and enhancement of the environment as its primary objective and its actions must be consistent with that objective'. The other non-funding recommendation relates to the manner in which the Minister seeks advice on the allocation of funds each year. While there are a number of bodies which might be consulted, I do not consider it proper for advice to the Minister to be so constrained. In conclusion, I wish to thank the members of the Committee for the detailed attention they have given to this important matter. I regret that unavoidable circumstances have delayed the Government's response and that, on this occasion, it has not been possible to meet the recommendation for additional funding. However, the Government will keep the matter under review. In this regard the report of the Standing Committee will continue to provide a valuable source of reference.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Cunningham)-by leave-Once again, the Government has refused to pick up a recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. I find it incredible that the Government has ignored that Committee's call for increased funding for voluntary conservation organisations, particularly when one considers that this financial year a surplus of $1.5 billion is predicted in the Budget. The voluntary conservation groups perform an essential function by raising issues and acting as a watch-dog over private and public developments. In the present climate of environment assessment, in which the States lack uniform environment legislation and the Commonwealth requires few environmental impact statements and no public inquiries, the importance of the voluntary groups in promoting proper pubIlcawareness and input is very obvious. I am sure that even the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment ( Mr Wilson) accepts that fact. Despite that, the present Government has progressively cut back on funding for those groups. Since 1975-76 funds have been cut by 48 per cent in real terms. Nevertheless, the Minister tells the House that the Government strongly supports those groups but will not consider any increase in funding until next financial year. That is the case, despite the fact that the funding of those groups has been cut back by nearly 50 per cent in real terms in the past few years. How are those groups expected to continue their work? The Committee recommended that the matching funding requirements for environment centres be dropped because those centres provided a valuable information facility to a wide variety of users, which facility, if provided by Government, would be infinitely more expensive to the taxpayer. But the Government rejected that recommendation also. It wants to force those centres to spend more time raising money-this is the key-and less time in examining the environmental effects of resource development. I cannot overstate the importance of the voluntary conservation movement to Australia's environment. It publicises important environmental issues and raises the level of public awareness. It makes submissions to people making environmental impact assessments and preparing statements and to public inquiries in the States, when they are set up-mainly in New South Wales. The voluntary conservation movement carries out research and investigation that very often the authorities at a Federal and State level either cannot or, will not do. The voluntary conservation movement plays an important role in all States, but especially in those with minimal environment laws, such as Queensland. Lack of uniform legislation is a major problem in the States, as the Government and the Minister well know. It is a problem which the present Government has ignored. The Commonwealth is opting out of proper environment assessment, leaving the field open to the ill-prepared State governments. Only in New South Wales and Victoria is there adequate environment assessment legislation. Except in New South Wales, public inquiries are unheard of, despite continued calls by the environment groups. They are concerned that issues are getting short shrift from the States' assessment procedures. Important environmental issues sU,ch as south west Tasmania and sandmining on Moreton Island have been raised in public and on the parliamentary scene, prompted by groups such as the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and the Moreton Island Protection Committee. The issues that they have raised are of such importance that they require public inquiries under the Commonwealth's 'Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, but this Government has refused to call such inquiries. Two groups which are deserving of funds but which did not get even a mention or a piece of the present tiny cake are those I have just mentioned-the wilderness societies in Tasmania and in the mainland States and the Moreton Island Protection Committee. They clearly ought to be funded but are not. The Australian Conservation Foundation, the largest and most respected conservation organisation in the country, has had its funding cut by 75 per cent in real terms in the last five years. sult, this Government must be seen as meanminded. All the Minister's fine words about his sympathy for the groups and about the good job that they do will not alter the fact that the Government has attempted to muzzle the envir:onment movement by restricting funds and by requiring full matching funds to be provided by the organisations themselves. This has not stopped the groups, but it has made things very difficult for them at a time when rapid resource development is placing increasing stresses on the environment and the States lack the capacity and the will adequately to examine projects as they are put forward. As I said, only New South Wales has the legislation on the statute book to assess new projects adequately by requiring environment impact statements and the capacity to put them to public inquiry if the Minister and the Department so declare. The Federal Government has that ability also under the present Federal Act, but there have been only two inquiries-the Ranger inquiry into uranium mining in Kakadu National Park and an inquiry into sand mining on Fraser Island. Both of those inquiries were set up by the Whitlam Labor Government and acted upon in one way or another by the present Government. It is about time this Government picked up its responsibilities in that area and ordered inquiries not into every little project but into projects which affect the major and significant environmental areas in Australia. Of course, it is not doing this. What I am saying is that, in the absence of the Government's acceptance of these responsibilities, these voluntary groups, which consist of many conscientious and concerned people throughout Australia, are picking up those responsibilities in situations in which the Federal Government and most of the State governments. are refusing to act. Were this Government genuinely concerned about the environment, it would have substantially increased funding to these admirable voluntary environment and conservation groups. NA Bill returned from the Senate without amendment. NA Suspension of Standing Orders

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: New England- Leader of the House)-I seek leave to move the suspension of so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent my moving a motion which has been distributed and'which is intended to provide for references to As a rethe Committee of Privileges when the House is not sitting. I should explain that the reason for seeking leave is that the desire of the Government is that there should be as soon as possible a full debate on privilege, but it felt that this motion needed to be pa-sed before the House rises. If I can have leave perhaps I can briefly address myself to the matter. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Those honourable members who have had a chance to look at the motion will know that it fits in very much with one of the recommendations of a recent examination by the Committee of Privileges. The concept is that when the House is not sitting there should be a capacity for a member to bring to your attention, Mr Speaker, as Speaker, a matter of privilege which that member proposes should be referred to the Committee of Privileges. Then if you, Mr Speaker, are satisfied that a prima facie case has been made out and the matter is one upon which urgent action should be taken, you would be in a position to be able to refer it forthwith to the Committee of Privileges, provided that any referral in accordance with these provisions is reported to the House at its next sitting whereupon the member who raised the matter shall be required to move forthwith, without notice, that such referral be endorsed by the House. There are quite a number of outstanding issues on privilege. In view of the late hour I felt that it would be preferable if we opened up debate on this matter to give those members who may wish to make a contribution an opportunity to do so but, at the same time, give an undertaking to the House that there will be a full opportunity for a privileges debate to be held early in the next session. There are a number of outstanding reports. There is the Privileges Committee report on Laurie Oakes and the report in relation to Preston Motors both of which have been presented to the Parliament during the Budget session. A recommendation came out of the Privileges Committee report on the Berthelsen matter that a parliamentary witnesses protection Act should be BILL constituted. Perhaps it might be wise, as I go through, if I mention the Government's reaction to each of these matters. With respect to the report on Mr Laurie Oakes and the report on Preston Motors the Government did not feel it was necessary for any further action to be taken. With respect to the recommendation of the Berthelsen matter for a parliamentary witnesses protection Act, there are a number of issues that concern the Government although at this stage the Government does not feel disposed to accept the recommendation for a parliamentary witnesses protection Act. However, there are a number of areas that concern the Government that I believe need to be debated in this place. Quite obviously a number of parliamentary committees are placed in a position in which they cross-examine public servants. Those pnblic servants are not given the protection that is available within a court oflaw. While parliamentary papers to examine the question of witnesses have been prepared there has to this stage been no action taken by the Parliament to pick up those matters. As the matter would be expected to be examined on our return, perhaps I should put into Hansard the references so that those members with a particular interest can turn to them. There is a particularly good parliamentary paper, No. 168 of 1972, which is entitled 'Powers over and Protection afforded to witnesses before Parliamentary Committees'. This paper was prepared by the then Attorney-General, our former colleague the late Senator Ivor Greenwood, and the then Solicitor-General, Mr Bob Ellicott. This picks up some of the matters which I believe members in this place do need to examine and consider with respect to the protection of parliamentary witnesses. It may be that as a result of that debate some other course of action might be decided on. Certainly, the Government has reservations about the recommendation for a parliamentary witnesses protection Act which emanated from the Berthelsen report. Another matter that concerns the Government is the question of unsubstantiated allegations. On a number of occasions statements of a damaging character have been made in both chambers. Quite often they are made on either unsupported or minimal evidence. There seem to be difficulties when parliamentary privilege is used in such a way as to throw discredit on people when the charges themselves are not backed up. We all recognise the very essence of parliamentary privilege is that members need to be in a position to canvass matters that they may not outside the Parliament. Yet the abuse of privilege is one of the difficult areas in the manner and form by which parliamentarians perform their duty. It is certainly true that this is a matter which deserves adequate attention in the Parliament. I raise it now not to canvass the substance of the issue but to suggest that it, too, is a matter which the Government would like examined and would wish to make some comment on in a more meaningful way and in a more adequate debate than is possible at this hour at this time of the sitting. The other matter which has come out of the more recent Privileges Committee report is the recommendation that a joint committee be established between the other place and this place to examine privileges. I notice that the honourable member for Corio ( Mr Scholes), in General Business Notice No.4, has in fact picked up this recommendation. The Government has a number of matters which it would wish to examine before this motion is considered and before a motion is moved in this place or is debated in this place, whether it be a motion moved by the honourable member for Corio or a different one to be moved by the Government. The two particular issues relate to the fact that the Senate has expressed some views about joint committees. There is little doubt that the question of privilege is a parliamentary question; yet it is also a question which needs to be examined in relation to either chamber. It is not much use our just going down the track of looking at these things where there is a common privilege, for I think that in each House there are matters which honourable members and honourable senators may wish to pursue where there may be differences between us. The question of a joint committee, I believe, needs to be considered in conjunction with the Senate and it would be the intention of the Government to discuss these matters with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and with honourable senators prior to the resumption of parliament so that a meaningful consideration can be given to that part of the recommendation. There is also the question of the terms of reference. It would be my proposal that the Government should submit draft terms of reference to this place so that we could consider them. The Committee should be constituted in accordance with the recommendation of that Privileges Committee. It certainly, therefore, is not the intention of the Government to delay this process unduly but rather to ensure that the matter is brought before us and can be debated with some idea of where we are going. So it is that I move the sessional order which I have just introduced into the Parliament. It is a sessional orderMONICA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I hesitate to interrupt the right honourable gentleman but he obtained leave to suspend Standing Orders. I will allow him to interrupt his remarks to move the suspension of Standing Orders. He can then move his motion.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I move: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the House moving a motion for the adoption of sessional orders relating to privilege. Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: New England-Leader of the House) (11.23)-I move: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following standing orders be adopted for the remainder of this Session: Privilege matter raised when House not sitting '97A. During a period when the House is not sitting and is not expected to meet for a further period of at least 2 weeks, a Member may bring to the attention privilege which has arisen since he proposes should be referred to the Committee of Privileges. If Mr Speaker is satisfied that a prima facie case of breach of privilege has been made out and the matter is one upon which urgent action should be taken, Committee of Privileges: Provided that any referral by Mr Speaker in accordance with the foregoing provisions of this standing order shall be reported to the House by Mr Speaker at its next sitting whereupon the Member who raised the matter shall be required to move such referral be endorsed by negatived, the Committee of Privileges shall take no further action in respect of the matter. Power to send for persons, papers and records 978. Where a matter is referred leges by Mr Speaker in accordance with the provisions of standing order 97 A, the Committee of Privileges shall have power to send for persons, papers and records relating to that inquiry'. This sessional order is of some difference from any which have been moved before but I commend it to members of this House because I believe it is a worthwhile step. I do recognise that there may be some difficulty in a Privileges Committee meeting taking place during the parliamentary recess but I believe it is a justifiable step and one, therefore, that deserves the support of the members of this place. In closing, I reiterate that it would be the Government's intention to return to the debate on those matters of privilege which are outstanding, which stand on the Notice Paper and which, of course, were listed in the blue sheet early in the resumption of the Parliament in February 1982.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Kingsford-Smith) (11.24)-The Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) has referred to a number of matters. Let me take them perhaps in the order in which he would like them dealt with. He raised the question of a motion being required-he, in fact, moved such a motion-so that a matter of privilege can be raised when the House is not sitting. The Opposition supports that motion. In fact, I might remind the House that it was the recommendation of a Privileges Committee on which I served-it dealt with the Berthelsen case-and which reported to a previous parliament back in September 1980. We recommended that there be a mechanism whereby matters of privilege could be referred for examination when the Parliament Motion was not in session. That flowed, of course, from the fact that in the Berthelsen case certainly a question of privilege arose but, because the Parliament was not in session, there was some delay in dealing with it. There are other matters of which the Minister has spoken, concerning which I find the Government's view somewhat disappointing. Without of the Speaker a matter of the House last met and which being personal about it, the Berthelsen case did clearly indicate that a person had suffered damage. The Committee of Privileges went to a lot of trouble, after examining witnesses, to indicate he shall refer it forthwith to the clearly that something should be done about that. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that the Committee recommended the enactment of a Parliamentary Witnesses Protection Act, which forthwith, without notice, that the House; should such motion be would provide for the prosecution of persons who tampered with, intimidated or discriminated against persons who had given evidence before a parliamentary committee. It was clear that that kind of thing had indeed happened. to the Committee of PriviI do not think that we are breaking new ground in a hurry. I remind the House that the House of Commons has the Witnesses Public Inquiries Protection Act 1892. It has been in force since that year but we still seem to be struggling to do something about privileges-not so much for ourselves but in this case for citizens who have suffered damage. If honourable members examine the proposed Witnesses Protection Act they wi1l find that it provides that people who obstruct or intimidate witnesses can be dealt with. It states clearly that compensation can be awarded to the party who is aggrieved and makes the point that no legal proceedings are to be taken against persons who give evidence. Those requirements are pretty elementary and public opinion would expect that if this Parliament is to continue its effective work as a democratic institution-committee work is part . and parcel of its function-it is important that witnesses who appear before its committees not suffer any damage whatsoever as a result. In Berthelsen's case damage certainly was sustained, and that kind of thing can continue to happen. It is of significance that in these days the Parliament works very well in bringing to light matters that the public feels should be aired, but if we study the Berthelsen case we find that in the Department of Defence there is quite a lot that is wrong. One can identify it from the sort of evidence that was given, from the way in which people contradicted themselves and virtually connived in certain circumstances at bringing about a situation which might have deluded the Committee into making the wrong finding and certainly would have affected the career of one man. I turn to a matter raised in the House this week. It concerns the Public Service Board and the Department of Transport and relates to a reclassification claim by the Professional and Electronics Radio Institute of Australia. There has been an indictment which, of course, has yet to be established, concerning how the Public Service Board and the Department of Transport carried out their functions in respect of a particular matter. It all relates to the question whether evidence has been properly given or some attempt made to delude the Parliament. It is important that committees have free and unfettered ability to investigate these matters. It would be of great value to a Parliament to know that it had such protective legislation. I close by saying that it is disappointing that although we have had all this discussion on the subject over such a long period-I am not now adverting to the recent privileges report but to the matter with which I was associated some time ago; the Berthelsen case took virtually two years to complete-so little has been achieved. In the previous Parliament, on 17 September 1980, the Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) proposed a motion, which we would still applaud, in these terms: That(I) this House, recognising the need for extensive consideration by the House of the report from the Committee of Privileges . . . is of the opinion that the report should be considered early in the 32nd Parliament . . . We are now a third of the way through the Thirtysecond Parliament. That resolution simply got lost. I remind the Minister and the Government that they promised in the previous Parliament to deal with the matter early in this Parliament and that they might well now be able to deal with it very soon indeed. Mr Jacobi-They are great ones at moving things, but not too good at debating them.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: That is right. My point is that a lot of work has been done, but I have no objection to a joint committee of privileges being established; that is fine. We are dealing with the question that people's rights have been affected. I cannot see any objection to introducing legislation that would protect witnesses. It is very important that that be done early next year. Having said that, and being aware of the other pressures on the House at this late hour, I merely record that the Opposition supports the motion.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Fadden) (11.30)-As Chairman of the Privileges Committee, I feel that I should make one or two observations about the procedures which have been introduced into this House tonight. There is a possibility that the Committee might like to give consideration to these matters. Neverthless we are pleased that the Government and, indeed, the House, with the agreement of both sides, have recognised the need for an inquiry. I do not propose to keep the House sitting beyond the middle of the night. Perhaps other members wish to add one or two comments. I take advantage of this opportunity to make brief observations in relation to the last hearing, which is known as the Oakes case. I have been a member of the Privileges Committee since about 1969. I have been its chairman for a number of years. That case would be, without doubt, the most difficult hearing that I have had to conduct in that period. I suppose that that was due very much to the fact that there was some dissension within the Committee about whether the matter should even have been before it. The honourable member for Lalor ( Mr Barry Jones) made reference some days ago when this debate commenced to the quality of the hearing. Members of this chamber may have gained the impression from listening to his comments that he had a very definite view on the subject. When people of firm mind are present at these hearings it adds to the difficulties. In conclusion, the Committee cannot continue to function properly if such a diversity of views is allowed to exist without being explored by a proper joint committee of inquiry. I compliment those who have recognised the worth of the Committee's recommendations, which, I point out to the Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair), were first brought before this chamber in 1978 following the Sunday Observer report, although they were not in as extensive a form as they are now. Let us hope, as we move into next year, that the privileges system of the Australian Parliament will be on a better footing than it is at present. I remind honourable members and those who are critical of privilege that privilege belongs not only to this Parliament but also to the Press and to the people. Every time the Press reports something about this chamber that is a little out of the ordinary it is utilising one form of privilege in its presentation of that matter. Indeed, often when honourable members stand in this chamber and take up the cudgels on behalf of a constituent, privilege is needed to permit the exposure of a certain matter. Whilst I know that it could be argued fairly that privilege is wide ranging, I would hate a situation to exist in the community whereby some with vested interests could beat up such feeling and fervour against some aspects of the subject as to lead to the destruction of the entire concept which has existed for centuries ..

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Corio) (11.35)-1 want to express some disappointment that we are again deferring consideration of the entire matter of privilege. The motion before us does not deal in any way with the subject matter of the report which was brought into this Parliament in 1978-the Berthelsen report-and which we have been promised the opportunity of considering in this House for over a year, or the two current inquiries before the House which 1 thought at least could have been disposed of in substance before the end of this session. I think most members of this Parliament want a joint committee set up to \llake a complete examination of privilege. 1 think it is regrettable that on the earlier occasion the Senate reported back to this House that it was not prepared to co-operate in a joint committee to examine the privileges of this Parliament. I am not sure by what process it was determined that the Senate was not prepared to cooperate. I am not sure that the senators were consulted or that the Government representatives in the Senate were consulted. If that committee had deemed that legislation was necessary-I would have thought that that would be the result-then appropriate legislation could be enacted to meet the provisions of the Constitution. I do not believe, as the Minister for Communications ( Mr Sinclair) has indicated, that we can reasonably expect the public to accept a situation whereby the Houses pass legislation which provides different forms of privilege and other avenues of protection to the two Houses. 1 think that the public would expect the Australian Parliament to enact legislation which had a degree of uniformity and uniform application. In this day and age the public would expect it to be readily identified by those people whom it would apply and whom it may affect, including the members. One of the problems about privilege, contempt of Parliament and the other associated matters is that there are very few people who actually understand what privilege is, including members of this chamber and the Senate. There are even fewer people who appear to understand the difference between a member of the Parliament, a Minister of the Crown and other functionaries and the applications and the limitations of privilege. 1 think it would not do any harm, even at this stage and even if we have not actually got to the stage of inquiring into what privileges we are going to fix, if some simplified form of the existing privileges could be prepared so that at least the members of this Parliament could understand what privilege is and how limited its application is, in effect, in protecting members in respect of what they do and what they say outside this chamber. I think it is also essential that any examination be a joint examination. 1 note that the problem has been added to by the fact that the Senate has before it at the moment a private members' Bill relative to contempt which proposes that the whole matter of contempt be taken outside the control of the Parliament and placed under the control of the courts. That may be good for lawyers; I am not sure that it will be good for parliament. Certainly, the matter of privilege must at all stages be a matter for the Parliament. But people. must be able to be confident that they know what the law is and where they stand in respect of the Parliament. Mysteries and mystiques are not in the best interests of the Parliament. I see deferral by this House of the commencement of the procedures to set up a joint committee as a negative step. The sooner we tackle privilegeand it is a very difficult problem-and the sooner we seek to resolve the problems between the Houses so that we can have a uniform set of standards under which this Parliament operates the better. I do not think it does this House or anyone else any good to have long hearings of matters when the Privileges Committee and the House will ultimately make findings that they will take no further action. 1 think the cases on the Notice Paper at the moment are both in that category. I was one.of those members of the Committee who was of the opinion-this is shown in the minutes-that the matter should be resolved quickly and brought back to the House as quickly as possible. 1 believe that we will not be able to avoid the matter of privilege for long with imto punity and without loss of dignity to this Parliament. The sooner we settle down to having a proper inquiry the better. The sooner we resolve the problem-we decide either to do nothing or to do something significant in concert with the Senate-the less chance there will be of having a continuing problem with privilege, grandstanding by some individuals and misinterpretation by others.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Dundas) (11.40)-1 take the opportunity of this motion and the wider discussion on the matters raised by the Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) to expand briefly on my view on the need for a joint select committee to examine the question of privilege in relation to this House and to the Senate. Some discussion has already taken place on that matter. It has already been mentioned by the speaker who preceded me, the honourable member for Corio ( Mr Scholes), that there is a private members Bill in the Senate to deal with the question of contempt of parliament generally. One might argue that, in a sense, it pre-empts the examination of this subject. That may give honourable members some cause for concern. It gives me cause for concern. I have agonised over the question of contempt of parliament for some time. I have agonised over the question of whether parliament ought to be a judge in its own cause. Some comment was directed at me because I raised a matter of privilege and had it referred to the Committee of Privileges when perhaps some people were aware of the reservations-my thoughts on this matter had been in the process of developing-I had about an extra parliamentary role in determining the question of contempt of parliament. I worked with the procedures that were available at the time. I think the broader question of whether there should be an extra parliamentary role for the judiciary in determining the question of contempt where prima facie cases have been found is a matter to be examined by all honourable members in consideration of all of the issues that need to be raised. A detailed commentary was made by Dennis Pearce on the question of parliamentary privilege which perhaps was the first article that I read that significantly influenced me. But there has been a new and more recent influence. I draw it to the attention of honourable members because it may give them some cause for concern as it did me when I learnt of the particular events that took place recently in Canada. Recently I was at a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference and a paper that was delivered to clerks was brought to my attention. It was a paper by E. George MACMinn, Commissioner of the Legislature Procedure Review Act of the Province of British Columbia. His paper dealt with police powers and confidentiality between a constituent and his member of parliament. The case, of course, concerned the Royal Canadian Mounted Police where certain phone tapping had been going on apparently with some undesirable individuals, with the police intercepting conversations. A member of parliament's name was mentioned relating to an attempt to bring influence to bear upon that member of parliament. As a result, the police sought the authority, under the appropriate legislation in the province of British Columbia-I believe that it went to the Supreme Court for the authority-to tap the member's personal phone, the phone in the legislative buildings and also, I understand, in a Minister's office. That order was given by a court without any consideration of whether the parliament or parliamentary privilege was likely to be affected by it. Some people assume that judges might be better able to judge these matters than members themselves. But I think when one knows of circumstances like that, one appreciates that there could be circumstances where judges would not have the same regard for the privilege of the parliament, and there may be circumstances where they would not even give consideration to that question. I think that particular case ought to be looked at and this matter needs to be considered by a joint parliamentary committee. The matter of the particular report in which I was involvedthe report relating to the printed reference to an article published in the Sydney Daily Mirror of Wednesday, 2 September 1981-is another matter to which I would like to advert briefly and make three short points. The points are these. There was some implied criticism from some members who reported this matter of the fact that the article by Mr Oakes was written in the Sydney Daily Mirror and was also published in some other newspapers but the reference in other newspapers was not referred to the Cominittee of Privi,leges. I would like to make it quite clear that I raised this matter at the first available opportunity, and at that time. I was only aware of the Daily Mirror article. Of course, the opportunity having passed I did not think it was appropriate for me to raise the question of the other articles although if other honourable members had seen them they may have thought it appropriate and could have done so. Secondly, there was some implied criticism of the article in the Australian Financial Review which dealt with similar material but which, as I said in an explanation to this House, was not precisely the same material and was not referred to the Committee of Privileges. I made my position clear on that matter. When I spoke to it at the first available opportunity, I indicated that if other members had a different view to mine, they should also consider referring the matter to the Privileges Committee. It was for them to consider, and members had that opportunity. One other matter I would like to canvass briefly is why I moved that this matter be considered by the Committee of Privileges. Mr Speaker, as you know you proposed an alternative course of action when you found the priina facie case. I accepted the fact that there was an alternative and the alternative that was proposed by you was very similar to the decision that was ultimately reached by the Privileges Committee. I do have a concern that people who are brought before committees of the Parliament ought to be given protection. In a sense I would be very much in favour of legislation to deal with that matter or at least for the Committee to consider it. But I also believe that people are entitled not to have a finding made by the Parliament without some inquiry or opportunity to appear before a committee to explain their position. It was for that reason that I proposed that the matter be referred to the Privileges Committee rather than take the simple course, and the course which the Committee adopted, of making a finding without giving the person the opportunity to appear. I felt that as perhaps there was some implied criticism of myself for having proposed that course of action I should make that explanation at this opportunity. MrDUFFY (Holt) (11.48)-Tosaytheleastit is unfortunate that this matter has come before the Parliament at this stage in the sitting because the one thing we seem to be able to do is talk a about privilege but take no action. The matter should have come on at a time when it could have been dealt with in more detail. As a result of what has become known <,.s the 'Oakes case', the unsatisfactory state of the law of precedent and practice and the law of privilege has received considerable prominence. The difficulties experienced by the Committee of Privileges are demonstrated by the fact that four reports are included in the report of the Committee of Privileges-a majority report and three dissenting reports. The first dissenting report was by the honourable member for Lalor ( Mr Barry Jones) and myself. The honourable member for Lalor summarised our report in his speech on 29 October, but I consider it necessary to spend some time on the major objections that we found to the procedures in privilege cases. There are three such matters. Firstly, in practice the Committee of Privileges operates as a secret committee. This leads to the absurd situation where accused persons are informed that they are not allowed to communicate the substance of any cross-examination to their legal advisers. Such legal advisers are not present at the hearing but those appearing before the Committee are entitled to obtain legal advice outside the conduct of the Committee hearings. Clearly if people are to obtain any protection from such restricted legal advice they must be able to discuss the matters raised at the hearings with their legal adviser. In my view the absolute stupidity of the current procedures is starkly revealed when people who appear before the Committee are informed that they cannot discuss the substance of any cross-examination undertaken at the hearing. If those appearing before the Committee comply with this ridiculous direction, it is almost impossible to comprehend what they do discuss with their legal advisers, apart from the obvious criticism of the procedures of the Committee. This matter would, of course, be overcome if they were entitled to full legal representation, and that is the second matter that I desire to deal with. The denial of legal representation in hearings before the Committee is a matter which should cause all members grave concern. The majority report does indicate the problems experienced by the Committee in the Oakes case and has clearly placed those matters before this Parliament for consideration by a joint committee. However, the majority report, while recognising the need for review and reform on the issue of legal representation, does not make a specific finding. We consider that the right of legal representation is so fundamental that it was necessary to state clearly lot in a dissenting report that a person appearing before the Committee is entitled to full. legal representation. A considerable amount of the time of the Committee was spent on the issue of whether Mr Wylie, the editor of the Daily Mirror, was entitled to legal representation. The Committee allowed Mr T. E. F. Hughes, QC. and Mr N. R. Carson to argue the right to appear for Mr Wylie, and Mr Hughes addressed the Committee on 21 September. But the Committee determined that the application for counsel to appear generally on behalf of Mr Wylie is not granted. It is important to determine why the Committee took the decision not to grant legal representation to Mr Wylie. A memorandum from the Clerk of the House advised the Committee as follows: Persons accused of breaches of privileges or of other contempts of either House are not as a rule allowed to be defended by counsel: But in a few cases incriminated persons have been allowed to be heard by counsel, the hearing being sometimes limited to 'such points as do not controvert the privileges of the House'. Considerable debate took place in relation to this matter as it will be noted that the advice stated that in a few cases incriminated persons have been allowed to be heard by counsel, the hearing being sometimes limited to such points as do not controvert the privileges of the House. The Committee decided that representation was limited to arguing the right to be heard, which would of course be denied, and possibly on the question of penalty. Apart from the fact that representation has not been permitted before the House of Commons Privileges Committee during the hearing of evidence since the I 770s, a precedent followed by this House, there is no reason to deny legal representation. For this Parliament in 1981 to follow precedents set in England in the 1770s is absolute stupidity. The relevance of procedures established by the House of Commons in the 1770s totally escapes me and I hope that its irrelevance will be accepted by the members of this House. It is worth noting that we are pinned down in this matter by archaic precedents established in England in a period when slavery still existed. It was not until Lord Mansfield's judgment in Somerset's case in 1772 that slavery was declared illegal. Civil liberties as practised in England in that period of history is dramatically illustrated by the methods used for the establishment of the colony of New South Wales. Yet this Parliament is still wallowing in precedents of that period in a pathetic attempt to justify denying the fundamental right of an accused person to have legal representation, a right which every member of this Parliament would demand for himself or herself and I hope, for all other Australians save and accept, on our present standards, a person who has injured the dignity of the members of this House. The present situation of denying legal representation to those accused by us is an outrage and this Parliament cannot continue to deny such a fundamental right to those accused by it. Thirdly, there is a crucial issue of Parliament acting as prosecutor and judge, that is, acting as judge in its own cause. In the Oakes case, it is a matter for regret that our privilege law did not enable you, Mr Speaker, to dispose of the matter summarily by rejecting the accuracy of the article and declaring that the matter was not worthy of further occupying the time of the House. The law of parliamentary privilege is to protect the institution of Parliament, and I quote from the memorandum prepared by the Clerk of the House at page 69 of the report under the heading 'Contempt in General' from May's Parliamentary Practice, 19th edition, page 136, as follows: It may be stated generally that any act or omission which obstructs or impedes either formance of its functions, member or officer of such House in the discharge of his duty, or which has a tendency, directly or indirectly, to produce such results may be treated as a contempt even though there is no precedent of the offence. It is this type of contempt that should concern the Parliament, while instances of vulgar abuse such as the Oakes article should be disposed of summarily. However, in accordance with modern principles of justice it is our view that the power to punish for contempt should be removed from the Parliament and transferred to a court. It is fundamental that the victims cannot also take the roles of prosecutor and judges. This is not a new concept. In 1908 a joint select committee on procedure in cases of privilege chaired by Sir John Quick recommended the transfer of jurisdiction to a court. No further action was taken until 1934 when a draft Bill dealing with offences against the Parliament was prepared but never presented to the Parliament. Members of this Parliament have an obligation to act on the issues raised in the report of the Committee of Privileges and the dissenting reports. In particular the issues of secrecy, legal representation and removal of the power to punish being transferred from this Parliament to a court are crucial issues if the law of privilege is to be taken seriously. I am pleased that the Minister for the Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman) has come into the House. Before finishing my remarks I think it is necessary to deal briefly with the matters raised in this debate on 29 Oct.ober by the Minister for the Capital Territory who came into this House parading as the great defender of civil liberties. Despite his dramatic and pompous presentation of his own defence, it was most unconvincing. It was pleasing to learn that the Minister advocates full rights of legal representation as that view was not evident during the hearing of the Oakes case. It should be noted that it was the same Minister for the Capital Territory who, at the fourth meeting of the Committee on 21 September 1981 as reported on page 55 of the report, moved that the application by Mr Wylie for legal representation could not be granted and he subsequently supported the amendment which said in effect that the application is not granted. As indicated earlier this was a matter which caused grave concern to the Committee. It was the issue which caused the member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) to move the motion, as reported on page 55 of the report, 'That the Committee adjourn its proceedings at this point to seek a directive from the House of Representatives as to House of Parliament in the peror which obstructs or impedes any whether witnesses should be entitled to be represented by counsel in this particular case'. This motion was moved by the honourable member for Hawker because he was concerned that the Committee was bound by precedents set before the establishment of the colony of New South Wales. It would have been better for the Minister for the Capital Territory to have suppoted a reference to the Holise on this issue as moved by the honourable member for Hawker rather than hide behind archaic precedents to justify his view that representation could not be granted to Mr Wylie and his support of the subsequent amendment that representation be not granted. The attempt of the Minister to whitewash himself and blame members of the Committee for defects in the procedures to be followed by it was a sickening performance. The establishment of the joint committee to examine all aspects of parliamentary privilege must now be given the urgent attention of this Parliament. It is a matter which 73 years ago caused the Quick Committee to call for reform and it is a disgrace that we have failed to reform procedures established more than 200 years ago. Question resolved in the affirmative. NA Motion (by Mr Sinclair) agreed to: That leave of absence be given to every member of the House of Representatives from ting of the House to the date of its next sitting. NA Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed: That the House, at its rising. adjourn until Tuesday, 16 February 1982, at 1.45 p.m., by Mr Speaker or, in the event of Mr Speaker being unavailable, by the Chairman of Committees.
