Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Wannon-Prime Minister) (12 midnight)-We come to the end of the parliamentary year for the House of Representatives.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It took a long while to get there.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It might have taken a long while to get there but we got there a little quicker than on other occasions. I think it is important that on these occasions we pay some tribute to those who in unseen and often unheard ways make the working of the Parliament possible. This is the most important institution in the country. We need to understand that the workings of the Parliament are not made possible just by politicians and Ministers but by all those who service this building in many ways and with a great and sincere dedication. Before we leave the House for 1981 I would like to place on record also my appreciation of the work. done by all of those who serve the Parliament. There is the work that you have done, Mr Speaker. The Speaker's role is important. The proper sense of its dignity which you bring is very valuable to this House, especially at those times when members of the House forget in one way or another the sense of dignity that they ought to bring to it. Your humour, your understanding and your patience are, I believe, appreciated by all members of the House, no matter what some members of the House might say at odd moments. The Chairman of Committees, the honourable member for Wide Bay ( Mr Millar) and his deputy chairmen have also a key role in getting through the business of the House. The Clerk of the House and his officers are vital in the smooth running of the House and in being able to give advice to you, Mr Speaker, to your Deputy or to the deputy chairmen. We thank them for the work that they have done over the past year. Their work is in the high traditions of the Parliament and we thank them for it. I refer to the Principal Parliamentary Reporter and his staff. Those of us who have been here a the determination of this sitnumber of years will have noticed the change in his staff over the years. This is just part of a changing scene in Australia. Hansard has a critical role Valedictory in giving the words of honourable members their true and proper sense. I can remember the occasion when the Honourable Norman Makin once made a speech saying that he objected to the unless otherwise called together way in which Hansard altered his words and altered the sense and the meaning of what he had to say. He objected to the way in which Hansard reporters thought they knew better than he did himself what he was trying to say. He made quite a long speech pleading that he just be reported precisely and accurately as he spoke, with no editing, no punctuation other than that which was plain from hisÂ· spoken words. Well, Hansard answered that accurately and precisely. The next time he made a 30 or 40 minute speech-speeches were a little longer in those days-his speech was all one sentence, without any punctuation, without any full stop at the end. I think after that even Norman Makin accepted that Hansard had a role to play in putting our speeches into good order. Mostly the Hansard staff do it without changing the sense. On very rare occasions there is a slight modification to the sense and that can be corrected if there is a need to. The capacity of the Parliamentary Librarian and his staff to marshal information to assist members of parliament is very significant. The staff of the Table Office deals efficiently with a very large volume of requests. The Parliamentary Liaison Officer works closely with both sides of the House to make sure that the business of the House runs smoothly. The Parliamentary Counsel and his staff give legal expression to practical proposals. It is to be hoped they do it in ways that make plain the meaning of the laws that we intend to pass and that do not unnecessarily lead to questioning in the courts of the laws that we pass. Th.ere are those who look after our everyday reqUIrements courteously and efficiently. We in this place are indeed well looked after. There is a degree of dedication in all the staff in this building. I think that that is impressive. I would like also to thank all members of the Ministry and their departments and staffs because they have displayed a great commitment to their tasks over the course of the last year. The issues and the volume of business that have been handled is impressive and much larger than would have been the case in earlier years. The Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) has moved through the business of the House smoothly and efficiently, making possible an earlier adjournment of the House than I suspect he might in his own heart truly wish. I sometimes suspect that the Leader of the House would like to be sitting here on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and Boxing Day. All congratulations go to him for getting us up while it is still November. The Whips, members of the Government parties and their staffs also obviously have a significant role to play in the smooth running of the Parliament, as do the members of the Opposition, their Whips and all who go with them. They are all very much a part of this building and the effective representation of the constituents of each of the members of this Parliament-all the people of Australia. They all make a contribution to the debates and to the workings of the Parliament. I do not want to say much else.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Mr Speaker, the honourable member is not even in his place. He is a stranger in some place where he is not meant to be sitting. I think we can leave this place knowing that - 981 has been a good year for Australia, knowmg that the country has moved ahead. In case members of the Opposition are now feeling slightly nervous, I can assure them that I will not read out for 40 minutes the record of this Government, as one of my predecessors read the record of his Government, because I know the record of this Government is well understood and appreciated and it does not need emphasising at this rather late hour on this particular day. I suspect that it is not exactly a rest that lies ahead-- . Mr Armitage-Stop twitching.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: There is an honourable member whose resignation lies ahead of him very soon. I suppose the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) will go to the Sinai and the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) will go with him. Government members-Ha, Ha!

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: That was a serious comment.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Margaret hasn't told you yet whether you are going.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I know what is going to happen. I would like to thank the honourable member for Wills for his commitment to argue the cause of Australian participation, if it should prove necessary. I thought that was a generous statement after his earlier speeches. I would like to offer all members of this House and their families, all those who serve the Parliament, including the Clerks and those who attend to the daily needs of the members and who make the wor-ings of the whole building possible, a happy Chnstmas and a prosperous New Year. I wish them all a happy time over the holiday period. I would like to give special thanks to those members of the Government parties who have supported me and the Government over the last year. I wish the Opposition all good fortune in' the period ahead of it and wish each of its members a long life in the ranks of the Opposition. Even though Gordon Pike will be here when we come back, I would like to thank him in particular for the work that he has done for many members of parliament over a very long period. He will be remembered for the many services that he has provided .to members of parliament over many years. I do not know how many years it is. Mr Armitage-,-Forty-two years.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It is 42 years. That must be the only accurate thing that the honourable gentleman has said in this House. My acknowledgment that the honoUl:able member could say something accurate is possibly the most charitable remark I have made in the whole year.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Oxley-Leader of the Opposition) (12.11 a.m)-I join in the convention which has been acknowledged by the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) of conveying seasonal greetings to a range of people who servi-e this House and, of course, of expressing goodwill generally. Thank goodness there is one day in every 12 months when this takes place, and with some felicity. For my part, it is a great honour to serve in this Parliament.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: We have been talking quite a lot lately. It is not just one day.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I must say that the familiarity and the geniality with which the Prime Minister has been treating me at Question Time have done me a great deal of harm in my own party. I wish that he would stop.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Mr Speaker, I can afford to do it now that the honourable gentleman's position is secure.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It may well be true, as the Prime Minister observed earlier, that the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) and I will be going to the Sinai together. The Prime Minister's problem is that he cannot find anyone to go to the barricades with him. As I was saying, it is a great honour to serve in this Parliament and a great privilege to serve the people of this community. There are many trials and tribulations for all of us. Many problems confront us in the nature of the service that we seek to discharge as members of parliament, but it is a very satisfying service cause it allows us to make some contribution in one way or another to the community. In that respect, I note that the Prime Minister was being extraordinarily unfair to the honourable or, I suppose it is, right honourable-to what extent he is often right and, even less, to what extent he is honourable is a matter of dispute-the Minister for the Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman). I thought it was very harsh and cruel to discriminate against him. The Prime Minister said that the people who were unseen and unheard made the workings of the Parliament possible. I would have thought that the Minister for the Capital Territory made some contribution but one could never say that he was unseen and, least of all, that he was unheard. The Prime Minister said that on this occasion he would be merciful and not subject us to a 40-minute recantation of the record of Government in the past 12 months. We would have welcomed even four minutes of recantation of the record of the Government in the last 12 months. It is a record about which the Australian public deserves to be reminded. The occasion is such that I shall not explore that point further. As this is a moment of good will, I turn to you, Mr Speaker. You are a man who is loved by all but who, perhaps, is frequently not appreciated. We are disappointed to hear that you are probably about to depart from this chamber to take up an appointment in the service of the community in the State of Victofia on behalf of Her Majesty. We wish you God speed and happy service in that part of Australia. It is not an easy task for you to serve the Parliament. I take the opportunity, should the report that we see in the newspapers be an accurate one and should the appointment take place before. Parliament resumes, of wishing you well there. Apparently the newspaper reports may be correct.

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: You are a bit behind in the news.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: It has been announced.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Has it really?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Oh my God, Mr Speaker, you missed out! I have to say that I am not so happy now that I have found that you have missed out. Once again Malcolm Fraser has let you down. You cannot rely on him. We commend the Hansard staff for the valuable contribution they make here in dissecting, faceting and polishing the priceless gems which we toss their way. Those begems must make their task much easier. The Clerks, of course, we respect highly. Their diaries of the indiscretions of members of parliament are something that they discreetly ensure are never presented to public life. For that we are eternally thankful. It is, I repeat, a privilege to serve in this Parliament. It is sometimes a test of one's fortitude and even more of one's good will and, I suppose, common.Christian values for those among us who are Chri-tians, and for those of us, like myself, who are humanists our humanist values to serve here. For all that I am pleased to have completed my twentieth year in an environment which is always challenging, which is always stimulating and I trust one in which we all seek to the best of our abilities to make a constructive contribution. We are, as the Prime Minister commented, greatly improved in the work we seek to do by the myriad of people who work in this chamber, outside the chamber supporting the people in it and those behind them in places like the Parliamentary Library, which in my view constitutes the sinews and the sort of arterial system that allows Parliament to function properly. I reciprocate the seasonal greetings that the Prime Minister expressed. I reciprocate them in particular in respect of honourable members on the Government side. I sincerely trusUhey have enjoyed the past 12 months in government. The period ahead of them in government is extremely limited. We can assure them that the cushions on this side of the House are waiting to welcome them in the very near future.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Richmond-Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources) (12.17 a.m.)-I would like to join the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) in using this occasion while there is a ceasefire to extend cordial seasonal greetings to all members of this chamber. I wish them a very happy Christmas and a very good New Year. We have performed this little ceremony on many occasions over the years. I suppose to some people it may seem a repetition of expressing appreciation to the many people who make this Parliament perform and fulfil its functions. But all those people give of their very best and so many of them are absolutely devoted to their cause. I thank the members of this House for their very assiduous work within the chamber and on the committees in seeing that the functions of our national Parliament are fully performed. Of course this year we have had a good many new members come into this chamber. For them it is a unique experience. There is nothing like your first year in Parliament. It is always a bit strange. But hope that those who have come here this year will by the end of the year be starting to settle down and will realise that there are certain values. I hope as the days go by they will live up to those values and try to sustain them because if we do not as a group sustain them then the place will fall apart. With those new members we have had the addition of three women to this chamber. Of course that is a great novelty because it is many years since we have had any ladies here. I think it has been very difficult for most of us to refer to them as honourable members rather than honourable gentlemen but we are learning and amending our ways, especially you, Mr Speaker. I notice that you do not make many errors in that respect now. I think the addition of the ladies to the chamber has made a marked improvement to the behaviour of us all. I think we have behaved better this year than we have behaved for many years, and no doubt it is because of the ladies. Apart from the achievements of getting legislation through, time has been spent during the year in expressing our condolences to members of the Parliament who have passed away. During this year two members of the Parliament diedour colleague Eric Robinson and Senator John Knight. Everyone here would like to say that they will be thinking of those families during this Christmas which will be a particularly sad time for them. I will be thinking of them and I am sure everybody else will. Family life is the hardest part of being a member of parliament. It imposes an enormous strain on one's wife and one's children, particularly in these circumstances.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: We, too, sympathise with Margot.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I sympathise very much with your wife, Bill. Mr Speaker, I also express appreciation to you for your unfailing patience and forbearance with the members of this chamber and, I suppose, myself. You have done a very distinguished job, as you normally do. I thank you, the Chairman of Committees and his deputies, the Clerks, the Serjeant-at-Arms, the parliamentary attendants-a multitude of people-and the people up in the Australian Broadcasting Commission who spread our good messages around Australia. I thank them. I thank the members of the Hansard staff who do a remarkable job, as the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) mentioned, in making our speeches legible and intelligent. I thank them very much. I also thank the Parliamentary Library and people like that wonderful institution, Gordon Pike, for whom we all have affection and great reI spect. It goes further afield. I would even like to pay a tribute to the gardeners around Parliament House. I think that they do a tremendous job. I doubt whether anywhere in Australia there is a finer display of roses at the moment than in the parliarnentary gardens. The honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) makes a few comments. We have some finer feelings on this side of the House. It is on occasions like this that we like to display them. The Opposition thinks it has a monopoly even on the roses. I assure it that it has not. Rather than take up the time of the House I again express Christmas greetings to everybody. I hope they re'turn to this Parliament in 1982 in the very best of health having had time to do their electoral chores and also to get themselves fit for another vigorous year of parliamentary activities.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: I would like to make a couple of points. Firstly, I thank the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) for his good wishes to me! Although the patience required from the Chair can be relaxed on this occasion, I must say to the Leader of the Opposition that the dignity of the place is not added to by the lack of sincerity in what he said. The other point I wish to make is that if one speaks of the dignity of the House, one must look at the commencement of the day's sitting. We have petitions presented and the petitions usually last for 10 or more minutes. In the course of that 10 or more minutes it is natural that honourable members preparing for the day's proceedings talk to each other and the level of conversation in the chamber is very high. It is obvious that the petitions are not being listened to. I think that the Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) ought to take action for the House to consider the way in which it ought to dispose of the issue of petitions and not submit the petitions to lack of consideration or the House to lack of dignity. The next point I wish to make is that almost all of the members on occasions hear extracts. from the House of Commons in Westminster, and on occasions even from the United States House of Representatives or from the Canadian House of Commons. It is not possible for the radio media in Australia to play extracts from this chamber. I think that is a matter which should be corrected. My observation, or my hearing of what has been done by the radio stations, is that there is a great deal of responsibility in - he way those extracts are presented. The next point I wish to make is that from my observation the commencement time of the House of Representatives, 1.45 p.m., is a great difficulty not only for honourable members but also for staff. I hope there will be a change in that commencement time which, I am sure, will enable honourable members to conduct their business in the mornings. As we all know, the mornings are fully occupied by us all. Finally, I wish to take the opportunity of saying that a man I have known for the period I have been in Parliament is about to retire. He is Mr Wally Sharpe, a driver who may be known to honourable members. He is about to retire after almost 50 years' service. He will retire before we come back. I join in the general good wishes to all honourable members. I hope they will have a very enjoyable Christmas period with their families. I hope the break will be very good for them all and that we can come back in February with a great deal of compassion and good will, one to the other. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Yes. NOTICE (2) (a) August 1976, (b) August 1978. (3) Separations arise for a number of reasons but a principal factor is career opportunity. For example, a study conducted in December 1980 of all separations of permanent officers from the Legislative Research Service for the period January 1970-December 1980 indicated that, given the limperforited promotion opportunities within that Service, many officers regarded employment within the Department as a stage in a general Public Service career. Of the 50 separations in that period, 31 officers transferred or were promoted to other Departments or authorities, while 16 resigned to take appointments in private industry, academic institutions and so on. There were 3 separations for other reasons, e.g. retirement, death. Over the same period, 27 officers transferred into or were promoted to the Legislative Research Service, while 23 were recruited from private industry, academic institutions etc. Separations cause concern because of limited staffing and existing workloads and because of the delays and expense involved in filling vacancies. As such these can reflect on both efficiency and morale. (4) No study has been conducted on a Department wide' basis. However the above study showed that improved employment prospects for economists particularly and lawyers were an influential factor in total separations between 1977 and December 1980. The difficulties experienced in attracting replacement staff bear out this conclusion. (5) (a) and (b) The matter has been under study and plans have been made for separation interviews to take place in order to provide necessary information. However, a high separation rate appears inevitable given the existing career opportunities. (3) Was the decision to buy the machine based on proposals to relocate (a) all or (b) part of the Legislative Research Service at the former Hotel Kurrajong; if not, on what was it based. (4) Where are the 2 terminals for the machine located in Parliament House and the former Hotel Kurrajong. (5) Who is responsible for the actual operation of the machine at each end. (6) What is the estimated (a) number of sheets which will be transmitted each year and (b) annual operating cost, inclusive of materials, maintenance and staff time.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The decision to acquire a telefacsimile machine was made by the then Parliamentary Librarian and senior officers involved in preparing the Departmental estimates for 1981-82. This was as a result of an undertaking given to a Senate Sub-Committee earlier in the year which was inquiring into accommodation matters. (2) $607 per month per machine. (3) The decision to lease machines was based on two major consider a tions: (i) A requirement to have high speed transfer of documents between Parliament House and the Hotel Kurrajong for the Statistics Group of the Legislative Research Service, Management Services Branch and Systems and Co-ordination Unit, which are all at the Kurrajong Annex. (ii) For some years the Department and the Joint Standing Committee on the Library have been examining systems for high speed transmission of documents between Parliament House and Senators' or Members' electorate offices. Telefacsimile transmission appears to be the most suitable means for achieving this purpose. The present installation will be used to evaluate the suitability of such a service. (4) The telefacsimile machines are located: (i) Room Bl4-Hotel Kurrajong (ii) Photocopy area-Basement-Parliament House (5) At Parliament House the staff in the photocopying area are responsible for sending and receiving copy. At the Kurrajong Annex the person sending the text is responsible for operating the machine. (6) (a) Initially it is expected that the number of sheets to be transmitted will be moderate, with a rapid increase as the capability of the equipment becomes better known. The estimates for the first two years of operations are: Year 1-5,000 sheets Year 2-8,000 sheets (b)Machines-lease plus maintenance, $1214 per month. Consumables-of the order of $0.12 per sheet Staff time-of the order of 2-3 minutes per transaction, i.e. $0.50 per transaction. Consumable and staff time will, therefore, add approximately $3,000 to the machine cost in the first year of operation. Department of the Parliamentary Library On 28 October 1981, Mr Morris asked Mr Speaker: (1) Who initiated the current User Needs Survey of Members and Senators which is being conducted on a random basis by the Parliamentary Library. (2) Was there any consultation the preparation of this survey; if so, what are the details; if not, what is the reason. (3) How many Members and Senators will be surveyed, who are they, and how were they chosen. (4) What is the purpose of ular occurrence. (5) Does the Survey specifically relate to current services offered by the Library. (6) Will the expansion or vices, or the introduction of new services, depend on the results of this survey. (7) What cognisance was taken of both the debate on the Library's appropriation in Senate Estimates Committee A, and the report of that Committee, in the preparation and conduct of this survey. (8) Was the joint Library Committee consulted in the preparation of this Survey. (9) Which Library staff members are responsible for (a) the conduct of the survey and (b) the analysis of its results. (10) Will the results of this survey be made known; if so, in what form and to whom.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable members' question is as follows: (1) The Head, Systems and Co-ordination Unit. The survey was initiated as a basis for considering improvements to existing systems and services. (2) Yes. The HeaJ Librarian nominated staff from the Current Information Section and ALERT service to work on a planning committee. Subsequently advice and assistance was received from the Statistics Group of the Legislative Research Service. (3) Invitations to participate in the survey were sent to 60 Senators and Members. It is hoped that at least 40 will agree to be interviewed. They were chosen using a table of random numbers from a list of all Senators and Members excluding the Presiding Officers and Ministers. All other Senators and Members will receive a copy of the questions and will be asked to respond by mail. Thus all Senators and Members will be included. A list of the Senators and. Members invited to participate in interviews is held by the Acting Parliamentary Librarian. (4) The purpose of the survey is to gather accurate data on the current information needs of Senators and Members for news information and current published material in those areas of public affairs in which they take a special interest and wish to keep up-to-date. Similar surveys have been conducted on two occasions in the past II years and may be conducted at periodic intervals in the future. Future surveys may also focus on different aspects of the Department's services. (5) No. However, the survey is focused on client needs for current awareness services and selective dissemination of information services, both of which are partially covered by existing Library services and are named in the survey questions. (6) The results of the survey will be used to seek to improve the effectiveness of Library services. The availability of resources will affect the rate or direction of change and other factors, for example, the relevance of new technology, will also be taken into account. (7) Views expressed on the provision of news information services and current 1jwareness services were noted. Mr Macphee-The answers to the honourable (Question No. 2643) member's questions are as follows: (1) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs began investigations some time ago. In the light of evidence that some South Korean nationals had, through false representations, obtained visas to travel to Australia and that some, when in Australia had obtained residence by false representations, the investigation was continued by the Australian Federal Police. I understand that the Police investigations are virtually completed but that some action as a result of those investigations remains to be taken. (2) The investigations revealed that some people did not take up employment in the field in which they claimed trade qualifications. More detailed investigations revealed that in some cases those persons did not in fact possess qualifications which would permit them to operate within the claimed trade or craft. (3) Generally the investigations and residence permits had been issued although some of them had been obtained through the use of supporting documents which were false. As a result of Australian Australia a number of persons have been charged with offences and it is expected that laid. One of the prosecutions has been referred to the District date yet to be established. The immigration status of persons who obtained visas and entry permits by false representations will be considered individually. Some of the persons concerned were applicants under the recent Regularisation of Status Program and these are being' considered within the spirit of that Program. National Crimes Commission Mr Jacobi asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 September 1981: (I) Further to my call for the urgent establishment of a National Crimes Commission, has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a recent Press article relating to statements made by Mr Fred Sylvester, Director of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, stating that (a) petty jealousies between State Police crime to gain an increasing national foothold, (b) he had recommended to the Royal Commission the establishment of a Federal Crime Commission, wider powers for his own organisation and more contact with overseas drug and intelligence agencies to allow the Australian Federal Police to fight entrenched organised crime effectively, and (c) organised crime had spread throughout Australia and no individual State could control it. (2) If so, is the Attorney-General sympathetic to these submissions and will he reconsider my repeated request and take immediate steps to implement the detailed recommendations for a Crimes Commission which have been published by the Australian Institute of Criminology and which would incorporate not merely the need for investigation into scandals of this kind but the more practical planning ahead through economic and social measures to reduce the opportunities for organised and white collar crime.

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: (I) A number of the Press reports of the statements referred to in the honourable member's question have been drawn to my attention. (2) As the Attorney-General informed the honourable member earlier this year in reply to Question No. 174 which raised the same point, the Government does not propose to establish a National Crimes Commission in relation to organised crime but rather to tackle identified problems in the area of organised crime with ery, involving the State Governments as appropriate. For example, the Government, in conjunction with the Governments of the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland recently appointed Mr Justice Stewart to be a Royal Commissioner to inquire into a number of matters including the activities of Terrence John Clark and person associated with him and whether those activities involved a contravention of laws of the Commonwealth relating to the importation or possession of drugs. Subsequent events have not provided any reason for the Government to change its revealed that proper entry views on this matter. Another major initiative in the area of combating organised crime has been the establishment by the Commonwealth and State Governments of the Australian Bureau of Criminal InFederal Police inquiries within telligence as a body to gather and disseminate criminal intelligence for all police bodies in Australia. (2) What are the required qualifications for tribunal officials. (3) Are there standard procedures for the assessment of Army Artillery student appeals by tribunals; iF so, what are these procedures; (Question No. 3401 ) if not, on what basis do officials assess an application. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The members of Student Assistance Review Tribunals are not Government officials but part time members chosen largely from the legal and academic communities. The procedure for the establishment of the Tribunals is prescribed by the provisions of the Student Assistance Act 1973 and its regulations. Each Tribunal consists of a Chairman and two members. The Tribunal Chairmen are normal1y selected from former members of the judiciary, the magistry, retired public servants with a background in law and senior academics with legal training. In the case of members, nominations are sought from the principals and registrars of various tertiary institutions including universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE institutions, and in relation to student members, from the Australian Union of Students. (2) Chairmen and members of the Tribunals are expected to be conscious of the needs of students, to be impartial and to be wel1 informed on the provisions of the legislation under which the student assistance schemes operate. (3) The Tribunal procedures are standard to the extent that they are required to follow the Student Assistance Act 1973 and regulations. For example, the Act provides that proceedings be conducted with as little formality and technicality and with as much expedition as possible and consistent with proper consideration of each appeal. The Tribunal is not bound by rules of evidence. Proceedings before a Tribunal are in public unless the Tribunal gives direction to the contrary. The actual form in which the to the Act and regulations, at the discretion of the Chairman and members of the Tribunal. Generally, the appellant personally attends the hearing though he may, if the Tribunal thinks fit, be represented by another person not being a legal practitioner (and the appellant is on occasion accompanied by a member or members of his family). The officer of the Commonwealth Department of Education who was responsible for the decision which is the or is represented. Tribunal members are supplied with copies of the appellant's application for assistance and of correspondence exchanged with the Department of Education relating to the decision under review, prior to the hearing. An appellant may subsequently lodge a submission in writing to the Tribunal if he wishes. In most cases the hearing begins with the Chairman asking the appellant to give a brief account of his case and the officer of the Department of Education who made the decision, or his representative at the hearing, is invited his decision. Tribunal members then follow up any matters which seem relevant in order to gain a clear understanding of the case prior to retiring to come to their decision. (2) Does Australia have access to these photos for either meteorological, agricultural or environmental purposes. Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Yes. NOAA-6and NOAA-7. (2) Yes. The photographs purposes but may have agricultural and environmental applications. The Bureau of Meteorology now usually relies on the Japanese Geostationary Satellite as its source of meteorological satellite pictures over Australia and adjacent oceans. However twice daily pictures are received from each of the NOAA-6 and NOAA-7 satellites and are of great value in preparing meteorological analyses over the southern ocean near the Antarctic continent and the central Indian Ocean. Additional NOAA-6 and NOAA-7 pictures covering the remainder of the southern hemisphere are relayed to the Bureau via theU .S. GOES satellite and are used in preparing hemispheric weather maps. These maps are essential background to the Bureau in preparing its four day forecasts. As well as pictures, information on upper atmosphere temperature is received from the US. satellites via meteorological telecommunications links from Washington and, more recently, from a direct reception station in Melbourne. Mr Milton asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 May 1981: (I) Are shortages of staff and Facilities in Victorian hospitals threatening dialysis treatment for those who need it. (2) Is it a fact that patients over 60 years of age may be refused treatment. (3) If so, will he take action ment from being curtailed. Mr MACKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I), (2) and (3) Under the new health funding arrangements, the Commonwealth provides funding to Victoria for the operating costs of public hospitals, services previously funded under the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme through general revenue grants at the level of funding provided in 1980-81, plus ten per cent, less a share of the revenueÂ· that Victoria can reasonably be expected to raise by the introduction of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges from I September 1981, having regard to the new health insurance arrangements that came into operation on that date. With the revenue increase arising from increased hospital charges, Victoria will have at its disposal increased resources in 1981-82. The Commonwealth is not involved in any decision as to how these resources should be allocated by a State. The matter of priorities is entirely one for Victoria. Therefore, the Victorian Government has the responsibility to determine its own priorities in the delivery of health care and to allocate funds to individual hospitals and related health services in accordance with those priorities. In this context, consideration of the need for additional staff and Facilities for renal dialysis patients in Victoria is a matter solely for the Victorian Government. Sydney, as reported on page 155 of the 'Proceedings of the Second Australian Conference of Health Economists', that (a) a major component of the health insurance industry is in fact insolvent, (b) actual evidence suggests that reserves and provisions need to approximate a minimum of 43 per cent of break-even contribution income to meet liabilities and a solvency margin, (c) there were 12 open funds whose reserves were less than 20 per cent of their breakeven contribution income on 30 June 1979 and (d) there are a further 8 funds including the fourth largest fund in New South Wales and the third largest fund in Victoria whose reserves and provisions are 20-30 per cent of income and which must be regarded as fairly shaky; if so, is there any substance to these statements. Clearly. this was not the case. There is a practical difference between a test of technical solvency COIlsidered by Mr Gadiel to be desirable and the ability of funds, by having.a surplus of assets, to meet claims and other liabilities as they fall due. His test of solvency w-.sthat combined serves and provisions should be equivalen't"io not less than 43 per cent of break-even contribution incollie in order to meet liabilities and to provide a 'solvency margin '. With regard to the reserves component, under present Government policy a level of about two months of break-even contribution income is considered isations and about four months levels alone are equivalent to contributions for large funds In arriving at these ratios, between the needs of financial unnecessary burden on contributors. The other component within the 43 per cent mentioned above is the level of provisions are primarily a matter for determination by each organisation by reference to the estimated level of outstanding claims, long service leave commitments and other liabilities for which provision should be made. Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 20 October 1981: (I) Is it a fact that the total annual output of the construction sector in Australia is approximately $16,000 million; if so, is this equal to the combined value of agriculture and mining. (2) Is it also a fact that total building search, including private, government and industry, amounts to only 0.2 per cent of the total value of output. (3) Does the CSIRO Division of Building Research deal with approximately 40,000 inquiries each year and does it make a very valuable contribution to standards in the construction industry. (4) Does the Government propose to cut back the provisions of building advice as an economy measure. (5) If so, what sum is expected to be saved by this cutback. (6) Will the Government reconsider this decision. Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The value of output of the Australian construction sector obviously depends on the definitions chosen for both 'output' and 'construction sector'. The figure for output can vary widely with the definitions chosen. I am aware that an esti. mate of $16,000 mi!lion in 1978-79 has recently been mentioned. This has been on an extrapolation of figures in the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication 'Australian National Accounts: Input-Output Tables 1974-75'. There are other ways of measuring output, and I would suggest that the most authoritative, widely accepted, and widely used figures are those published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 'Australian National Accounts: National Income and Expenditure'. The most recently published (1981) edition of these Method national accounts gives a provisional figure for 1978-79 (latest available year) for gross domestic product at market prices of Letter the construction industry, of$7,053 million. Telephone The corresponding figures for agriculture (including fores. Letter tery, fishing and hunting), and mining, are $6,481 million and Letter $5,363 million respectively. These together total $12,204 Letter million, or some 73 per cent more than the construction Letter industry. Letter (2) The most reliable source of figures on research expendi3 June 1977 Letter ture in Australia is 'Project SCORE, Research and Development in Australia'. The most recently available, complete figures in this series are for 1976-77, produced by the then Department of Science and the Environment. These show that total funding of reseach and development in the objective category of 'Construction' for that year was $8.089 million. This was 0.13 per cent of gross domestic product at market prices of the construction industry in that year. It should be noted that the level of indigenous Rand D does not depend only on the economic importance of the sector. Research intensity opportunities for research, and use of overseas technology rather than indigenous research, must also be taken into account. (3) No strict account of the number of inquiries received by the Division of Building Research is kept. The Division has, however, estimated that it has dealt with about 40,000 inquiries per year in each of the last few years. About twenty officers of the Division are involved in standards activities; this includes regular meetings with committees of the Standards Association of Australia to develop standards in the areas of building and construction, and the publication and implementation of some of the Division's research results as standards. (4) The Government has no plans to cut back the provision Construction Industry of building advice as an economy measure. The Division of (Question No. 2960) Building Research has itself recently decided to close its own Consumer Information Service in recognition of other services now available, but it is expanding its Industry Liaison Service for architects, engineers, builders and other members of the building industry and allied trades. (5) No estimate is available of the savings to the Division of the termination of the Consumer Information Service, as it occurred at the same time as other organizational rearrangements in the Division, most significantly the expansion of its and construction re- Industry Liaison Service. (6) As noted in (4) above, this was a decision not of the Government but of the Division of Building Research in response to its own perception of its priorities within the overall resource allocation for the Division determined by the CSIRO Executive and the Institute ofIndustrial Technology. Sale of International Airline Tickets (Question No. 3619) Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981: (I) What consideration has his Department given to prohibiting the sale of international airline tickets which do not clearly indicate conditions and restrictions governing travel on the ticket. (2) What action is he able to take to ensure that all restrictions attaching to airline travel being sold are clearly shown on the ticket at the time of sale.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) and (2) In developing its aviation policy the Government has attempted to create an environment responsive to the needs of both consumers and carriers. The basic aim of the policy has been to encourage airlines to provide a comprehensive range of cost related fare and rate types to be available on a non-discriminatory basis. In accordance with this policy, and with the agreement of our bilateral partners, the airlines introduced on our major routes a ra'nge of fare types designed to cater for the different ket. The fares normally range from the flexible on-demand types to which very few conditions attach (First Class, Sleeper, Business Class, Economy) through to the low cost promotional fare types involving more restrictive ticket conditions (Excursion Fares, Advance Purchase Fares, Group Inclusive Fares). With respect to the promotional fare types, the Government, in co-operation with our bilateral partners, Quntas and the designated carriers of the countries involved, have developed arrangements to ensure that intending passengers are adequately advised of important fare conditions that may afl'ect their travel plans. Any advertising for example, must include as a minimum requirement a statement of the advance purchase period and the fact that a cancellation penalty applies. Further, quirement that passengers intending to buy advance purchase fares must not only be advised of the cancellation/refund conditions by the airline/travel agent involved, but a statement to the effect that the total fare is not refundable if not used on the fligh(s)/date(s) shown, must also appear on or be attached to the ticket itselr. In addition, passengers purchasing advance purchase fares must also be advised of the availability of insurance cover, which may assist in guarding against unforseen changes to travel plans. In deciding whether or not to impose special consumer warning notices on tickets my Department has had to balance the consumer interest against the legitimate need of the industry to minimise airline and travel agent administrative costs. It should also be noted affect the consumer interest through their impact on fare levels. It would appear, from information available to the Department of Transport, however that consumers have readily accepted the more restrictive conditions types in exchange for lower cost travel. The method Fol5,000 lowed in the calculation of the estimates is in accordance with that used For the preparation of the data on the proportion of 43,000 38,000 total company income payable overseas that were released on 31 March 1980 (Press Release by the Treasurer, No. 35). 46,000 The estimates are subject to the qualifications noted in that press release. In particular, it should be noted that the proportion of total company income payable overseas is not a reliable measure of the extent of Foreign participation in the economy. It is subject to a good deal of short-term fluctuation and apparent trends may be subject to reversal as revised and more recent data become available. Moreover, the proportion, apart From being calculated From data that are subject to problems of statistical estimation, is affected by various influences in addition to the level of Foreign ownership. These include any tendency for the profitability of Foreigncontrolled enterprises to differ From that of Australiancontrolled enterprises and For the profitability and taxation payments of sectors in which foreign ownership is relatively $ high to vary relative to other sectors. For these reasons, great care should be taken in drawing any conclusions relating to foreign participation from the data. In addition to these general qualifications, it should be noted that some of the data required for the calculations of the proportions of company income payable overseas in respect of the mining, manuFacturi ng and finance sectors were not available, with the result that certain assumptions and ap...... 55,000 proximations had to be made. A major qualification to the proportions for these sectors is that the estimates of income 45,000 payable overseas are derived from data For groups of related enterprises classified according Classification of Industries, whereas the estimates of total company income relate generally to single enterprises classified according to the Australian Standard Industrial Classification. Hence, the reliability of the estimates for the industry sectors shown in the table is severely levels and year to year movements in the proportions, by the lack of consistency on an industry basis between the income payable overseas data and the total company income data, and also by the assumptions and approximations that have had to be made. The following notes regarding portions of company income payable overseas should also be taken into account when interpreting the data shown in the table: (i) In order to derive the proportion of total company income payable overseas, withholding tax has been added to the income payable overseas data. (Although withholding tax reduces the income received by the foreign owners of Australian businesses, it is the amount of income generated by these businesses, rather than the amount payable to their owners, that is relevant for the purpose of obtaining an indication of the share of foreign investors in total company income.) It was not, however, possible to make this adjustment in respect of the data for the industry sectors. (ii) Information is not available to permit the proportions for the mining and manufacturing industries to be estimated using numerators consistent with the denominators in that the denominators do not include dividends received. (iii) The data used for tax payable by mining companies and manufacturing companies were approximations and included estimated adjustments for late assessments. (iv) The estimated company income after tax of financial enterprises included data relating to institutions engaged mainly in financing. Data relating to companies engaged in financial service activities (eg stock or commodity exchanges, financial consultants or brokers) were not included. (v) The company income data used to derive the proportions in the table are before deducting any allowance for stock valuation adjustment (this is a measure of the 'paper profits' rising prices). This ensures that both the company income and the income payable overseas data are valued in the same way. Redevelopment of Brisbane Airport: Effect on Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on Â·27 August 1981: (I) What is the location of any fish or prawn trawling, breeding and/or feeding grounds which will be lost or adversely affected as a result of dredging or pumping of sand from Moreton Bay, Queensland, in association with the redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport. (2) Have any investigations been carried out to ascertain whether new trawling and fishing grounds can be opened up to compensate for those lost. Mr MCVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The likely effects of Airport construction on both the Middle Banks in Moreton Bay and the existing Serpentine Creek system were examined by the Brisbane Airport Environment Study Committee between 1972 and 1979. The work of this Committee formed the basis of the Environmental Impact Statement prepared in 1979 and on which public comment was invited and considered. Further studies have continued since 1'979 and are continuing at the present time. The study showed that the Middle Banks were generally devoid of marine vegetation and supported very little fish life. The presence of fish in the and it is not expected that dredging will result in more than a passing interference in fish occurrence. Full recovery of bottom dwelling sealife is also expected within 12-18 months of termination of dredging. A total loss of fish and prawn habitat will occur in the sections of Serpentine Creek that are to be reclaimed. Studies have shown, however, that the Creek is not an important nursery area for bream or whiting although studies on other species have been inconclusive. The new flood canal may prove to have potential for fish breeding and feeding grounds as observations to date indicate that it has attraction for fish. Removal of the mangrove areas in Serpentine Creek will reduce the amount of suitable Bay region for post larvae and to estuarine areas after hatching in oceanic waters. However, relative to the total estuarine areas available, this loss is likely to be insignificant and the Moreton Bay prawn crops are likely to be affected only to a small extent. The reclamation of Serpentine Creek and diversion of flows to the flood canal may change the distribution of the bottom dwelling sealife in Bramble Bay, but the effects are expected to be minor compared with those major flood. The reclamation works on Boggy Creek in the Brisbane River are unlikely to have any more effects upon the ecology of the area than do the regular dredging of the shipping channels or the flood flows in the Brisbane River. (2) This is a matter for the Queensland State Government and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has advised that no new trawling and fishing grounds are available to be opened up. (2) Is it more common in the Northern Territory for the community itself to administer its own housing project funds and generally employ a housing manager who lives and works in the community on a full time basis. payments direct to accounts (3) In the Northern Territory does his Department give services to housing programs such as technical advisers and work evaluations free of charge. (4) In Western Australian communities does his Department charge, on average, about 11 per cent of the communities' housing budgets for the services of his Department. (5) What is the comparative cost of an employee being based in Perth and spending eight weeks at a time in a community compared with the cost of having a resident housing manager in the community. (6) Does his Department recruit housing managers for the Aboriginal housing programs in Western Australia directly from the Department or does nal employment section of the Commonwealth Employment Service. Mr MCVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Yes, in those instances where housing projects are of more than approximately three months duration and are located in remote areas where there are no appropriate facilities for construction staff. (2) Yes. Some larger communities employ a full-time housing manager. Other communities employ a community adviser, part of whose' duties stances a Mission or Council administers housing funds on behalf of communities. (3) Fees are charged for design and construction services. Fees are not charged for feasibility studies, technical advice, programming assistance or estimates provided for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission or for similar advisory support provided at the request of communities. (4) No. Fees vary according to services provided and are based on minimum commercial scales less rebate for repetitive work. A typical fee for procurement, supervision and construction consultancy is 6.8 per cent. Direct project charges are levied at cost. (5) The Department does not employ resident community housing managers and comparative figures are not available. (6) The Department does not recruit or employ housing managers for Aboriginal communities or Aboriginal housing programs. When skilled on-site foremen are needed they are either provided from the Department's workforce or recruited locally. Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme Means Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 October 1981: (I) With regard to the Commonwealth Government Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) for, ordinary students, what are the criteria (a) by which the Government establishes the nominated maximum level of adjusted family income below which ordinary students can obtain the maximum rate of living allowance and (b) for establishing the nominated reduction rate of $2.50 for every $10 of income, where the adjusted family income exceeds $10,312. (2) With regard to the Commonwealth Government TEAS for independent students, plied to student's income for why is the means test not applied income at the time of commencement of studies, (c) what is the reason for the difference in allowance applied to an ordinary student's family income and to independent students spouse's income, (d) how many students who applied for TEAS allowance were refused the allowance on the basis of means test provisions since the introduction of the means test and (e) how many students receiving a TEAS allowance withdrew as a result of financial difficulties. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) As regards 'ordinary' students under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS)(a) The level of adjusted family income at which maximum TEAS benefits are provided at the 'at-home' and 'away-from-home' rates (which is known as Marginal Adjusted Family Income or MAFI) is reviewed annually in the Budget context. The Government considers movements in average weekly earnings as well as its overall commitment in programs generally. (b) The principle of a gradually tapered means test is long standing; whilst administratively more complex it avoids the obvious inequities arising for exafTlple from a system based on income nothing system. The abatement rate of $2.50 in allowance for every $10 by which the adjusted family income exceeds the MAFI has applied since 1977 and permits support to students over a relatively wide range of parental incomes. (2) As regards students granted independent status under TEAS(a) and (b) The means test on the student's income is in fact applied to income during the year of study and not, as the question suggests, to income for the previous financial year. It would not be realistic to means test the student's own income on the basis of the preceding year when in some cases his or her income will be of a very different order during the year of study; on the other hand, parental income is means tested on the basis of the preceding year, since that year's income is verifiable and can reasonably be assumed to be ongoing at a broadly comparable level. (c) The abatement rate applied to the income of the independent' student's spouse, by which the allowance is reduced at the rate of $1 for every $2 by which the adjusted spouse income exceeds the MAFI, provides a less gradual taper than does' the abatement rate on family income in the case of the 'ordinary' student. The respective abatement rates take account of assumptions about the income of the family unit and Test the demands assumed to be placed upon it in the case of an 'ordinary' student; account is also taken of the (Question No. 3429) range of other benefits or concess'ions available to the different types of TEAS beneficiary. (d) Information is not readily available on the numbers of students, since the introduction of the TEAS means test in 1974, whose applications for TEAS allowances were refused on the basis of the means test provisions; and (e) Similarly, information is not available on the number of students who were in receipt of a TEAS allowance and subsequently withdrew, whose withdrawal was as a result of financial difficulties. However, J refer the honourable member to the 1979 Survey of Full-time Tertiary Student Finances (Volume 2) which was tabled on 14 October 1981, which in Chapter 3 (page (a) why is the means test ap31) discusses the reasons why students discontinue the previous financial year, (b) full-time studies. It should be noted that the sample into an applicant's available volved in the survey, which related to universities and colleges of advanced education only, was concerned between proportional reductions with full-time students generally, and that of the respondents, 41 per cent were in receipt of TEAS. Quarantine Inspection of Imported Goods Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: Have systematic additional random inspections to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of quarantine inspection of imported goods been carried out as recommended in the report entitled 'Review of Australian Quarantine Arrangements' prepared by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in 1976; if so, what were the results of inspections. Mr Mackellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: My Department has advised that the recommendation referred to was not taken up because it became apparent, after careful consideration, that quarantine screening and other procedures for imported goods did not lend themselves to the systematic, randomly based evaluation techniques proposed. As indicated in the recommendation referred to, the quarantine arrangements applying to goods imported into Australia are self regulating to an extent. Quarantine procedures for particular goods from different countries are determined in the light of assessments of the pest and disease risks which these goods present. significance are located during routine or random inspections which are not already catered for, appropriate corrective measures are taken immediately to meet any perceived risk. These measures may involve mandatory treatments, new or increased levels of inspection for particular the emphasis of quarantine screening arrangements. Where inspections indicate, for example, inaccuracies in documentation, goods of similar origin are subject to particular attention in the future. This approach ensures that quarantine procedures are in effect, subject to continuous review and as far as practicable, kept up to date with quarantine needs. Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April1981: (I) Is Australia and its territories currently free of (a) scrapie, (b) anthrax, (c) Newcastle, (d) rabies, (e) blue tongue and (f) foot and mouth diseases. (2) If not, what incidents or outbreaks of each disease have been reported during the last three years, and what was the source of the infection in each case. (3) If Australia is free of each disease, fection of each in Australia or its territories reported. Mr MACKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Australia is free from scrapie, rabies and foot and mouth disease. However anthrax, and avirulent strains of Newcastle disease virus and bluetongue virus have been reported here. (2) The following diseases or disease agents have been reported in Australia during the past three years. Newcastle disease-An avirulent Newcastle disease virus was first isolated in 1965 and is still present in Australian birds. This virus does not cause clinical disease. The source of the virus is not known. Bluetongue-Several isolations of viruses which, by definition, fall within the bluetongue group have been made in Australia. None has been demonstrated to cause clinical disease. The sources of these viruses are unknown but from serological evidence it appears that some have been in Australia for many years. Anthrax-Anthrax is believed to have made its first appearance in New South Wales about 1847. It is currently confined to isolated areas of New South Wales and Victoria. (3) The following diseases have been reported or suspected in Australia in the past but have not been reported within the past three years. Scrapie-Scrapie was diagnosed in 1952 in a small flock of Suffolk sheep imported from the United Kingdom twelve months earlier. The sheep and their progeny and all in-contact sheep were slaughtered and the area left unstocked for twelve months. It has not recurred in Australia. Rabies-In Hobart in February 1867 a boy died 29 days after being bitten on the lip by a dog. Opinions expressed at the time indicated that several rabies had occurred in dogs, and at least one pig, in the area.The affected animals were destroyed and a clean up of stray dogs was carried out by the local Municipal Council. Reports published at the time leave little doubt that the disease was rabies. In 1883 a health officer in New South Wales reported several instances in which dogs presented the symptoms of rabies. No human case was reported and no later reports were made. Foot and mouth disease-The only certain occurrence of foot and mouth disease in Australia was an outbreak in'Victoria in 1872 following the importation of eight bulls from England. The diagnosis was confirmed by several veterinary Quantity surgeons. The outbreak was confined to two properties and was successfully eradicated by slaughter. 170 3 Trade Practices Act 2 (Question No. 1950) Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981: Animal Diseases (I) Further to the report of the Trade Practices Consulta(Question No. 1726) tive Committee on the operation of the Trade Practices Act in relation to primary production in Australia, is it a fact that the Consultative Committee's case against the Banana Growers Federation was adjourned following a statutory direction to the Commission by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs on IS September 1978. Hospital Bed Days: Alcohol-related Illness Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 September 1981: (I) What is the estimated number of hospital bed days and the cost of this hospitalisation due to alcohol-related illness and injury and as a proportion of total bed days and costs. (2) Are there any other estimated health costs to the country of alcohol-related illness and injury, for example, days lost through sickness. (3) Are there any other related figures available on this problem, for example, prison admissions, etc. Mr MACKellar-The honourable member will be aware that State health authorities do not routinely collect data on alcohol-related illness and injuries in morbidity data. However, in an effort to assist the honourable member as fully as possible, I have been advised that the following estimates are believed to be indicative: (I) A. T. Williams, F. Harding Burns, and S. Morey, in their paper, 'Prevelance of Alcoholism in a Sydney Teaching Hospital', Medical Journal of Australia, 1978,2,608-611, and C. M. Peterson's 'Inpatient population and alcohol abuse', St Vincents Hospital Sydney, 1977-78, unpublished, suggested that in the order beds may be filled with persons suffering from alcohol-related illnesses. Based on information available from public psychiatric hospitals, about 15 per cent or so of beds, not occupied by mentally retarded patients, appear to be used by people with a diagnosis of alcoholism mate does not allow for those who are additionally treated by special institutions for people with alcohol-related problems or private institutions. Extrapolation of these figures would indicate that between 2 million and 3 million public hospital bed days per annum could be involved in caring for people with alcohol-related problems. This would indicate $220 to $300 million in public acute hospitals for 1977-78. (2) There are no reliable estimates of the cost to the community of working days lost or injury. The NH & MRC estimated that, in 1972, the loss of potential earnings through premature deaths associated with alcohol was approximately $120 million per annum and the cost of alcohol-related traffic accidents was about $500 million annually (in 1972 terms). L. Halchenko (Costs of Alcoholism in Industry in Australia, 1974-75, AFADD) estimated that, in 1975, alcohol related absenteeism cost industry $46 million each year. (3) No studies have been made to enable an accurate estimate of the cost of alcohol-related crime to the community to be calculated. Evidence available from E. Oits, The Relationship between Alcohol and Violent Crime', Roneoed Material Chief Secretary's Office, Victorian Government; B. Roslund and C. Larson, 'Crimes of Violence and Alcohol Abuse in Sweden', International Journal of Addictions, 14, 8, 1103-1115, 1979; and N. Parker, 'Murderers'; a personal series', Medical Journal of Australia, 1,36-39,1979, suggests at least half, and possibly 75 per cent, of all violent crime is associated with alcohol use. L. H. Title: ZZZZZ

Brisbane Airport: Air Traffic Control Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 22 September 1981: (I) Can he say whether the closure of the Brisbane Airport due to air traffic control problems has halted a $30m resort development in the Whitsunday area, Queensland. (2) If so, can he also say whether the mainland resort developers have halted the project tion of the effects on other areas in Queensland caused by the closure of the Brisbane Airport. (3) What will be the effect a result of the Brisbane Airport temporary closure. (4) What action has he taken to immediately resolve the situation caused by a shortage of air traffic controllers.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No-indeed there is no total closure of Brisbane Airport but there is a limited closure from 9 pm to midnight daily which has had minimal effect on scheduled services to and from Brisbane Airport. (2) Not applicable. (3) There are no jet airline operations scheduled to depart to or from Brisbane or any of the Queensland coastal airports later than 9 pm and these are therefore unaffected by the 9 pm closure of Brisbane's airport. (4) Action was initiated in 1979 to recruit air traffic control trainees to the maximum capacity of the training college. Between 110 and 120 trainees have been recruited each year since 1979. Because the training course takes three years for the bulk of these trainees, the benefit from this recruitment action will not be felt until late 1981 jearly 1982. It is anticipated that there will be an improving situation from this time onwards. On the specific problem at Brisbane arising from the acute shortage of controllers in Queensland, my Department has now transferred 17 permanent and seven temporary controllers to Queensland. These transferees, once trained, will release other controllers for training in the terminal area positions and so enable the airport to resume normal operations. My Department anticipates that this training will be completed early next year. Department of Defence: Severance Pay Mr ScholesÂ· asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 October 1981: (I) Does his Department withhold proportion of severance pay entitlements at the time of discharge (2) If so, what is the purpose of withholding these funds and for what period are they retained by his Department. (3) Is interest paid on funds of former service personnel withheld for his Department's convenience. (4) Does any legal authority exist for the retention of moneys properly belonging to the former servicemen. (5) If the withholding of tory authority, what redress is available to service personnel. Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Certain entitlements such as pay-in-lieu of recreation leave and furlough do not become due until after the member is discharged. However, on the day of discharge, members are advanced 80 per cent of their and normally, payment of their pay-in-lieu of furlough entitlement less $200 is effected (2) The Defence Force Pay systems whilst allowing for payment and some calculation of entitlements at unit level, are largely centralised and computer based. Variations to members entitlements are processed through the Defence Force Pay Accounting Centre in Melbourne which is also charged with final reconciliation of members accounts. Experience over many years has shown that errors do occur in calculations and can only be identified when all of the members records are brought together and reconciled. These records include details of leave entitlements. and amounts recoverable from the member which can be incurred up to and on the day of discharge. The current practice was standardized in August 1979 and was generally an improvement on previous procedures. Ex-members normally receive the balance of their pay in lieu of leave and furlough entitlements within three to four weeks of discharge. (3) No. (4) Advice from the Crown Solicitor's Office indicates the need for the Department to reconcile the accounts of retiring members and pay moneys due to them on retirement or as soon as possible thereafter. Reconciliation which is the basis of the current procedures, is necessary to ensure the correct 'and proper use of public funds. (5) Redress through the Civil Courts is available to ex-members. However, an examination of current procedures is in progress with the aim of reducing the time taken to reconcile the pay accounts. Review of Commonwealth Functions: Effect on Commissioner for Employees' Compensation Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981: (I) Is it a fact that delays of up to six perienced by the Office of Compensation in the processing of claims for compensation. (2) In what way has this office been affected by the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions. (3) Is it a fact that the of Review have caused or contributed to the delay; if not, what other factors have caused the delay.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation has informed me that no statistics are kept regarding the specific length of time each individual case takes to be processed in the Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation (OCEC). However, in the light of complaints about delays received from various sources, e.g., members of the Parlia, ment, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Commissioner acknowledges that it is a fact that, despite attempts to improve the situation, delays of up to six months have occurred in the determination of claims under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 ('the Compensation Act'). Measures ation included: increasing the number of delegates outside OCEC and widening the scope of the delegations; the introduction of revised procedures in OCEC, together with the working of considerable overtime; and the provision, this year, of some additional staff and an increase of 5 in staff ceiling. (2) In the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government decided that, in the interests of efficiency, effectiveness and rationalisation in relation to the administration of the Compensation Act and OCEC operations, two ,measures should be introduced. These decisions and their effects are: (a) the introduction, with effect from I July 1981, of a new appeal forum, namely, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in lieu of the review procedures previously operating. Some increase in the work load associated with the review of determinations has resulted and the provision of additional staff resources in this area of OCEC is under consideration; and (b) the other decision was that the operations of OCEC be expanded in the Australian Capital Territory and extended to the States to take over work currently performed on OCEC's behalf by Commonwealth Departments and Authorities. Implementation of this decision is in the preliminary stages with work being carried out on the evaluation of systems and resources required. This in itself has not led to any disruption to the claims processing work in OCEC. (3) No. The processing of claims has not been adversely affected. It is expected that, when implemented, the revised system of administration of the Compensation Act will minimise delays. The Commissioner has reported his views on the factors causing delays in his Annual Report for 1980-81. Brisbane Airport: Retention of Flight Path Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 October 1981: (I) Will he instruct the Brisbane Airport authorities to retain information concerning flight paths at that airport for a longer period than the present holding period of 30 days. (2) Would retention of this information over a period of several years enable Departmental personnel, as well as the public, to compare and contrast air traffic patterns over the Brisbane metropolitan area. (3) What is the reason for holding this information no longer than 30 days.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) No. The retention of flight strip records for a period of 30 days is sufficient for routine statistical and investigational purposes. The retention of these of 30 days is arranged from time to time to assist in special studies. (2) Yes, but to store and extract the information would require very large resources which would not be commensurate with the benefit gained. The new radar display to be ordered by my Department will permit automatic storage and analysis of data over long periods. (3) The standard contained in an Annex to the Convention of International Civil Aviation requires such records to be held for a minimum of 30 days. Up to approximately 1978, these records were maintained by my Department for a period of 90 days. This period was reduced to 30 days after a twelve month trial, bearing in mind that special holding arrangements are made for special studies.
