Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) In 1980-81, $6.25m was provided by way of grants to the States for land transport planning and research. This program has been discontinued as from 30 June 1981. However, the Commonwealth is providing $2.42m in 1981-82 as direct assistance to the Australian Road Research Board (ARRB) and the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation (ARRDO) in lieu of Commonwealth assistance previously provided through the States under the transport planning and research grants. Commonwealth grants to ARRB and ARRDO in 1981-82 are in total 61 per cent less in money terms than the amount provided in grants to States for transport planning and research in .1980-81. There is no specific index for planning and research expenditure in (2) and (3) The Government is confining its assistance for transport planning and research to programs which are of national significance. Title: ZZZZZ
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics publishes a quarterly analysis of industrial disputes according to duration, cause, method of settlement, analysis by number of workers involved and analysis by total working days lost. The statistics of causes of industrial disputes are classified under the following headings: wages, hours or work, leave, pensions, compen(Question No. 3589) sation provisions, managerial policy, physical working conditions, trade unionism and other. . There is no separate breakdown by employer-employee nor demarcation classification. However managerial policy is defined as disputes concerning the managerial policy of employers and this classification would embrace employeremployee disputes. Similarly there is no separate classification of demarcation disputes but inter-union and intra union disputes are included under the classification of trade unionism along with employment of non-unionists, sympathy stoppages in support of employees in !lI1other industry, recognition of union activities, etc. The. (2) The Waterside Workers' Award contains, at clause 28, a detailed dispute settlement procedure. A feature of that procedure involves the operation of a Port Conciliator Service whereby, if agreement does not arise between the employers and the Federation, the parties may exercise a right to involve a Port Conciliator to reconcile purpose, the Port Conciliator may make a recommendation or, where the parties mutually agree, arbitrate on the matler. The operation of the Port Conciliator a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The establishment of the Port Conciliator service was entered into by the AEWL and the WWF at the time of the rationalisation of the industry in 1977. A number of awards covering front activities contain disputes settlement procedures ego the Australian Foreman Stevedores Association, the Federated Clerks Union and the Federated Storemen and Packers Union. In addition some other unions have written into the awards to which they are parties specific grievance procedures and/or provision for the appointment of Boards of Reference to resolve disputes. (3) Unions, other than the WWF, with members employed in the stevedoring industry include: Australian Stevedoring Federated Clerks Union (FCU). Australian Foremen Stevedores Association (AFSA). Australian Shipping Officers Association (ASOA). Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association (FEDFA). Federated Storeman and Packers Union (FSPU). Transport Workers Union (TWU). Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union (AMWSU). Federated Iron workers Association (FIA). Electrical Trade Union (ETU). Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union (FMWU). Australian Workers Union (AWU). Australasian Society of Engineers (ASE). Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU). (4) Since December 1977, the Department of Transport has published monthly reports of manhours lost by operational employees of stevedoring disputes. The DOT statistics are compiled from returns submitted by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour and by stevedoring companies. They measure manhours lost by operations employees of stevedoring companies directly or indirectly involved in disputes. The statistics do not reveal time lost in the industry occasioned by industrial action by union members not employed by stevedoring companies. (5) The Government supports the adoptions of disputes settlement procedures by recognises that it is for the parties rectly involved to determine what is most appropriate for particular areas. I am aware that stevedoring employers are at present exploring ways to improve the various dispute settlement procedures operting under awards and agreements in the industry. Any extension rangements involving waterfront employers and the WWF is a matter for the parties concerned and judgment as to the advantages or disadvantages rest with them. (6) The advantage of an industry-based union on the waterfront include a likely diminution in interunion disputes, the possibility of a more orderly ease and more effective consultation. There are no obvious disadvantages associated with an industry-based union for the waterfront. (7) It is the policy of the mation of industry-based unions. I note also that the ACTU supports the establishment of industry-based unions. In consultation with industry, employer and union interests, the Government is actively encouraging acceptance of this policy and it will continue to examine legislative measures to ensure consistency with its policy objective. the matlers in dispute. Community Agencies: Grants-in-aid Scheme of research priorities, conse(Question No. 3632) Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic A"ffairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981: (Question No. 3629) (I) Has his attention been drawn to the dire financial situation that community agencies funded through the Grants-inAid scheme find themselves in as a result of various awards such as the recently gazetted charitable institutions professional staff social workers a ward. (2) Will the Government change the funding arrangement of the Grants-in-Aid scheme from a subsidy grant to a total grant covering award rates in States and Territories where they are applicable. (3) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that the smaller ethnic communities which have few resources, such as the Armenians, Finns, Afghans, Koreans, Pacific Islanders and Romanians, receive no funding as these groups are not covered by existing departmental services, either at State or Commonwealth levels. service will continue to be proMr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) I am aware of the implications of the various awards under which Grant-in-Aid workers are employed and of the financial pressures that agencies are experiencing as a result of recent salary increases. (2) The Galbally Report formulation for the Grant-in-Aid scheme specifies that funding provided under the scheme is designed to subsidise the employment of social welfare workers through community agencies. It was not intended that grants should meet all the costs incurred by organisations in employing workers. An important feature of Grants-in-Aid is the stimulus given to sponsoring agencies to develop the appropriate resources to attract and maintain grants. Self-help was one of the key principles contained in the Galbally Rec port. The wish of communities to contribute to welfare service delivery, both financially and through their skills and manpower, should not be underestimated. (3) It is the policy of the Government to help small emerging ethnic groups who may find Grants-in-Aid. For this reason, a number of grants have been made to generalist social welfare agencies such as the Red Cross, St Vincent de Paul, Care organisations to provide services to such groups. There are over 100 different ethnic groups in our multicultural society, and the locations and concentrations of these groups vary. While it has been possible to fund some small ethnic communities directly, it is not possible to cater for all nationalities in all areas through the provision of specific workers. The Grant-in-Aid scheme is only one component of a total welfare strategy for addressing the needs of migrant communities. The migrant services units and the Telephone Interpreter Service within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs play and important role, as do State and community welfare agencies. Migrants: Information Needs Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981: Is he able to say what steps have been taken by Commonwealth Departments following the recommendations of the Scott Survey for the information he provide detai Is. Mr MACPhee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: When tabling the summary of findings on 28 August 1980, I noted that the Survey of Information Needs of Migrants had produced findings and data of relevance to information delivery at all levels in the Australian community. Accordingly, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs distributed some 1000 copies of the full report and 1200 copies of the summary of findings to a wide range of Commonwealth, State, community and private organisations with responsibilities which included delivery of services to the migrant communities. A further 1000 copies of the full report and ies of the summary findings have been purchased through the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops. The major changes in information delivery within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs following the survey have been: (i) revision and simplification of information material produced for prospective migrants overseas. (ii) introduction of group counselling for prospective migrants. (iii) the production of specialised migrant counselling overseas. (iv) the use of Bilingual radio stations, changes to policy and to provide information on available services. A special task force of the Ethnic Liaison Officer Scheme has examined the report to identify its implications for Commonwealth agencies. Since the completion of the report, changes in the Commonwealth Government agencies' approaches to information delivery have included: (i) greater use of multilingual publications about facilities, services and obligations. (ii) greater emphasis on ethnic media for Government advertising. (iii) greater attention to relaying Ministerial and Departmental announcements to the ethnic press. it difficult to seek and manage Migrant Resource Centres (Question No. 3635) Force and a variety of church Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that without appropriate funding for migrant resource centres, hostility could be created at the local level since agencies and communities will have to compete with each other for scarce voluntary and financial resources. Mr Thomson-On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 2460) Mr Barry Jones asked a question of the Prime Minister concerning the generation of power by hydrogen fusion induced by laser excitation. I advised that I would take the question on notice. The Australian Research Grants Scheme of my Department has supported Professor Hora of the University of New South Wales to carry out basic theoretical research in this field. He is examining the interaction of lasers with plasmas and has received a total of $109,271 for his research over the past five years. Fusion research falls within the responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for National Development and Energy, whose Department has provided the following statement: The Government is aware of experiments being carried out in the USA on inertial confinement fusion methods which include laser induced fusion. The complexity of both these and magnetic confinement systems which include tokamaks is such that they are still in the phase of proving technical feasibility. It is evident, however, that both will be complex systems, physically large and with Commercially viable systems will necessarily require development over a long-span of years, making it difficult at this time to predict what ot her energy sources they might replace. The Government is supporting some research in Australia on both the inertial and the magnetic confinement methods for producing nuclear fusion. In addition, Australian membership of the International Fusion Research Council provides the opportunity to keep up to date with overseas developments. Class 5, $16874/18246. Unemployment Benefit: Means Test (Question No. 2790) Teacher Education Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing (Question No. 2746) the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981: (I) Is it a fact that the Victorian State Liberal Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation has urged the Commonwealth Government to lift the ceiling on all allowable extra earnings, that is, the means test, for those receiving unemployment benefits, and has called on the Government to increase unemployment benefits in line with consumer price index increases. (2) If so, is he able to say whether the Victorian Minister's suggestions were made following a Victorian State Government report on youth homelessness. (3) Has he seen the report. (4) If so, did the report indicate that by increasing unemployment benefit and easing the means test, the social and psychological consequences of long term unemployment would be relieved, and young .people could be provided with vital work experience as well as promoting individual initiative. (5) Will the Minister consider these proposals of his Liberal colleague in the Victorian Parliament.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) to (3) In releasing a report prepared by five Victorian Government Departments for the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, the Victorian Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation did urge the Commonwealth to review unemployment benefits and bring them into line with movements in the Consumer Price Index. He also recommended an easing in the income test on these benefits. (4) The report identifies many factors as contributing to the homeless status of young people in Victoria, and states that the causes can be expected to be complex, inter-related and mutually compounding. Inadequate finance was identified as the only one of a set of contributing factors. cluded the state of the housing family breakdown and social problems affecting young people. (5) Unemployment benefit rates are 'currently automatically indexed for price movements except for the single people aged 16 years to 17 years and aged 18 and over without dependants, although the latter rate was increased in November 1981 in line with the increases in indexed rates over the last year. Factors that need to be taken into account about proposals to index all unemployment benefit rates and to further relax the income test include the incentives to undertake full-time work or further education, or increase incentives to leave the parental home. The Government has a continuing concern with the problems of youth homelessness, and gives careful consideration to proposals aimed at alleviating such problems that are put before it. All proposals must be considered in the light of the Government's overall economic objectives and with regard to competing priorities in the welfare field. Video Access Centres thllt the Victorian boundary (Question No, 3312) Mr Holding asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 14 October 1981: (1) When were the Video Access Centres in Carlton, Footscray and Williamstown, Vic., opened, and by whom were they opened. (2) How many staff were employed at that time in each centre. (3) When was each centre closed and what was the reason for the closure in each case. (4) How many staff were employed at each centre at the time of clsure. (5) Was any attempt made to provide alternative employment for staff with technical expertise; if so, what are the details. Mr Wilson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: I am informed by the Australian Film Commission that: (I) The video centres at Carlton and Footscray were opened in the first half of 1974 by the Australian Film Institute, acting on behalf of the Film, Radio, and Television Board of the Australia Council. had become autonomous incorporated bodies funded by grants from the Australian Film Commission. Carlton Video Centre became the Melbourne Access Video and Media Cooperative and subsequently moved to premises in Fitzroy. The Footscray centre merged with a centre in Altona into the Western Communications Co-operative and the premises . moved to Williamstown and subsequently to Newport. (2) At the time of opening, the video centres at Carlton, Footscray and Altona each employed two full-time staff, as well as part-time paid assistants. (3) Western Communications at Newport closed in July 1981 as a result of a decision continue funding to small video access centres. The centre at Fitzroy is still in operation, with support from the Film Commission. (4) At the time of closure the Western Communications Co-operative had a staff of two full-time employees. (5) The Commission has received advice that the two full time employees of the Western Communications Cooperative have obtained employment with a Television Station in Melbourne. (2) How many of these raids were carried out in the Melton, Deer Park, Laverton and Werribee areas in each year. (3) How many (a) raids were carried out in the same areas on 31 May 1980 and I June 1980, and (b) premises were raided and on how many premises were drugs found. (4) Were any of the raids conducted on the wrong premises due to incorrect addresses being given to the officers concern; if so, have apologies been provided to the occupants and if no apologies have been made, what is the reason. Education: Capital Grants to Government Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981: (I) What were the Government's reasons for rejecting the recommendation of the Commonwealth Schools Commission made in June 1981 that the level of Commonwealth capital grants for government schools be determined and maintained on a triennial basis. (2) What were the Government's reasons for rejecting the Commission's proposal relating to changes in the basis of funding for recurrent grants to government schools. (3) Will the Government reconsider its decision on these mailers; if not, will he qualify the extent of his control over planning decisions which powers would appear to be invested in the Commonwealth Schools Commission. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) In its report for the 1982-84 triennium the Commonwealth Schools Commission recommend that the levels of both Commonwealth and State capital programs be determined and maintained on a triennial basis. The Government has decided that it would be appropriate to retain the Hexibility of determining the level of capital grants on an annual basis in the overall budgetary framework. Unlike the grants for universities and colleges of advanced education the government schools capital program is a shared program. In 1979-80 (the latest available figures for State Governments expenditure) the Commonwealth contributed about 30 per cent of the total expenditure in the States on capital programs for government schools. The States likewise determine their capital spending on an annual basis. (2) Again in the interests cided not to adopt a funding mechanism which tied Commonwealth recurrent grants for government schools to a per capita formula. There is no requirement on the States to either accept the resource standards proposed by the Commission or to determine resource provision on the basis of a fixed standard. Against this background and given that the Commonwealth contributes only about 9 per cent of funds for recurrent costs of government schools the Commonwealth determines its allocations on an annual basis. (3) The decisions made by the Government on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1982 will stand. The Commonwealth Schools Commission is the Government's chief advisory body on the needs of ment relating to those needs. In the final analysis, however, it is the Government which makes decisions on funding policy for Commonwealth programs. Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981: (I) Has his attention been drawn to the survey by the Council of Academic Staff Associations which suggests that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has over-estimated the supply of new graduates available for teaching by approximately 12 bined with under-estimates of the demand for teachers due to errors in estimated total loss rates, birth rates and migration levels, this over-estimate of will serve to create a substantital teacher shortage in several years time. (2) What steps does he intend to take to rectify this serious Schools prospect of teacher shortages. (Question No. 3601) Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) and (2) My attention has been drawn to Bulletin No. 15/81 published by the Council of Academic Staff Associations of Victorian Colleges of Advanced Education. The conclusions expressed, do, however, appear to be based on doubtful assumptions, for example that teacher resignation rates would increase more than have been allowed for. Even if these assumptions proved correct-and on balance this seemed unlikely-the approach adopted by both the Commonwealth and the States left room for short term adjustments to the numbers of teachers being trained. This could be done by adjusting intakes to one year diploma of education courses. It should also be noted that new graduates were not the only source of teacher recruitment-there were numbers of teachers available with previous experience who wished to reenter the teaching profession. Recent decisions taken by the Commonwealth Government to consolidate colleges of advanced education should help to create more Hexible institutions that could respond more readily to changes in demand for various types of courses. Any necessary adjustments to intakes to particular courses can be made within the overall level of resources available in each State over the 1982-84 triennium. Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) and (2) I have received representations expressing concern that the funds provided by the Commonwealth in 1981-82 towards vacation care programs remained at the previous year's level. I have replied to such representations, including those in respect of services in the Fairfield (New South Wales) area, advising that the Commonwealth provides funds to all State Governments in the form of an annual block (Question No. 3646) grant as a contribution towards the costs of providing vacation care services. Each State Government is responsible for determining priorities and for the allocation of the Commonwealth and State funds available for this purpose to individual projects, based on the State's assessment of competing areas of need. Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The Minister for Social Security has (Question No. 3658) provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) The Social Welfare Policy Secretariat's Report on Pov-. erty Measurement included an estimate that, excluding the self-employed, some 9.3 per cent of adult income units comprising over a million people had incomes below the Henderson poverty line in 1978-79. The exclusions of juveniles (unmarried persons aged under 21 who were not responsible for a dependent child) and the self-employed were made to achieve consistency with the Poverty Inquiry figures and because for cent increase in fees and the inthese groups annual income (as collected in the ABS Survey) may be a most inaccurate measure of their economic well-being. However, the SWPS report suggests that a further 130,000 juveniles may have had incomes in 1978-79 which were below the Henderson poverty line. (2) No. (3) The SWPS report concluded that 9.5 per cent of people (9.3 per cent of families) had incomes below the Henderson poverty line in 1978-79, compared with the Poverty Inquiry's estimate for 1972-73 of 8.2 per cent of people (10.2 per cent of families). The SWPS estimates may be more closely comparable with those in an International Labour Organisation publication by Professor Wilfred Beckerman of Oxford University. These estimates indicated that in 1973-74 about 10 per cent of people (about II per cent of families) were in poverty as measured by the Henderson line. Thus it cannot be concluded that the proportion of the Australian population living below the Henderson poverty line was 'substantially higher'in 1978-79 than it had been in the early 1970's. (4) The SWPS report concluded that the Henderson poverty lines could not be considered as an objective or unambiguous measure of poverty in Australia. The Henderson lines were not based on a study of needs in Australia. The lines were based on an arbitrarily total of the Melbourne basic wage in 1966 plus child endowment) for a standard family of a working husband, a nonworking wife and two children. The equivalence scales used to derive poverty lines for other than standard families were based on relativities between expenditures of different families in New York in 1954. They are at best of doubtful relevance to A-stralia in the 1980's. The SWPS report includes indicative equivalence scales which show important differences from the scales incorporated in the Henderson poverty line. (5) Senator Guilfoyle stated 1980 that she had recently asked the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, in consultation with her own Department, to examine the whole issue of alernative approaches to measure a poverty line that would be relevant to Australia in the 1980's. (6) The report has not established a new poverty line although, as suggested above, a number of equivalence scales which may have indicative usefulness have been calculated. The Secretariat concluded that there was no objective method of establishing which level of income was adequate or appropriate: that was a matter of personal or political judgment. (7) and (8) The Government will have a number of sources of information for deciding where come available for social security purposes may best be spent. The SWPS report contains a good deal of information about the groups in the community with the lowest relative incomes. The Government will naturally pay attention to the views expressed by consultative committees, welfare organisations and individuals.
